SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.

  Laertes, son to Polonius.

  A Gentleman, courtier.

  Francisco, a soldier
  Reynaldo, servant to Polonius.

  Players.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
COMMERCIALLY.



ACT I.
 Scene I.


  Ber.
 Well, good night.


                    Enter Horatio and Marcellus.
 Bernardo hath my place.
                                   Exit.
 Say-
    What, is Horatio there ?
  Hor.
 I have seen nothing.

  Hor.

  Ber.

  Ber.


  Mar.
 Thou art a scholar; speak to it, Horatio.

  Mar.

  Ber.

  Mar.
 Our last king,
    Whose image even but now appear'd to us,
    Was, as you know, by Fortinbras of Norway,
    Thereto prick'd on by a most emulate pride,
    Dar'd to the combat; in which our valiant Hamlet
    (For so this side of our known world esteem'd him)
    Did slay this Fortinbras; who, by a seal'd compact,
    Well ratified by law and heraldry,
    Did forfeit, with his life, all those his lands
    Which he stood seiz'd of, to the conqueror;
    Against the which a moiety competent
    Was gaged by our king; which had return'd
    To the inheritance of Fortinbras,
    Had he been vanquisher, as, by the same comart
    And carriage of the article design'd,
    His fell to Hamlet.

    And even the like precurse of fierce events,
    As harbingers preceding still the fates
    And prologue to the omen coming on,
    Have heaven and earth together demonstrated
    Unto our climature and countrymen.
- Stay illusion!
                                               Spreads his arms.
  
    If thou art privy to thy country's fate,
    Which happily foreknowing may avoid,
    O, speak!
    Or if thou hast uphoarded in thy life
    Extorted treasure in the womb of earth
    (For which, they say, you spirits oft walk in death),
                                                 The cock crows.
 Do, if it will not stand.
 It faded on the crowing of the cock.

    Break we our watch up; and by my advice  
    Let us impart what we have seen to-night
    Unto young Hamlet; for, upon my life,
    This spirit, dumb to us, will speak to him.
           Exeunt.


Flourish.
 [Enter Claudius, King of Denmark, Gertrude the Queen, Hamlet,
Polonius, Laertes and his sister Ophelia, [Voltemand, Cornelius,]
Lords Attendant.

    Therefore our sometime sister, now our queen,
    Th' imperial jointress to this warlike state,
    Have we, as 'twere with a defeated joy,
    With an auspicious, and a dropping eye,
    With mirth in funeral, and with dirge in marriage,
    In equal scale weighing delight and dole,
    Taken to wife; nor have we herein barr'd
    Your better wisdoms, which have freely gone  
    With this affair along.
, Volt.

    What wouldst thou have, Laertes?
  Laer.
 My dread lord,
    Your leave and favour to return to France;
    From whence though willingly I came to Denmark
    To show my duty in your coronation,  
    Yet now I must confess, that duty done,
    My thoughts and wishes bend again toward France
    And bow them to your gracious leave and pardon.
 Not so, my lord.

  Queen.
 Good Hamlet, cast thy nighted colour off,
    And let thine eye look like a friend on Denmark.

    Do not for ever with thy vailed lids
    Seek for thy noble father in the dust.
 These indeed seem,
    For they are actions that a man might play;
    But I have that within which passeth show-
    These but the trappings and the suits of woe.
 Let not thy mother lose her prayers, Hamlet.
 I shall in all my best obey you, madam.

    Horatio!- or I do forget myself.
- [To Bernardo] Good even, sir.
 I would not hear your enemy say so,
    Nor shall you do my ear that violence
    To make it truster of your own report
    Against yourself.
 My lord, I came to see your father's funeral.
 Indeed, my lord, it followed hard upon.

    Would I had met my dearest foe in heaven
    Or ever I had seen that day, Horatio!
    My father- methinks I see my father.

  Hor.

  Hor.
 My lord, I think I saw him yesternight.
 Saw? who?
  Hor.
 Two nights together had these gentlemen
    (Marcellus and Bernardo) on their watch
    In the dead vast and middle of the night
    Been thus encount'red.
 This to me
    In dreadful secrecy impart they did,
    And I with them the third night kept the watch;
    Where, as they had deliver'd, both in time,
    Form of the thing, each word made true and good,
    The apparition comes.

  Ham.
 My lord, I did;
    But answer made it none.

  Ham.

  Hor.
 As I do live, my honour'd lord, 'tis true;  
    And we did think it writ down in our duty
    To let you know of it.
 Arm'd, my lord.

  Ham.

  Ham.

  Hor.

  Ham.
 Most constantly.
 It would have much amaz'd you.

  Both.
 I will watch to-night.

    Upon the platform, 'twixt eleven and twelve,
    I'll visit you.
 Farewell.
 Would the night were come!
    Till then sit still, my soul.

    Fear it, Ophelia, fear it, my dear sister,
    And keep you in the rear of your affection,  
    Out of the shot and danger of desire.

    The canker galls the infants of the spring
    Too oft before their buttons be disclos'd,
    And in the morn and liquid dew of youth
    Contagious blastments are most imminent.
 I shall th' effect of this good lesson keep
    As watchman to my heart.

  Pol.

    Give every man thine ear, but few thy voice;
    Take each man's censure, but reserve thy judgment.

    Neither a borrower nor a lender be;
    For loan oft loses both itself and friend,
    And borrowing dulls the edge of husbandry.

  Pol.
 The time invites you.
 Farewell, Ophelia, and remember well
    What I have said to you.
 'Tis in my memory lock'd,
    And you yourself shall keep the key of it.

  Laer.
 What is't, Ophelia, he hath said to you?
  Oph.
 So please you, something touching the Lord Hamlet.
 Marry, well bethought!
    'Tis told me he hath very oft of late
    Given private time to you, and you yourself
    Have of your audience been most free and bounteous.
 My lord, he hath importun'd me with love
    In honourable fashion.
 From this time
    Be something scanter of your maiden presence.
 For Lord Hamlet,
    Believe so much in him, that he is young,
    And with a larger tether may he walk
    Than may be given you.

Elsinore.

  Ham.
 What hour now?
  Hor.
 It then draws near the season
    Wherein the spirit held his wont to walk.
 The dram of e'il
    Doth all the noble substance often dout To his own scandal.


                         Enter Ghost.
 Look, my lord, it comes!
  Ham.
 No, by no means!
  Ham.
 It will not speak.
 Why, what should be the fear?
    I do not set my life at a pin's fee;
    And for my soul, what can it do to that,
    Being a thing immortal as itself?  
    It waves me forth again.
 I'll follow it.

    Go on.
 You shall not go, my lord.

  Ham.
 Be rul'd.

  Hor.

                                                         Exeunt.


Enter Ghost and Hamlet.
 I am bound to hear.
 What?
  Ghost.
 I am thy father's spirit,
    Doom'd for a certain term to walk the night,
    And for the day confin'd to fast in fires,
    Till the foul crimes done in my days of nature
    Are burnt and purg'd away.

    But this eternal blazon must not be
    To ears of flesh and blood.
 List, list, O, list!
    If thou didst ever thy dear father love-
  Ham.
 O God!
  Ghost.
 Murther most foul, as in the best it is;
    But this most foul, strange, and unnatural.
 So the whole ear of Denmark
    Is by a forged process of my death
    Rankly abus'd.

  Ham.
 O my prophetic soul!
    My uncle?
  Ghost.

    Thus was I, sleeping, by a brother's hand
    Of life, of crown, of queen, at once dispatch'd;
    Cut off even in the blossoms of my sin,
    Unhous'led, disappointed, unanel'd,
    No reckoning made, but sent to my account
    With all my imperfections on my head.
 O, horrible! O, horrible! most horrible!
  Ghost.

    Adieu, adieu, adieu! Remember me.
  
  Ham.
 Yes, by heaven!
    O most pernicious woman!
    O villain, villain, smiling, damned villain!
    My tables! Meet it is I set it down
    That one may smile, and smile, and be a villain;
    At least I am sure it may be so in Denmark.
        [Writes.
 Now to my word:
    It is 'Adieu, adieu! Remember me.
'  
    I have sworn't.
 Lord Hamlet!
  Hor.
 O, wonderful!
  Hor.
 Good my lord, tell it.
 No, you will reveal it.
 There needs no ghost, my lord, come from the grave
    To tell us this.

  Hor.
 These are but wild and whirling words, my lord.

  Hor.
 There's no offence, my lord.

  Both.

  Hor.


                 Ghost cries under the stage.


  Ghost.

  Ham.

    Consent to swear.
 Never to speak of this that you have seen.

    There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio,
    Than are dreamt of in your philosophy.
 [beneath] Swear.

                                                   [They swear.

    The time is out of joint.

Elsinore.

  Pol.
 You shall do marvell's wisely, good Reynaldo,
    Before You visit him, to make inquire
    Of his behaviour.
 Look you, sir,
    Enquire me first what Danskers are in Paris;
    And how, and who, what means, and where they keep,
    What company, at what expense; and finding
    By this encompassment and drift of question
    That they do know my son, come you more nearer
    Than your particular demands will touch it.

    Take you, as 'twere, some distant knowledge of him;
    As thus, 'I know his father and his friends,
    And in part him.

  Pol.
 But breathe his faults so quaintly
    That they may seem the taints of liberty,
    The flash and outbreak of a fiery mind,
    A savageness in unreclaimed blood,
    Of general assault.
 Marry, sir, here's my drift,
    And I believe it is a fetch of warrant.
 Very good, my lord.

  Pol.

    I saw him yesterday, or t'other day,
    Or then, or then, with such or such; and, as you say,
    There was 'a gaming; there o'ertook in's rouse;
    There falling out at tennis'; or perchance,
    'I saw him enter such a house of sale,'
    Videlicet, a brothel, or so forth.
 You have me, have you not
  Rey.
 Good my lord!                                    [Going.
]
  Pol.
 I shall, my lord.
 My lord, as I was sewing in my closet,
    Lord Hamlet, with his doublet all unbrac'd,
    No hat upon his head, his stockings foul'd,
    Ungart'red, and down-gyved to his ankle;
    Pale as his shirt, his knees knocking each other,
    And with a look so piteous in purport
    As if he had been loosed out of hell
    To speak of horrors- he comes before me.

  Pol.
 I will go seek the King.
 I am sorry.

  Pol.
 I fear'd he did but trifle
    And meant to wrack thee; but beshrew my jealousy!
    By heaven, it is as proper to our age
    To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions
    As it is common for the younger sort
    To lack discretion.

    This must be known; which, being kept close, might move
    More grief to hide than hate to utter love.

  Queen.

  Guil.
 Ay, amen!
                 Exeunt Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, [with some
                                                    Attendants].


  Pol.
 Th' ambassadors from Norway, my good lord,
    Are joyfully return'd.

  King.
 Have I, my lord? Assure you, my good liege,
    I hold my duty as I hold my soul,
    Both to my God and to my gracious king;
    And I do think- or else this brain of mine
    Hunts not the trail of policy so sure
    As it hath us'd to do- that I have found  
    The very cause of Hamlet's lunacy.

                                                [Exit Polonius.
 I doubt it is no other but the main,
    His father's death and our o'erhasty marriage.
 Well, we shall sift him.
 Most fair return of greetings and desires.

    Upon our first, he sent out to suppress
    His nephew's levies; which to him appear'd
    To be a preparation 'gainst the Polack,  
    But better look'd into, he truly found
    It was against your Highness; whereat griev'd,
    That so his sickness, age, and impotence
    Was falsely borne in hand, sends out arrests
    On Fortinbras; which he, in brief, obeys,
    Receives rebuke from Norway, and, in fine,
    Makes vow before his uncle never more
    To give th' assay of arms against your Majesty.

  Pol.

    Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit,
    And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes,
    I will be brief.
 And now remains
    That we find out the cause of this effect-
    Or rather say, the cause of this defect,
    For this effect defective comes by cause.
 Now gather, and surmise.
]
    'In her excellent white bosom, these, &c.
 Good madam, stay awhile.
     [Reads.

      'Thine evermore, most dear lady, whilst this machine is to him,
                                                          HAMLET.

    This must not be.
?
  King.

  Pol.
 [points to his head and shoulder] Take this from this, if this
      be otherwise.
 If he love her not,
    And he not from his reason fall'n thereon
    Let me be no assistant for a state,  
    But keep a farm and carters.

  Pol.

                       Exeunt King and Queen, [with Attendants].
 Then I would you were so honest a man.

  Ham.
 Let her not walk i' th' sun.

  Pol.
 [aside] How say you by that? Still harping on my daughter.
- What do you
    read, my lord?
  Ham.
 Slanders, sir; for the satirical rogue says here that old men
    have grey beards; that their faces are wrinkled; their eyes
    purging thick amber and plum-tree gum; and that they have a
    plentiful lack of wit, together with most weak hams.
 [aside] Though this be madness, yet there is a method in't.
 Into my grave?
  Pol.
 You go to seek the Lord Hamlet.
 There he is.
  
  Guil.
 Nor the soles of her shoe?
  Ros.

  Ham.
 Denmark's a prison.
 'Tis too narrow for your
    mind.

  Ham.

  Ros.
 Then are our beggars bodies, and our monarchs and outstretch'd
    heroes the beggars' shadows.
 Shall we to th' court? for, by my
    fay, I cannot reason.

  Both.
 We'll wait upon you.
 Were
    you not sent for? Is it your own inclining? Is it a free
    visitation? Come, deal justly with me.
 But let me conjure you by the rights
    of our fellowship, by the consonancy of our youth, by the
    obligation of our ever-preserved love, and by what more dear a
    better proposer could charge you withal, be even and direct with
    me, whether you were sent for or no.
  
  Ros.

  Guil.
 My lord, we were sent for.

  Ros.
 Nay, their endeavour keeps in the wonted pace; but there is,
    sir, an eyrie of children, little eyases, that cry out on the top
    of question and are most tyrannically clapp'd fort.


  Guil.

  Ham.


  Pol.
 Hark you, Guildenstern- and you too- at each ear a hearer!
    That great baby you see there is not yet out of his swaddling
    clouts.

  Ros.
 Mark it.

  Pol.
 When Roscius was an actor in
    Rome-
  Pol.
 Upon my honour-
  Ham.

  Ham.
 Play.

  Pol.
 Unequal match'd,
      Pyrrhus at Priam drives, in rage strikes wide;
      But with the whiff and wind of his fell sword  
      Th' unnerved father falls.

      Out, out, thou strumpet Fortune! All you gods,  
      In general synod take away her power;
      Break all the spokes and fellies from her wheel,
      And bowl the round nave down the hill of heaven,
      As low as to the fiends!

  Pol.
 It shall to the barber's, with your beard.
 That's good! 'Mobled queen' is good.
 Look, whe'r he has not turn'd his colour, and has tears in's
    eyes.

  Ham.
 God's bodykins, man, much better! Use every man after his
    desert, and who should scape whipping? Use them after your own  
    honour and dignity.

  Ham.
 Follow that lord- and look you mock him not.
]
    My good friends, I'll leave you till night.
 The play's the thing
    Wherein I'll catch the conscience of the King.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
 Scene I.
 Most like a gentleman.

  Ros.

  King.
 With all my heart, and it doth much content me
    To hear him so inclin'd.

    Good gentlemen, give him a further edge
    And drive his purpose on to these delights.

                            Exeunt Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.
 Sweet Gertrude, leave us too;
    For we have closely sent for Hamlet hither,
    That he, as 'twere by accident, may here
    Affront Ophelia.
 Madam, I wish it may.
]
  Pol.
 There's the respect
    That makes calamity of so long life.

    For who would bear the whips and scorns of time,
    Th' oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely,
    The pangs of despis'd love, the law's delay,
    The insolence of office, and the spurns
    That patient merit of th' unworthy takes,
    When he himself might his quietus make
    With a bare bodkin? Who would these fardels bear,
    To grunt and sweat under a weary life,
    But that the dread of something after death-
    The undiscover'd country, from whose bourn
    No traveller returns- puzzles the will,
    And makes us rather bear those ills we have
    Than fly to others that we know not of?
    Thus conscience does make cowards of us all,  
    And thus the native hue of resolution
    Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought,
    And enterprises of great pith and moment
    With this regard their currents turn awry
    And lose the name of action.
- Soft you now!
    The fair Ophelia!- Nymph, in thy orisons
    Be all my sins rememb'red.
 What means your lordship?
  Ham.

  Oph.
 Ay, truly; for the power of beauty will sooner transform
    honesty from what it is to a bawd than the force of honesty can
    translate beauty into his likeness.
 I did love you once.

  Oph.
 Indeed, my lord, you made me believe so.

  Ham.
 Let the doors be shut upon him, that he may play the fool
    nowhere but in's own house.

  Oph.
 Go, farewell.
 Go to, I'll no more on't! it hath made
    me mad.
 To a nunnery, go.
 O, woe is me
    T' have seen what I have seen, see what I see!

                   Enter King and Polonius.


  King.
- How now, Ophelia?
    You need not tell us what Lord Hamlet said.
- My lord, do as you please;
    But if you hold it fit, after the play
    Let his queen mother all alone entreat him  
    To show his grief.





Scene II.
 O, it offends me to the
    soul to hear a robustious periwig-pated fellow tear a passion to
    tatters, to very rags, to split the cars of the groundlings, who
    (for the most part) are capable of nothing but inexplicable dumb
    shows and noise.
 It out-herods Herod.

  Ham.

  Player.
 For there be of them
    that will themselves laugh, to set on some quantity of barren
    spectators to laugh too, though in the mean time some necessary
    question of the play be then to be considered.
 What, ho, Horatio!

                      Enter Horatio.
 Horatio, thou art e'en as just a man
    As e'er my conversation cop'd withal.
 [Enter Trumpets and Kettledrums.
 Danish
    march.


  Ham.

  King.
 I have nothing with this answer, Hamlet.
 These words are not
    mine.

  Ham.
 [To Polonius] My lord, you play'd once
    i' th' university, you say?
  Pol.

  Ham.
 It was a brute part of him to kill so capital a calf there.
 They stay upon your patience.

  Ham.
 Here's metal more attractive.

  Pol.
 [to the King] O, ho! do you mark that?
  Ham.

  Ham.
 That's a fair thought to lie between maids' legs.
 What is, my lord?
  Ham.

  Ham.
 O God, your only jig-maker! What should a man do but be merry?
    For look you how cheerfully my mother looks, and my father died
    within 's two hours.
 But, by'r Lady, he must build churches then; or else
    shall he suffer not thinking on, with the hobby-horse, whose  
    epitaph is 'For O, for O, the hobby-horse is forgot!'

               Hautboys play.
 The dead body is
    carried away.

                                                         Exeunt.


  Oph.
 Belike this show imports the argument of the play.
 Will he tell us what this show meant?
  Ham.
 For us, and for our tragedy,
      Here stooping to your clemency,
      We beg your hearing patiently.

  Ham.


              Enter [two Players as] King and Queen.
 So many journeys may the sun and moon
      Make us again count o'er ere love be done!
      But woe is me! you are so sick of late,
      So far from cheer and from your former state.

      Now what my love is, proof hath made you know;
      And as my love is siz'd, my fear is so.

      A second time I kill my husband dead
      When second husband kisses me in bed.

      What to ourselves in passion we propose,
      The passion ending, doth the purpose lose.

      The violence of either grief or joy
      Their own enactures with themselves destroy.

    Queen.
 If she should break it now!

    King.
 The lady doth protest too much, methinks.
 'The Mousetrap.
 You are as good as a chorus, my lord.

  Ham.
 You are keen, my lord, you are keen.

  Ham.

  Ham.
 Pox, leave
    thy damnable faces, and begin! Come, the croaking raven doth
    bellow for revenge.
 The King rises.

  Ham.
 What, frighted with false fire?
  Queen.
   Why, let the strucken deer go weep,
          The hart ungalled play;
         For some must watch, while some must sleep:
          Thus runs the world away.

  Ham.

  Ham.

  Ham.
 Your wisdom should show itself more richer to signify this to
    the doctor; for me to put him to his purgation would perhaps
    plunge him into far more choler.

  Guil.

  Ham.

  Guil.
 You are welcome.

    If it shall please you to make me a wholesome answer, I will do
    your mother's commandment; if not, your pardon and my return
    shall be the end of my business.

  Guil.
 But, sir, such
    answer is I can make, you shall command; or rather, as you say,
    my mother.
 Have you any
    further trade with us?
  Ros.
 And do still, by these pickers and stealers!
  Ros.
 Ay, sir, but 'while the grass grows'- the proverb is something
    musty.

  Ham.
 Believe me, I cannot.

  Ham.
 I know, no touch of it, my lord.
 Look you, these are the stops.
 I
    have not the skill.


                        Enter Polonius.
 My lord, the Queen would speak with you, and presently.

  Ham.
 Very like a whale.
 Then will I come to my mother by-and-by.
 Therefore prepare you;
    I your commission will forthwith dispatch,
    And he to England shall along with you.

  Ros.
 Arm you, I pray you, to th', speedy voyage;
    For we will fetters put upon this fear,
    Which now goes too free-footed.

  Both.
 We will haste us.


                   Enter Polonius.

    Behind the arras I'll convey myself
    To hear the process.

    I'll call upon you ere you go to bed
    And tell you what I know.

  King.

                                                Exit [Polonius].
 Now might I do it pat, now he is praying;
    And now I'll do't.

    Why, this is hire and salary, not revenge!
    He took my father grossly, full of bread,
    With all his crimes broad blown, as flush as May;
    And how his audit stands, who knows save heaven?
    But in our circumstance and course of thought,
    'Tis heavy with him; and am I then reveng'd,
    To take him in the purging of his soul,
    When he is fit and seasoned for his passage?  
    No.
 My mother stays.

The Queen's closet.

  Ham.

                              [Polonius hides behind the arras.

  Queen.
 Come, come, and sit you down.
 [draws] How now? a rat? Dead for a ducat, dead!
            [Makes a pass through the arras and] kills Polonius.
 A bloody deed- almost as bad, good mother,
    As kill a king, and marry with his brother.
 As kill a king?
  Ham.
 Ay, lady, it was my word.

                         [Lifts up the arras and sees Polonius.

    Leave wringing of your hinds.
 O, such a deed
    As from the body of contraction plucks  
    The very soul, and sweet religion makes
    A rhapsody of words! Heaven's face doth glow;
    Yea, this solidity and compound mass,
    With tristful visage, as against the doom,
    Is thought-sick at the act.

  Queen.

    Here is your husband, like a mildew'd ear
    Blasting his wholesome brother.

  Queen.
 A murtherer and a villain!
    A slave that is not twentieth part the tithe
    Of your precedent lord; a vice of kings;
    A cutpurse of the empire and the rule,
    That from a shelf the precious diadem stole
    And put it in his pocket!  
  Queen.
 No more!

                Enter the Ghost in his nightgown.
 This visitation
    Is but to whet thy almost blunted purpose.

    But look, amazement on thy mother sits.

  Ham.
 On him, on him! Look you how pale he glares!
    His form and cause conjoin'd, preaching to stones,
    Would make them capable.

  Ham.
 It is not madness
    That I have utt'red.
 Bring me to the test,
    And I the matter will reword; which madness
    Would gambol from.

    That monster, custom, who all sense doth eat
    Of habits evil, is angel yet in this,
    That to the use of actions fair and good
    He likewise gives a frock or livery,
    That aptly is put on.

  Queen.
 'Twere good you let him know;
    For who that's but a queen, fair, sober, wise,
    Would from a paddock, from a bat, a gib
    Such dear concernings hide? Who would do so?  
    No, in despite of sense and secrecy,
    Unpeg the basket on the house's top,
    Let the birds fly, and like the famous ape,
    To try conclusions, in the basket creep
    And break your own neck down.
  
    This man shall set me packing.

    Come, sir, to draw toward an end with you.


  King.
 There's matter in these sighs.
]
    Ah, mine own lord, what have I seen to-night!
  King.
 What, Gertrude? How does Hamlet?
  Queen.

  King.
 O heavy deed!
    It had been so with us, had we been there.

    His liberty is full of threats to all-
    To you yourself, to us, to every one.
 He weeps for what is done.

  King.

  
    Friends both, go join you with some further aid.
- O, come away!
    My soul is full of discord and dismay.
 A passage in the Castle.


Enter Hamlet.
 (within) Hamlet! Lord Hamlet!
  Ham.


  Ros.
 Tell us where 'tis, that we may take it thence
    And bear it to the chapel.
 Do not believe it.
 But such officers do the King best service in
    the end.
 When he needs what you have
    glean'd, it is but squeezing you and, sponge, you shall be dry
    again.
 My lord, you must tell us where the body is and go with us to
    the King.
 Bring me to him.


    How now O What hath befall'n?
  Ros.
 Where the dead body is bestow'd, my lord,
    We cannot get from him.
  
  King.
 Your worm is your
    only emperor for diet.
 We fat all creatures else to fat us, and
    we fat ourselves for maggots.
 Alas, alas!
  Ham.

  King.

                                            [Exeunt Attendants.
 Hamlet, this deed, for thine especial safety,-
    Which we do tender as we dearly grieve
    For that which thou hast done,- must send thee hence
    With fiery quickness.

    The bark is ready and the wind at help,
    Th' associates tend, and everything is bent
    For England.
 Ay, Hamlet.

  Ham.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE

SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
 Go, Captain, from me greet the Danish king.

  Capt.
 Against some part of Poland.

  Ham.

  Ham.
 Why, then the Polack never will defend it.

  Capt.
- I humbly thank you, sir.

  Capt.
 God b' wi' you, sir.
]
  Ros.
 Will't please you go, my lord?
  Ham.
 I'll be with you straight.
 Now, whether it be
    Bestial oblivion, or some craven scruple
    Of thinking too precisely on th' event,-
    A thought which, quarter'd, hath but one part wisdom
    And ever three parts coward,- I do not know
    Why yet I live to say 'This thing's to do,'
    Sith I have cause, and will, and strength, and means
    To do't.


Enter Horatio, Queen, and a Gentleman.

  Queen.
  
                                               [Exit Gentleman.
 Say you? Nay, pray You mark.


    O, ho!
  Queen.
 Nay, but Ophelia-
  Oph.
 (Sings)
           Larded all with sweet flowers;
         Which bewept to the grave did not go
           With true-love showers.


  King.
'

  King.
 We must be patient; but I cannot
    choose but weep to think they would lay him i' th' cold ground.
 Good night, good night.
 Follow her close; give her good watch, I pray you.


  Laer.
 We will, we will!
  Laer.
 I thank you.
 Calmly, good Laertes.
 That drop of blood that's calm proclaims me bastard;
    Cries cuckold to my father; brands the harlot
    Even here between the chaste unsmirched brows
    Of my true mother.
 Tell me, Laertes,
    Why thou art thus incens'd.
 Where is my father?
  King.
 Let him demand his fill.
 Who shall stay you?
  Laer.
 My will, not all the world!
    And for my means, I'll husband them so well
    They shall go far with little.

                              A noise within: 'Let her come in.
 You must sing 'A-down a-down, and you call him a-down-a.

  Laer.
 Pray you, love,
    remember.
 There's rue for you,
    and here's some for me.
 They say he made a good end.

  Oph.


         His beard was as white as snow,
         All flaxen was his poll.

    I pray you go with me.

                                                          Exeunt

Elsinore.


Enter Horatio with an Attendant.


  Sailor.
 God bless you, sir.
 Let him bless thee too.
 On the instant they got clear of our ship; so I
    alone became their prisoner.
 Farewell.
                   Exeunt.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
 Now must your conscience my acquittance seal,
    And You must put me in your heart for friend,
    Sith you have heard, and with a knowing ear,
    That he which hath your noble father slain
    Pursued my life.
 It well appears.
 But tell me
    Why you proceeded not against these feats
    So crimeful and so capital in nature,
    As by your safety, wisdom, all things else,
    You mainly were stirr'd up.

    They were given me by Claudio; he receiv'd them
    Of him that brought them.

  King.

    [Reads]'High and Mighty,-You shall know I am set naked on your
    kingdom.
 To-morrow shall I beg leave to see your kingly eyes;
    when I shall (first asking your pardon thereunto) recount the
    occasion of my sudden and more strange return.

                                                     'HAMLET.
 'Tis Hamlet's character.
 Ay my lord,
    So you will not o'errule me to a peace.

    I have seen myself, and serv'd against, the French,
    And they can well on horseback; but this gallant  
    Had witchcraft in't.
 So far he topp'd my thought
    That I, in forgery of shapes and tricks,
    Come short of what he did.
 The very same.
 What out of this, my lord?
  King.
 To cut his throat i' th' church!
  King.
 But, good Laertes,
    Will you do this? Keep close within your chamber.

    Will return'd shall know you are come home.
  
  Laer.
- But stay, what noise,

                           Enter Queen.
 Your sister's drown'd, Laertes.
 Drown'd! O, where?
  Queen.
 There is a willow grows aslant a brook,
    That shows his hoar leaves in the glassy stream.
                          Exit.
  
    How much I had to do to calm his rage I
    Now fear I this will give it start again;
    Therefore let's follow.

                                                         Exeunt.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE

  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
 Why, 'tis found so.
  
  Other.
 Why, he had none.
 I like thy wit well, in good faith.
 The gallows does well.
 Who builds stronger than a mason, a shipwright, or a
    carpenter?
  Clown.

  Other.


                 Enter Hamlet and Horatio afar off.
' The houses he makes lasts
    till doomsday.


       In youth when I did love, did love,
         Methought it was very sweet;
       To contract- O- the time for- a- my behove,
         O, methought there- a- was nothing- a- meet.
 Custom hath made it in him a Property of easiness.

                                            [Throws up a skull.
 It might, my lord.

  Ham.
 Did these bones cost no more the
    breeding but to play at loggets with 'em? Mine ache to think
    on't.

                                      Throws up [another skull].
 Whose grave's this, sirrah?
  Clown.
 You lie out on't, sir, and therefore 'tis not yours.
 Thou dost lie in't, to be in't and say it is thine.

  Clown.

  Ham.
 What woman then?
  Clown.
- How long hast thou been a grave-maker?
  Clown.

  Ham.
 Why?
  Clown.
 How strangely?
  Clown.
 Faith, e'en with losing his wits.
 Why he more than another?
  Clown.
 Whose was it?
  Clown.
 He
    hath borne me on his back a thousand tunes.
 And now how abhorred
    in my imagination it is! My gorge rises at it.

  Ham.
 And smelt so? Pah!
                                          [Puts down the skull.
]
  Hor.
  
  Ham.
 'Twas of some estate.
 Mark.
 What ceremony else?
  Priest.
 Her death was doubtful;
    And, but that great command o'ersways the order,
    She should in ground unsanctified have lodg'd
    Till the last trumpet.

    Yet here she is allow'd her virgin crants,
    Her maiden strewments, and the bringing home
    Of bell and burial.

    We should profane the service of the dead
    To sing a requiem and such rest to her
    As to peace-parted souls.
 Lay her i' th' earth;
    And from her fair and unpolluted flesh  
    May violets spring! I tell thee, churlish priest,
    A minist'ring angel shall my sister be
    When thou liest howling.

  Ham.
 What, the fair Ophelia?
  Queen.
 O, treble woe
    Fall ten times treble on that cursed head
    Whose wicked deed thy most ingenious sense
    Depriv'd thee of! Hold off the earth awhile,
    Till I have caught her once more in mine arms.
 Gentlemen!
  Hor.
 O my son, what theme?  
  Ham.

  Queen.
 Dost thou come here to whine?
    To outface me with leaping in her grave?
    Be buried quick with her, and so will I.

    Anon, as patient as the female dove
    When that her golden couplets are disclos'd,  
    His silence will sit drooping.
-
    This grave shall have a living monument.

                                                         Exeunt.
 I beseech you.
 I sat me down;
    Devis'd a new commission; wrote it fair.
 Ay, good my lord.

  Hor.

    'Tis dangerous when the baser nature comes
    Between the pass and fell incensed points
    Of mighty opposites.
 Does it not, thinks't thee, stand me now upon-
    He that hath kill'd my king, and whor'd my mother;
    Popp'd in between th' election and my hopes;
    Thrown out his angle for my Proper life,
    And with such coz'nage- is't not perfect conscience
    To quit him with this arm? And is't not to be damn'd
    To let this canker of our nature come
    In further evil?
  Hor.
 Let a beast be
    lord of beasts, and his crib shall stand at the king's mess.
 I will receive it, sir, with all diligence of spirit.
 'Tis for the head.
 I thank your lordship, it is very hot.
 No, believe me, 'tis very cold; the wind is northerly.
 It is indifferent cold, my lord, indeed.

  Ham.
 I beseech you remember.

  Osr.

  Ham.
 Of Laertes?
  Hor.

  Ham.
 I dare not confess that, lest I should compare with him in
    excellence; but to know a man well were to know himself.

  Ham.

  Osr.
 Why is this all impon'd, as you call it?
  Osr.
 This lapwing runs away with the shell on his head.
  
  Ham.
 He did comply with his dug before he suck'd it.


  Lord.
 He sends to
    know if your pleasure hold to play with Laertes, or that you will
    take longer time.

  Ham.
 You will lose this wager, my lord.
 I shall win at the odds.
 If your mind dislike anything, obey it.

  Ham.
 If it be now, 'tis not to come', if it be
    not to come, it will be now; if it be not now, yet it will come:
    the readiness is all.


    Enter King, Queen, Laertes, Osric, and Lords, with other
              Attendants with foils and gauntlets.

               A table and flagons of wine on it.
 I am satisfied in nature,
    Whose motive in this case should stir me most
    To my revenge.
 But till that time
    I do receive your offer'd love like love,
    And will not wrong it.
 Come on.
 In mine ignorance
    Your skill shall, like a star i' th' darkest night,
    Stick fiery off indeed.

  Ham.
  
  King.
 Give them the foils, young Osric.
 Very well, my lord.
 Come on, sir.

  Laer.
 Come, my lord.

  Laer.

  Laer.
 Stay, give me drink.

               [Drum; trumpets sound; a piece goes off [within].
 A touch, a touch; I do confess't.

  King.
 He's fat, and scant of breath.
 Gertrude, do not drink.

  Queen.
 My lord, I'll hit him now.
 Nay come! again!                         The Queen falls.
 It is here, Hamlet.
                    Hurts the King.

  All.

  Ham.

    I am dead, Horatio.

    I am more an antique Roman than a Dane.
 As th'art a man,
    Give me the cup.
         [March afar off, and shot within.
]
    What warlike noise is this?
  Osr.
 O, I die, Horatio!
    The potent poison quite o'ercrows my spirit.

    I cannot live to hear the news from England,
    But I do prophesy th' election lights  
    On Fortinbras.

  Hor.

    Where should We have our thanks?
  Hor.

    He never gave commandment for their death.

    But since, so jump upon this bloody question,
    You from the Polack wars, and you from England,
    Are here arriv'd, give order that these bodies
    High on a stage be placed to the view;
    And let me speak to the yet unknowing world
    How these things came about.

    For me, with sorrow I embrace my fortune.

    I have some rights of memory in this kingdom
    Which now, to claim my vantage doth invite me.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.

  Sir Michael, a friend to the Archbishop of York.

  Poins.

  
  Lady Percy, wife to Hotspur, and sister to Mortimer.





<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
--England and Wales.
 Scene I.


  King.

    But this our purpose now is twelvemonth old,
    And bootless 'tis to tell you we will go.

  King.
 Here is a dear, a true-industrious friend,
    Sir Walter Blunt, new lighted from his horse,
    Stain'd with the variation of each soil
    Betwixt that Holmedon and this seat of ours,
    And he hath brought us smooth and welcome news.
 Of prisoners, Hotspur took
    Mordake Earl of Fife and eldest son
    To beaten Douglas, and the Earl of Athol,
    Of Murray, Angus, and Menteith.

    And is not this an honourable spoil?
    A gallant prize? Ha, cousin, is it not?
  West.

  West.
 This is his uncle's teaching, this Worcester,  
    Malevolent to you In all aspects,
    Which makes him prune himself and bristle up
    The crest of youth against your dignity.
 Now, Hal, what time of day is it, lad?
  Prince.
 Thou art so fat-witted with drinking of old sack, and
    unbuttoning thee after supper, and sleeping upon benches after
    noon, that thou hast forgotten to demand that truly which thou
    wouldest truly know.

  Fal.
 Indeed you come near me now, Hal; for we that take purses go
    by the moon And the seven stars, and not by Phoebus, he, that
    wand'ring knight so fair.
 And I prithee, sweet wag, when thou art
    king, as, God save thy Grace-Majesty I should say, for grace thou
    wilt have none-
  Prince.
 Thou sayest well, and it holds well too; for the fortune of
    us that are the moon's men doth ebb and flow like the sea, being
    governed, as the sea is, by the moon.
 As, for proof now: a purse
    of gold most resolutely snatch'd on Monday night and most
    dissolutely spent on Tuesday morning; got with swearing 'Lay by,'
    and spent with crying 'Bring in'; now ill as low an ebb as the
    foot of the ladder, and by-and-by in as high a flow as the ridge
    of the gallows.
 Well, thou hast call'd her to a reckoning many a time and oft.
 Did I ever call for thee to pay thy part?
  Fal.
 Yea, and so us'd it that, were it not here apparent that thou
    art heir apparent- But I prithee, sweet wag, shall there be
    gallows standing in England when thou art king? and resolution
    thus fubb'd as it is with the rusty curb of old father antic the
    law? Do not thou, when thou art king, hang a thief.

  Prince.

  Fal.
 Yea, or the drone of a Lincolnshire bagpipe.
 O, thou hast damnable iteration, and art indeed able to
    corrupt a saint.

  Prince.
 Where shall we take a purse tomorrow, Jack?
  Fal.
 An I do not, call
    me villain and baffle me.
 Hear ye, Yedward: if I tarry at home and go not, I'll hang you
    for going.

  Poins.
 There's neither honesty, manhood, nor good fellowship in thee,
    nor thou cam'st not of the blood royal if thou darest not stand
    for ten shillings.

  Prince.
 Well then, once in my days I'll be a madcap.
 Why, that's well said.
 Well, God give thee the spirit of persuasion and him the ears
    of profiting, that what thou speakest may move and what he hears
    may be believed, that the true prince may (for recreation sake)
    prove a false thief; for the poor abuses of the time want
    countenance.
 Farewell, thou latter spring! farewell, All-hallown summer!
                                                  Exit Falstaff.
 How shall we part with them in setting forth?
  Poins.

  Poins.
 Well, for two of them, I know them to be as true-bred
    cowards as ever turn'd back; and for the third, if he fight
    longer than he sees reason, I'll forswear arms.
 The virtue of
    this jest will lie the incomprehensible lies that this same fat  
    rogue will tell us when we meet at supper: how thirty, at least,
    he fought with; what wards, what blows, what extremities he
    endured; and in the reproof of this lies the jest.

  Poins.
 I know you all, and will awhile uphold
    The unyok'd humour of your idleness.

    Yet herein will I imitate the sun,
    Who doth permit the base contagious clouds
    To smother up his beauty from the world,
    That, when he please again to lie himself,
    Being wanted, he may be more wond'red at
    By breaking through the foul and ugly mists
    Of vapours that did seem to strangle him.

  North.
 Worcester, get thee gone; for I do see
    Danger and disobedience in thine eye.
 When we need
    'Your use and counsel, we shall send for you.

                                                 Exit Worcester.

  Hot.

    Three times they breath'd, and three times did they drink,
    Upon agreement, of swift Severn's flood;
    Who then, affrighted with their bloody looks,
    Ran fearfully among the trembling reeds
    And hid his crisp head in the hollow bank,
    Bloodstained with these valiant cohabitants.
 My Lord Northumberland,
    We license your departure with your son.
-
    Send us your prisoners, or you will hear of it.
 An if the devil come and roar for them,
    I will not send them.
 I cannot blame him.

    By God, he shall not have a Scot of them!
    No, if a Scot would save his soul, he shall not.

    I'll keep them, by this hand!
  Wor.

    And lend no ear unto my purposes.
'
    Nay;  
    I'll have a starling shall be taught to speak
    Nothing but 'Mortimer,' and give it him
    To keep his anger still in motion.
 Farewell, kinsman.
 At Berkeley Castle.
 You say true.

    We will stay your leisure.

    Deliver them up without their ransom straight,
    And make the Douglas' son your only mean
    For powers In Scotland; which, for divers reasons  
    Which I shall send you written, be assur'd
    Will easily be granted.

    I speak not this in estimation,
    As what I think might be, but what I know
    Is ruminated, plotted, and set down,
    And only stays but to behold the face
    Of that occasion that shall bring it on.

  North.
 Farewell, good brother.
 Uncle, adieu.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
COMMERCIALLY.

Rochester.
- What, ostler!
  Ost.
 [within] Anon, anon.

  1.
 Poor jade is wrung in the withers out of all cess.
 I am stung like a tench.
 Like a tench I By the mass, there is ne'er a king christen  
    could be better bit than I have been since the first cock.
 I have a gammon of bacon and two razes of ginger, to be
    delivered as far as Charing Cross.
 Car.
 I prithee lend me this lantern to see my gelding in the
    stable.
 Nay, by God, soft! I know a trick worth two of that,
    i' faith.

  2.
 Car.
 They will
    along with company, for they have great charge.
 There's a franklin in the Wild of Kent hath
    brought three hundred marks with him in gold.
 They are
    up already and call for eggs and butter.
 They will away
    presently.
 No, I'll none of it.
 Tut! there are other
    Troyans that thou dream'st not of, the which for sport sake are
    content to do the profession some grace; that would (if matters
    should be look'd into) for their own credit sake make all whole.
 Thou shalt have a share in our purchase, as
    I and a true man.
 Farewell, you muddy knave.





Scene II.
 Stand close.
]
  Fal.
 I am accurs'd to rob in that thief's company.

  Fal.
 Thou liest; thou art not colted, thou art uncolted.
 Out, ye rogue! Shall I be your ostler?
  Fal.
 Stand!
  Fal.

  Fal.
 [aside to Poins] Ned, where are our disguises?
  Poins.

                                      [Exeunt Prince and Poins.
 Every man to
    his business.
 Stand!
  Traveller.
 Jesus bless us!
  Fal.
 The thieves have bound the true men.

    The thieves are scattered, and possess'd with fear
    So strongly that they dare not meet each other.


Enter Hotspur solus, reading a letter.


  Hot.
 What a lack-brain is this! By the Lord, our plot is a good
    plot as ever was laid; our friends true and constant: a good
    plot, good friends, and full of expectation; an excellent plot,
    very good friends.
 I will set
    forward to-night.
 Hath Butler brought those horses from the sheriff?
  Serv.
 One horse, my lord, he brought even now.

  Hot.
 In faith,
    I'll know your business, Harry; that I will!
    I fear my brother Mortimer doth stir
    About his title and hath sent for you
    To line his enterprise; but if you go-
  Hot.

  Hot.
 This is no world
    To play with mammets and to tilt with lips.
 Kate:
    I must not have you henceforth question me
    Whither I go, nor reason whereabout.

Eastcheap.
 Where hast been, Hal?
    Prince,.
 To conclude, I am so good a proficient in one quarter of an
    hour that I can drink with any tinker in his own language during
    my life.
 Thou art perfect.
]

                    Enter [Francis, a] Drawer.
 Anon, anon, sir.
 How long hast thou to serve, Francis?  
  Fran.
 Let me see.
 About Michaelmas next I shall be-
  Poins.
 Pray stay a little, my lord.
  
  Poins.
 But
    Francis-
  Fran.

  Fran.
 Away, you rogue! Dost thou not hear them call?
              Here they both call him.
  

  Vint.
 What, stand'st thou still, and hear'st such a calling? Look
    to the guests within.

                                                  [Exit Vintner.


                          Enter Poins.


  Prince.


           Enter Falstaff, [Gadshill, Bardolph, and Peto;
                   Francis follows with wine].
 A plague of all cowards, I say, and a vengeance too! Marry and
    amen! Give me a cup of sack, boy.

    There lives not three good men unhang'd in England; and one of
    them is fat, and grows old.
 I call thee coward? I'll see thee damn'd ere I call thee
    coward, but I would give a thousand pound I could run as fast as
    thou canst.
 Give me
    a cup of sack.

  Fal.
 What's the matter?
  Fal.

  Prince.
 We four set upon some dozen-
  Fal.

  Gads.
 No, no, they were not bound.
 Pray God you have not murd'red some of them.

  Poins.
 These four came all afront and mainly thrust at me.
 Seven? Why, there were but four even now.

  Fal.
 In buckram?
  Poins.
 Down fell their hose.
 Why, thou clay-brain'd guts, thou
    knotty-pated fool, thou whoreson obscene greasy tallow-catch-
  Fal.
 What sayest thou to this?
  Poins.

    Give you a reason on compulsion? If reasons were as plentiful as
    blackberries, I would give no man a reason upon compulsion, I.

  Poins.
 We two saw you four set on four, and bound them and were
    masters of their wealth.
 Mark now how a plain tale shall put you  
    down.
 What trick hast thou now?
  Fal.
 Hostess, clap to
    the doors.
 Watch to-night, pray to-morrow.
 Content- and the argument shall be thy running away.
 What manner of man is he?
  Host.
 What doth gravity out of his bed at midnight? Shall I give him
    his answer?
  Prince.
 By'r Lady, you fought fair; so did you, Peto; so
    did you, Bardolph.
 Why, he hack'd it with his dagger, and said he would swear
    truth out of England but he would make you believe it was done in
    fight, and persuaded us to do the like.

  Bard.
 Yea, and to tickle our noses with speargrass to make them
    bleed, and then to beslubber our garments with it and swear it
    was the blood of true men.
 Thou hadst fire and sword on thy side, and yet thou
    ran'st away.
 Hot livers and cold purses.
 My own knee? When I was about thy years, Hal, I was not an
    eagle's talent in the waist; I could have crept into any
    alderman's thumb-ring.
 Owen, Owen- the same; and his son-in-law Mortimer, and old
    Northumberland, and that sprightly Scot of Scots, Douglas, that  
    runs a-horseback up a hill perpendicular-
  Prince.

  Prince.
 A-horseback, ye cuckoo! but afoot he will not budge a foot.
 I grant ye, upon instinct.
 Well, he is there too, and one
    Mordake, and a thousand bluecaps more.

  Fal.
 Well, thou wilt be horribly chid to-morrow when thou comest to
    thy father.
 This chair shall be my state, this dagger my
    sceptre, and this cushion my, crown.
 Thy state is taken for a join'd-stool, thy golden sceptre
    for a leaden dagger, and thy precious rich crown for a pitiful
    bald crown.

  Fal.
 And here is my speech.
 Peace, good tickle-brain.
 For though the camomile, the more it is trodden
    on, the faster it grows, yet youth, the more it is wasted, the
    sooner it wears.

  Prince.
 A goodly portly man, i' faith, and a corpulent; of a cheerful
    look, a pleasing eye, and a most noble carriage; and, as I think,
    his age some fifty, or, by'r Lady, inclining to threescore; and
    now I remember me, his name is Falstaff.
 If that man should be
    lewdly, given, he deceiveth me; for, Harry, I see virtue in his
    looks.
 Dost thou speak like a king? Do thou stand for me, and I'll
    play my father.

  Fal.

  Fal.

  Prince.
 That villanous abominable misleader of youth, Falstaff,
    that old white-bearded Satan.
 I know thou dost.
 If sack and sugar be a fault,
    God help the wicked! If to be old and merry be a sin, then many
    an old host that I know is damn'd.

    Banish Peto, banish Bardolph, banish Poins; but for sweet Jack
    Falstaff, kind Jack Falstaff, true Jack Falstaff, valiant Jack
    Falstaff, and therefore more valiant being, as he is, old Jack
    Falstaff, banish not him thy Harry's company, banish not him thy
    Harry's company.
 Heigh, heigh, the devil rides upon a fiddlestick!
    What's the matter?
  Host.
 The sheriff and all the watch are at the door.
 Dost thou hear, Hal? Never call a true piece of gold a
    counterfeit.
 And thou a natural coward without instinct.
 The rest walk, up above.

  Prince.
 As fat as butter.

  Sher.
 I will, my lord.
 There are two gentlemen
    Have in this robbery lost three hundred marks.
 I think it is good morrow, is it not?
  Sher.
 Falstaff! Fast asleep behind the arras, and snorting like a
    horse.

  Prince.
 Nothing but papers, my lord.
 .
 .
 .
 .

                 Item, Sauce.
 .
 .
 .
      iiii d.
 .
 .

                 Item, Anchovies and sack after supper.
 and thy place
    shall be honourable.

COMMERCIALLY.
