  BASTARD.

  KING JOHN.
 Spoke like a sprightful noble gentleman.
 My mother dead!

                   Re-enter HUBERT

  HUBERT.

  KING JOHN.

    I saw a smith stand with his hammer, thus,
    The whilst his iron did on the anvil cool,
    With open mouth swallowing a tailor's news;  
    Who, with his shears and measure in his hand,
    Standing on slippers, which his nimble haste
    Had falsely thrust upon contrary feet,
    Told of a many thousand warlike French
    That were embattailed and rank'd in Kent.
 I had a mighty cause
    To wish him dead, but thou hadst none to kill him.
  
  KING JOHN.

  HUBERT.
 My lord-
  KING JOHN.

    But thou didst understand me by my signs,
    And didst in signs again parley with sin;
    Yea, without stop, didst let thy heart consent,
    And consequently thy rude hand to act
    The deed which both our tongues held vile to name.
 This hand of mine
    Is yet a maiden and an innocent hand,
    Not painted with the crimson spots of blood.

    Within this bosom never ent'red yet
    The dreadful motion of a murderous thought  
    And you have slander'd nature in my form,
    Which, howsoever rude exteriorly,
    Is yet the cover of a fairer mind
    Than to be butcher of an innocent child.

    I conjure thee but slowly; run more fast.


England.

    I am afraid; and yet I'll venture it.

    If I get down and do not break my limbs,
    I'll find a thousand shifts to get away.

    As good to die and go, as die and stay.
 Who brought that letter from the Cardinal?
  SALISBURY.


                 Enter the BASTARD

  BASTARD.
 Once more to-day well met, distemper'd lords!
    The King by me requests your presence straight.

    We will not line his thin bestained cloak
    With our pure honours, nor attend the foot
    That leaves the print of blood where'er it walks.
 Whate'er you think, good words, I think, were best.
  
  BASTARD.

  SALISBURY.
 Murder, as hating what himself hath done,
    Doth lay it open to urge on revenge.

  BASTARD.

  SALISBURY.

  PEMBROKE.
 O, he is bold, and blushes not at death!
    Avaunt, thou hateful villain, get thee gone!
  HUBERT.

  SALISBURY.

    Yet I am none.
 Whose tongue soe'er speaks false,
    Not truly speaks; who speaks not truly, lies.
 Cut him to pieces.

  BASTARD.
 Keep the peace, I say.

  BASTARD.
 What wilt thou do, renowned Faulconbridge?
    Second a villain and a murderer?
  HUBERT.
 Who kill'd this prince?
  HUBERT.
 'Tis not an hour since I left him well.
 Here's a good world! Knew you of this fair work?
    Beyond the infinite and boundless reach
    Of mercy, if thou didst this deed of death,
    Art thou damn'd, Hubert.
 Ha! I'll tell thee what:  
    Thou'rt damn'd as black-nay, nothing is so black-
    Thou art more deep damn'd than Prince Lucifer;
    There is not yet so ugly a fiend of hell
    As thou shalt be, if thou didst kill this child.

  HUBERT.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
 SCENE 1.

    Then pause not; for the present time's so sick
    That present med'cine must be minist'red  
    Or overthrow incurable ensues.
 It was my breath that blew this tempest up,
    Upon your stubborn usage of the Pope;
    But since you are a gentle convertite,
    My tongue shall hush again this storm of war
    And make fair weather in your blust'ring land.
                 Exit
  KING JOHN.
 Is this Ascension-day? Did not the prophet
    Say that before Ascension-day at noon
    My crown I should give off? Even so I have.
 All Kent hath yielded; nothing there holds out
    But Dover Castle.
  
    Your nobles will not hear you, but are gone
    To offer service to your enemy;
    And wild amazement hurries up and down
    The little number of your doubtful friends.
 They found him dead, and cast into the streets,
    An empty casket, where the jewel of life
    By some damn'd hand was robbed and ta'en away.

  KING JOHN.

    But wherefore do you droop? Why look you sad?
    Be great in act, as you have been in thought;
    Let not the world see fear and sad distrust
    Govern the motion of a kingly eye.
 Have thou the ordering of this present time.

    My heart hath melted at a lady's tears,
    Being an ordinary inundation;
    But this effusion of such manly drops,
    This show'r, blown up by tempest of the soul,
    Startles mine eyes and makes me more amaz'd
    Than had I seen the vaulty top of heaven
    Figur'd quite o'er with burning meteors.

    Come, come; for thou shalt thrust thy hand as deep
    Into the purse of rich prosperity
    As Lewis himself.
 Hail, noble prince of France!
    The next is this: King John hath reconcil'd
    Himself to Rome; his spirit is come in,
    That so stood out against the holy Church,  
    The great metropolis and see of Rome.
 Your Grace shall pardon me, I will not back:
    I am too high-born to be propertied,
    To be a secondary at control,
    Or useful serving-man and instrument
    To any sovereign state throughout the world.

    To cudgel you and make you take the hatch,
    To dive like buckets in concealed wells,
    To crouch in litter of your stable planks,
    To lie like pawns lock'd up in chests and trunks,
    To hug with swine, to seek sweet safety out
    In vaults and prisons, and to thrill and shake
    Even at the crying of your nation's crow,
    Thinking this voice an armed Englishman-
    Shall that victorious hand be feebled here
    That in your chambers gave you chastisement?  
    No.

  LEWIS.
 Fare thee well;
    We hold our time too precious to be spent
    With such a brabbler.

  BASTARD.
  
  BASTARD.
 Indeed, your drums, being beaten, will cry out;
    And so shall you, being beaten.
 And thou shalt find it, Dauphin, do not doubt.

    Exeunt




SCENE 3.
 The field of battle

Alarums.

  HUBERT.
 Be of good comfort; for the great supply
    That was expected by the Dauphin here
    Are wreck'd three nights ago on Goodwin Sands;
    This news was brought to Richard but even now.


England.

  PEMBROKE.
 They say King John, sore sick, hath left the field.

  SALISBURY.

    Commend me to one Hubert, with your King;
    The love of him-and this respect besides,
    For that my grandsire was an Englishman-
    Awakes my conscience to confess all this.

    My arm shall give thee help to bear thee hence;
    For I do see the cruel pangs of death
    Right in thine eye.
 O, bravely came we off,
    When with a volley of our needless shot,
    After such bloody toil, we bid good night;
    And wound our tott'ring colours clearly up,
    Last in the field and almost lords of it!

                 Enter a MESSENGER

  MESSENGER.
 Here; what news?
  MESSENGER.
 keep good quarter and good care to-night;
    The day shall not be up so soon as I
    To try the fair adventure of to-morrow.
 A friend.
 Whither dost thou go?
  HUBERT.

  HUBERT.
 Thou hast a perfect thought.
 O, my sweet sir, news fitting to the night,
    Black, fearful, comfortless, and horrible.
 How did he take it; who did taste to him?
  HUBERT.


The orchard at Swinstead Abbey

Enter PRINCE HENRY, SALISBURY, and BIGOT

  PRINCE HENRY.

    Which some suppose the soul's frail dwelling-house,
    Doth by the idle comments that it makes
    Foretell the ending of mortality.
  
  PRINCE HENRY.

    Death, having prey'd upon the outward parts,
    Leaves them invisible, and his siege is now
    Against the mind, the which he pricks and wounds
    With many legions of strange fantasies,
    Which, in their throng and press to that last hold,
    Confound themselves.

    I am a scribbled form drawn with a pen
    Upon a parchment, and against this fire
    Do I shrink up.

  PRINCE HENRY.

    Within me is a hell; and there the poison  
    Is as a fiend confin'd to tyrannize
    On unreprievable condemned blood.

  BASTARD.

    What surety of the world, what hope, what stay,
    When this was now a king, and now is clay?
  BASTARD.
 I have a kind soul that would give you thanks,
    And knows not how to do it but with tears.

    This England never did, nor never shall,
    Lie at the proud foot of a conqueror,
    But when it first did help to wound itself.
>>






1599


THE TRAGEDY OF JULIUS CAESAR

by William Shakespeare



Dramatis Personae

  JULIUS CAESAR, Roman statesman and general
  OCTAVIUS, Triumvir after Caesar's death, later Augustus Caesar,
    first emperor of Rome
  MARK ANTONY, general and friend of Caesar, a Triumvir after his death
  LEPIDUS, third member of the Triumvirate
  MARCUS BRUTUS, leader of the conspiracy against Caesar
  CASSIUS, instigator of the conspiracy
  CASCA,          conspirator against Caesar
  TREBONIUS,           "          "     "
  CAIUS LIGARIUS,      "          "     "
  DECIUS BRUTUS,       "          "     "
  METELLUS CIMBER,     "          "     "
  CINNA,               "          "     "
  CALPURNIA, wife of Caesar
  PORTIA, wife of Brutus
  CICERO,     senator
  POPILIUS,      "
  POPILIUS LENA, "
  FLAVIUS, tribune  
  MARULLUS, tribune
  CATO,     supportor of Brutus
  LUCILIUS,     "     "    "
  TITINIUS,     "     "    "
  MESSALA,      "     "    "
  VOLUMNIUS,    "     "    "
  ARTEMIDORUS, a teacher of rhetoric
  CINNA, a poet
  VARRO,     servant to Brutus
  CLITUS,       "    "     "
  CLAUDIO,      "    "     "
  STRATO,       "    "     "
  LUCIUS,       "    "     "
  DARDANIUS,    "    "     "
  PINDARUS, servant to Cassius
  The Ghost of Caesar
  A Soothsayer
  A Poet
  Senators, Citizens, Soldiers, Commoners, Messengers, and Servants

ACT I.


Enter Flavius, Marullus, and certain Commoners.


  FLAVIUS.
 Hence, home, you idle creatures, get you home.

  FLAVIUS.
 Truly, Sir, all that I live by is with the awl; I
    meddle with no tradesman's matters, nor women's matters, but with
    awl.

  FLAVIUS.
 Truly, sir, to wear out their shoes to get myself
    into more work.

    See whether their basest metal be not moved;
    They vanish tongue-tied in their guiltiness.

    Go you down that way towards the Capitol;
    This way will I.

  FLAVIUS.

  CAESAR.
 Stand you directly in Antonio's way,
    When he doth run his course.
 Forget not in your speed, Antonio,
    To touch Calpurnia, for our elders say
    The barren, touched in this holy chase,
    Shake off their sterile curse.

  CASSIUS.

  CAESAR.

  BRUTUS.

  CASSIUS.

  BRUTUS.

    Tell me, good Brutus, can you see your face?
  BRUTUS.
 No, Cassius, for the eye sees not itself
    But by reflection, by some other things.

  CASSIUS.

  BRUTUS.
 What means this shouting? I do fear the people
    Choose Caesar for their king.
 I would not, Cassius, yet I love him well.

    For let the gods so speed me as I love
    The name of honor more than I fear death.
 Ye gods! It doth amaze me
    A man of such a feeble temper should
    So get the start of the majestic world
    And bear the palm alone.

  BRUTUS.
 I will do so.

  CASSIUS.
 Antonio!
  ANTONY.
 Let me have men about me that are fat,
    Sleek-headed men, and such as sleep o' nights:
    Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look;
    He thinks too much; such men are dangerous.

  ANTONY.
 Fear him not, Caesar; he's not dangerous;
    He is a noble Roman and well given.
 Exeunt Caesar and all his Train but Casca.

  CASCA.
 Why, there was a crown offered him, and being offered him,
     he put it by with the back of his hand, thus, and then the
     people fell ashouting.
  
  BRUTUS.
 Why, for that too.
 I can as well be hang'd as tell the manner of it.
 He fell down in the marketplace and foamed at mouth and was
    speechless.
 An had been a man of any
    occupation, if I would not have taken him at a word, I would I  
    might go to hell among the rogues.
 Ay.
 To what effect?
  CASCA.

  CASSIUS.
 Do so, farewell, both.
                            Exit.
 What a blunt fellow is this grown to be!
    He was quick mettle when he went to school.
 Till then, think of the world.
 Good even, Casca.
 Are not you moved, when all the sway of earth
    Shakes like a thing unfirm? O Cicero,
    I have seen tempests when the scolding winds
    Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen
    The ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam
    To be exalted with the threatening clouds,
    But never till tonight, never till now,
    Did I go through a tempest dropping fire.
 When these prodigies
    Do so conjointly meet, let not men say
    "These are their reasons; they are natural":
    For I believe they are portentous things
    Unto the climate that they point upon.
 Indeed, it is a strange-disposed time.

    But men may construe things after their fashion,
    Clean from the purpose of the things themselves.
 Good then, Casca.
 Farewell, Cicero.

    For my part, I have walk'd about the streets,
    Submitting me unto the perilous night,
    And thus unbraced, Casca, as you see,
    Have bared my bosom to the thunderstone;
    And when the cross blue lightning seem'd to open  
    The breast of heaven, I did present myself
    Even in the aim and very flash of it.

    But if you would consider the true cause
    Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts,
    Why birds and beasts from quality and kind,
    Why old men, fools, and children calculate,
    Why all these things change from their ordinance,
    Their natures, and preformed faculties
    To monstrous quality, why, you shall find
    That heaven hath infused them with these spirits
    To make them instruments of fear and warning  
    Unto some monstrous state.
 Let it be who it is, for Romans now
    Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors.

  CASCA.
  
    Therein, ye gods, you make the weak most strong;
    Therein, ye gods, you tyrants do defeat.
 So can I.
 But I am arm'd,
    And dangers are to me indifferent.

  CASCA.

  CASSIUS.

    Now know you, Casca, I have moved already
    Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans
    To undergo with me an enterprise
    Of honorable-dangerous consequence;
    And I do know by this, they stay for me
    In Pompey's Porch.

  CASSIUS.
 Be you content.

    Is Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?
  CINNA.
 Him and his worth and our great need of him
    You have right well conceited.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
COMMERCIALLY.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
 What, Lucius, ho!
    I cannot, by the progress of the stars,
    Give guess how near to day.
 Lucius, I say!
    I would it were my fault to sleep so soundly.


  LUCIUS.
 Call'd you, my lord?
  BRUTUS.
                                 Exit.
 It must be by his death, and, for my part,
    I know no personal cause to spurn at him,
    But for the general.
 Crown him that,  
    And then, I grant, we put a sting in him
    That at his will he may do danger with.

    The abuse of greatness is when it disjoins
    Remorse from power, and, to speak truth of Caesar,
    I have not known when his affections sway'd
    More than his reason.
 So Caesar may;
    Then, lest he may, prevent.
 And, since the quarrel
    Will bear no color for the thing he is,
    Fashion it thus, that what he is, augmented,
    Would run to these and these extremities;
    And therefore think him as a serpent's egg
    Which hatch'd would as his kind grow mischievous,
    And kill him in the shell.
 Get you to bed again, it is not day.

    Is not tomorrow, boy, the ides of March?
  LUCIUS.

                                     Opens the letter and reads.
 Sir, March is wasted fifteen days.
 'Tis good.

                                                    Exit Lucius.

    Between the acting of a dreadful thing
    And the first motion, all the interim is  
    Like a phantasma or a hideous dream;
    The genius and the mortal instruments
    Are then in council, and the state of man,
    Like to a little kingdom, suffers then
    The nature of an insurrection.


                         Re-enter Lucius.
 Sir, 'tis your brother Cassius at the door,
    Who doth desire to see you.
 Let 'em enter.

    They are the faction.
 Yes, every man of them, and no man here
    But honors you, and every one doth wish
    You had but that opinion of yourself
    Which every noble Roman bears of you.
 He is welcome hither.

  BRUTUS.
 They are all welcome.
 Doth not the day break here?
  CASCA.

    Here, as I point my sword, the sun arises,
    Which is a great way growing on the south,
    Weighing the youthful season of the year.

    Some two months hence up higher toward the north
    He first presents his fire, and the high east
    Stands as the Capitol, directly here.
 But if these,
    As I am sure they do, bear fire enough
    To kindle cowards and to steel with valor
    The melting spirits of women, then, countrymen,
    What need we any spur but our own cause
    To prick us to redress? What other bond
    Than secret Romans that have spoke the word
    And will not palter? And what other oath
    Than honesty to honesty engaged
    That this shall be or we will fall for it?
    Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous,
    Old feeble carrions and such suffering souls
    That welcome wrongs; unto bad causes swear
    Such creatures as men doubt; but do not stain
    The even virtue of our enterprise,  
    Nor the insuppressive mettle of our spirits,
    To think that or our cause or our performance
    Did need an oath; when every drop of blood
    That every Roman bears, and nobly bears,
    Is guilty of a several bastardy
    If he do break the smallest particle
    Of any promise that hath pass'd from him.

  CASSIUS.
 Let us not leave him out.

  METELLUS.

  CASCA.

  BRUTUS.
 This shall make
    Our purpose necessary and not envious,
    Which so appearing to the common eyes,
    We shall be call'd purgers, not murderers.

    And that were much he should, for he is given
    To sports, to wildness, and much company.
 Peace, count the clock.
 The clock hath stricken three.
 But it is doubtful yet
    Whether Caesar will come forth today or no,
    For he is superstitious grown of late,
    Quite from the main opinion he held once
    Of fantasy, of dreams, and ceremonies.
 Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him.
 Be that the uttermost, and fail not then.

    I wonder none of you have thought of him.

  BRUTUS.

    He loves me well, and I have given him reasons;
    Send him but hither, and I'll fashion him.

    Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber;
    Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies,
    Which busy care draws in the brains of men;
    Therefore thou sleep'st so sound.
  
    I urged you further; then you scratch'd your head,
    And too impatiently stamp'd with your foot.

  BRUTUS.

  BRUTUS.
 I should not need, if you were gentle Brutus.

    I have made strong proof of my constancy,
    Giving myself a voluntary wound
    Here in the thigh.
 O ye gods,
    Render me worthy of this noble wife! Knocking within.

    Leave me with haste.
 Now bid me run,
    And I will strive with things impossible,
    Yea, get the better of them.

  LIGARIUS.

  BRUTUS.
 Follow me then.


  CAESAR.
 My lord?
  CAESAR.
 Go bid the priests do present sacrifice,
    And bring me their opinions of success.
                                Exit.
 Caesar shall forth: the things that threaten'd me
    Ne'er look'd but on my back; when they shall see  
    The face of Caesar, they are vanished.
 There is one within,
    Besides the things that we have heard and seen,
    Recounts most horrid sights seen by the watch.
 Cowards die many times before their deaths;
    The valiant never taste of death but once.


    What say the augurers?
  SERVANT.

    Plucking the entrails of an offering forth,
    They could not find a heart within the beast.
 The gods do this in shame of cowardice.
 Danger knows full well
    That Caesar is more dangerous than he.
 Alas, my lord,
    Your wisdom is consumed in confidence.

  DECIUS.
 Caesar, all hail! Good morrow, worthy Caesar!
    I come to fetch you to the Senate House.
 And you are come in very happy time
    To bear my greeting to the senators
    And tell them that I will not come today.
 Say he is sick.
 Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause,
    Lest I be laugh'd at when I tell them so.
 And this way have you well expounded it.

  DECIUS.
"
    If Caesar hide himself, shall they not whisper
    "Lo, Caesar is afraid"?  
    Pardon me, Caesar, for my dear dear love
    To your proceeding bids me tell you this,
    And reason to my love is liable.
 How foolish do your fears seem now, Calpurnia!
    I am ashamed I did yield to them.


         Enter Publius, Brutus, Ligarius, Metellus, Casca,
                     Trebonius, and Cinna.
 Caesar, 'tis strucken eight.
  

                           Enter Antony.

  TREBONIUS.
 [Aside.


  ARTEMIDORUS.
           Exit.





SCENE IV.


Enter Portia and Lucius.


                     Enter the Soothsayer.
 Madam, not yet.
 Thou hast some suit to Caesar, hast thou not?
  SOOTHSAYER.
 Brutus hath a suit
    That Caesar will not grant.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
>>



ACT III.

  ARTEMIDORUS.
 O Caesar, read mine first, for mine's a suit
    That touches Caesar nearer.
 Read it, great Caesar.

  ARTEMIDORUS.
 Sirrah, give place.

  CASSIUS.
 Casca,
    Be sudden, for we fear prevention.

  CASSIUS.

  DECIUS.
                                     Kneels.

    Know, Caesar doth not wrong, nor without cause
    Will he be satisfied.

  METELLUS.

  CAESAR.
 What, Brutus?
  CASSIUS.
 I could be well moved, if I were as you;
    If I could pray to move, prayers would move me;
    But I am constant as the northern star,
    Of whose true-fix'd and resting quality
    There is no fellow in the firmament.

    So in the world, 'tis furnish'd well with men,
    And men are flesh and blood, and apprehensive;
    Yet in the number I do know but one
    That unassailable holds on his rank,
    Unshaked of motion; and that I am he,
    Let me a little show it, even in this;
    That I was constant Cimber should be banish'd,
    And constant do remain to keep him so.
 O Caesar-
  CAESAR.
 Speak, hands, for me!
                        Casca first, then the other Conspirators
                                  and Marcus Brutus stab Caesar.
 People and senators, be not affrighted,
    Fly not, stand still; ambition's debt is paid.

  CASCA.
 Go to the pulpit, Brutus.

  DECIUS.
 Publius, good cheer,
    There is no harm intended to your person,
    Nor to no Roman else.
 So tell them, Publius.
 Fates, we will know your pleasures.

    That we shall die, we know; 'tis but the time
    And drawing days out that men stand upon.
 Why, he that cuts off twenty years of life
    Cuts off so many years of fearing death.

  BRUTUS.

  DECIUS.
 What, shall we forth?
  CASSIUS.
 Ay, every man away.

    Brutus shall lead, and we will grace his heels
    With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome.

  BRUTUS.
 But here comes Antony.

  BRUTUS.
 For your part,
    To you our swords have leaden points, Mark Antony;
    Our arms in strength of malice, and our hearts
    Of brothers' temper, do receive you in
    With all kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.

    Gentlemen all- alas, what shall I say?
    My credit now stands on such slippery ground,
    That one of two bad ways you must conceit me,
    Either a coward or a flatterer.
 Or else were this a savage spectacle.

  ANTONY.

                                          Exeunt all but Antony.
  
    Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood!
    Over thy wounds now do I prophesy
    (Which like dumb mouths do ope their ruby lips
    To beg the voice and utterance of my tongue)
    A curse shall light upon the limbs of men;
    Domestic fury and fierce civil strife
    Shall cumber all the parts of Italy;
    Blood and destruction shall be so in use,
    And dreadful objects so familiar,
    That mothers shall but smile when they behold
    Their infants quarter'd with the hands of war;
    All pity choked with custom of fell deeds,
    And Caesar's spirit ranging for revenge,
    With Ate by his side come hot from hell,
    Shall in these confines with a monarch's voice
    Cry "Havoc!" and let slip the dogs of war,
    That this foul deed shall smell above the earth
    With carrion men, groaning for burial.

    Passion, I see, is catching, for mine eyes,
    Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine,
    Began to water.


  CITIZENS.
 Then follow me and give me audience, friends.
 I will hear Brutus speak.
 The noble Brutus is ascended.
 Believe me for mine honor, and have  
    respect to mine honor, that you may believe.
 Had you rather Caesar were living and die all slaves, than
    that Caesar were dead to live all freemen? As Caesar loved me, I
    weep for him; as he was fortunate, I rejoice at it; as he was
    valiant, I honor him; but as he was ambitious, I slew him.
 None, Brutus, none.
 Peace! Silence! Brutus speaks.
 Peace, ho!
  BRUTUS.
 Good countrymen, let me depart alone,
    And, for my sake, stay here with Antony.

  THIRD CITIZEN.

  ANTONY.

                                           Goes into the pulpit.

  FOURTH CITIZEN.
 What does he say of Brutus?
  THIRD CITIZEN.
 He says, for Brutus' sake,
    He finds himself beholding to us all.
 This Caesar was a tyrant.

  ANTONY.
 Peace, ho! Let us hear him.
 Was this ambition?
    Yet Brutus says he was ambitious,
    And sure he is an honorable man.

    I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke,
    But here I am to speak what I do know.

    You all did love him once, not without cause;
    What cause withholds you then to mourn for him?
    O judgement, thou art fled to brutish beasts,
    And men have lost their reason.
 Methinks there is much reason in his sayings.
 If thou consider rightly of the matter,  
    Caesar has had great wrong.
 Now mark him, he begins again to speak.

    O masters! If I were disposed to stir
    Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage,
    I should do Brutus wrong and Cassius wrong,
    Who, you all know, are honorable men.

  FOURTH CITIZEN.
 Read the will; we'll hear it, Antony.

    You shall read us the will, Caesar's will.
 Honorable men!
  ALL.
 They were villains, murtherers.

    Shall I descend? And will you give me leave?
  ALL.

  FIRST CITIZEN.
  
  ALL.

    You all do know this mantle.
 Then burst his mighty heart,
    And, in his mantle muffling up his face,  
    Even at the base of Pompey's statue,
    Which all the while ran blood, great Caesar fell.

  FIRST CITIZEN.
 O noble Caesar!
  THIRD CITIZEN.
 O woeful day!
  FOURTH CITIZEN.
 We will be revenged.
 Stay, countrymen.
 We'll hear him, we'll follow him, we'll die with
    him.

    I come not, friends, to steal away your hearts.
 I only speak right on;
    I tell you that which you yourselves do know;
    Show you sweet Caesar's wounds, poor dumb mouths,
    And bid them speak for me.
 Away, then! Come, seek the conspirators.

    Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves?
    Alas, you know not; I must tell you then.

  ALL.
 Peace, ho!  
  ANTONY.
 Pluck down benches.
 He and Lepidus are at Caesar's house.

    He comes upon a wish.
 Be like they had some notice of the people,
    How I had moved them.


Enter Cinna the poet.
 I dreamt tonight that I did feast with Caesar,
    And things unluckily charge my fantasy.


                        Enter Citizens.


  FIRST CITIZEN.

  FOURTH CITIZEN.
 That's as much as to say they are fools that marry.
 For your dwelling, briefly.
 I am Cinna the poet, I am Cinna the poet.
 It is no matter, his name's Cinna.
 Your brother too must die; consent you, Lepidus?
  LEPIDUS.

  ANTONY.

  ANTONY.
 Brutus and Cassius
    Are levying powers; we must straight make head;
    Therefore let our alliance be combined,
    Our best friends made, our means stretch'd;
    And let us presently go sit in council,
    How covert matters may be best disclosed,
    And open perils surest answered.

  BRUTUS.
 A word, Lucilius,
    How he received you.

    There are no tricks in plain and simple faith;
    But hollow men, like horses hot at hand,
    Make gallant show and promise of their mettle;
    But when they should endure the bloody spur,
    They fall their crests and like deceitful jades
    Sink in the trial.
 Hark, he is arrived.


                  Enter Cassius and his Powers.
 Stand!
  SECOND SOLDIER.
 Judge me, you gods! Wrong I mine enemies?
    And, if not so, how should I wrong a brother?
  CASSIUS.
 Pindarus,
    Bid our commanders lead their charges off  
    A little from this ground.

  BRUTUS.


  CASSIUS.

  BRUTUS.
 The name of Cassius honors this corruption,
    And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.
 Go to, you are not, Cassius.
  
  CASSIUS.

  BRUTUS.
 Away, slight man!
  CASSIUS.
 Is't possible?
  BRUTUS.

  CASSIUS.

  CASSIUS.

    I said, an elder soldier, not a better.

  CASSIUS.
 I durst not?
  BRUTUS.
 For your life you durst not.
 You have done that you should be sorry for.

  CASSIUS.
  
  BRUTUS.
 Come, Antony, and young Octavius, come,
    Revenge yourselves alone on Cassius,
    For Cassius is aweary of the world:
    Hated by one he loves; braved by his brother;
    Check'd like a bondman; all his faults observed,
    Set in a notebook, learn'd and conn'd by rote,
    To cast into my teeth.

    Strike, as thou didst at Caesar, for I know,
    When thou didst hate him worst, thou lovedst him better
    Than ever thou lovedst Cassius.

    O Cassius, you are yoked with a lamb,
    That carries anger as the flint bears fire,
    Who, much enforced, shows a hasty spark
    And straight is cold again.
 Hath Cassius lived
    To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus,
    When grief and blood ill-temper'd vexeth him?
  BRUTUS.
 O Brutus!
  BRUTUS.
 [Within.
 [Within.


      Enter Poet, followed by Lucilius, Titinius, and Lucius.

  CASSIUS.
 I'll know his humor when he knows his time.
 Away, away, be gone!                       Exit Poet.

  CASSIUS.

  BRUTUS.
 Ha? Portia?
  BRUTUS.
 How 'scaped killing when I cross'd you so?
    O insupportable and touching loss!
    Upon what sickness?
  BRUTUS.
 O ye immortal gods!

               Re-enter Lucius, with wine and taper.

  Fill, Lucius, till the wine o'erswell the cup;
  I cannot drink too much of Brutus' love.
 Come in, Titinius!                        Exit Lucius.

  CASSIUS.
 No more, I pray you.

  MESSALA.
 Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?
  BRUTUS.
 We must die, Messala.
 This it is:
    'Tis better that the enemy seek us;
    So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers,
    Doing himself offense, whilst we lying still
    Are full of rest, defense, and nimbleness.

  BRUTUS.

    The enemy, marching along by them,
    By them shall make a fuller number up,
    Come on refresh'd, new-added, and encouraged;
    From which advantage shall we cut him off
    If at Philippi we do face him there,
    These people at our back.

    On such a full sea are we now afloat,  
    And we must take the current when it serves,
    Or lose our ventures.

  CASSIUS.

    Early tomorrow will we rise and hence.

    Farewell, good Messala;
    Good night, Titinius; noble, noble Cassius,
    Good night and good repose.
 O my dear brother!
    This was an ill beginning of the night.
 Good night, good brother.
 MESSALA.

                                          Exeunt all but Brutus.


               Re-enter Lucius, with the gown.

    Call Claudio and some other of my men,
    I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.

  LUCIUS.
 Calls my lord?
  BRUTUS.
 I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep;
    It may be I shall raise you by and by
    On business to my brother Cassius.
 So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.

  BRUTUS.

    It may be I shall otherwise bethink me.
 Bear with me, good boy, I am much forgetful.
 Ay, my lord, an't please you.

  LUCIUS.
 I should not urge thy duty past thy might;  
    I know young bloods look for a time of rest.
 I have slept, my lord, already.
 Art thou anything?  
    Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil
    That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare?
    Speak to me what thou art.
 To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.

  BRUTUS.
     Exit Ghost.

    Now I have taken heart thou vanishest.

  BRUTUS.
 My lord, I do not know that I did cry.

  BRUTUS.
 Sleep again, Lucius.
 Go and commend me to my brother Cassius;
    Bid him set on his powers betimes before,
    And we will follow.

  VARRO.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
 Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know
    Wherefore they do it.
 They could be content
    To visit other places, and come down
    With fearful bravery, thinking by this face
    To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage;
    But 'tis not so.
 Octavius, lead your battle softly on,
    Upon the left hand of the even field.

  ANTONY.


      March.
 They stand, and would have parley.

  OCTAVIUS.
 Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?
  ANTONY.
 Not that we love words better, as you do.

  BRUTUS.
 Antony,
    The posture of your blows are yet unknown;
    But for your words, they rob the Hybla bees,
    And leave them honeyless.

  BRUTUS.
  
  OCTAVIUS.

  CASSIUS.
 Come, Antony, away!
    Defiance, traitors, hurl we in your teeth.
 Ho, Lucilius! Hark, a word with you.

  CASSIUS.
 [Stands forth.

    You know that I held Epicurus strong,
    And his opinion.
 Even so, Lucilius.
 Now, most noble Brutus,
    The gods today stand friendly that we may,
    Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age!
    But, since the affairs of men rest still incertain,
    Let's reason with the worst that may befall.
 Come, ho! Away!           Exeunt.

    Ride, ride, Messala.


  CASSIUS.

  TITINIUS.

  CASSIUS.
 This hill is far enough.

  TITINIUS.
 Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hill;
    My sight was ever thick; regard Titinius,
    And tell me what thou notest about the field.
 Come now, keep thine oath;
    Now be a freeman, and with this good sword,
    That ran through Caesar's bowels, search this bosom.

  PINDARUS.
              Exit.
 What, Pindarus! Where art thou, Pindarus?
  MESSALA.
 Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet
    The noble Brutus, thrusting this report
    Into his ears.
 Brutus, come apace,
    And see how I regarded Caius Cassius.
 Re-enter Messala, with Brutus, young Cato,
                         and others.
 Where, where, Messala, doth his body lie?
  MESSALA.

  CATO.





SCENE IV.

Another part of the field.
 Yet, countrymen, O, yet hold up your heads!
  CATO.
 Yield, or thou diest.
] There is so much that thou wilt kill me straight:
    Kill Brutus, and be honor'd in his death.
 Here comes the general.

  ANTONY.
                           Exeunt.
 He is or ta'en or slain.
 Sit thee down, Clitus.
 Peace then, no words.

  BRUTUS.
 O Dardanius!
  DARDANIUS.
 O Clitus!
  CLITUS.

  CLITUS.
 What says my lord?
  BRUTUS.
 Nay I am sure it is, Volumnius.
 Countrymen,
    My heart doth joy that yet in all my life
    I found no man but he was true to me.

    I shall have glory by this losing day,
    More than Octavius and Mark Antony
    By this vile conquest shall attain unto.

    Night hangs upon mine eyes, my bones would rest
    That have but labor'd to attain this hour.

                            Alarum.
 Cry within, "Fly, fly, fly!"
  CLITUS.

  BRUTUS.
 Give me your hand first.
 Enter Octavius, Antony, Messala,
                 Lucilius, and the Army.

  LUCILIUS.

    Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?
  STRATO.
 I held the sword, and he did run on it.

    All the conspirators, save only he,
    Did that they did in envy of great Caesar;
    He only, in a general honest thought
    And common good to all, made one of them.

    His life was gentle, and the elements
    So mix'd in him that Nature might stand up
    And say to all the world, "This was a man!"
  OCTAVIUS.

      Earl of Kent.

      Old Man, tenant to Gloucester.


      Goneril, daughter to Lear.

      Regan, daughter to Lear.
>>



Scene: - Britain.



ACT I.
 Is not this your son, my lord?
  Glou.

  Kent.
 I cannot conceive you.

  Glou.

  Glou.
 But I have, sir, a son by order of law, some year elder than
     this, who yet is no dearer in my account.
 My Lord of Kent.
 He hath been out nine years, and away he shall again.

     The King is coming.

  Glou.

  Lear.

  Lear.

  Lear.
 Speak again.
 I love your Majesty
     According to my bond; no more nor less.

     Sure I shall never marry like my sisters,
     To love my father all.
 Ay, good my lord.
 So young, and so untender?
  Cor.
 The barbarous Scythian,
     Or he that makes his generation messes
     To gorge his appetite, shall to my bosom
     Be as well neighbour'd, pitied, and reliev'd,
     As thou my sometime daughter.
 Peace, Kent!
     Come not between the dragon and his wrath.
 Royal Lear,
     Whom I have ever honour'd as my king,
     Lov'd as my father, as my master follow'd,
     As my great patron thought on in my prayers-
  Lear.
 What wouldst thou do, old man?
     Think'st thou that duty shall have dread to speak
     When power to flattery bows? To plainness honour's bound
     When majesty falls to folly.

  Lear.

  Lear.

  Lear.
 Away! By Jupiter,
     This shall not be revok'd.
 Fare thee well, King.

     [To Cordelia] The gods to their dear shelter take thee, maid,
     That justly think'st and hast most rightly said!
     [To Regan and Goneril] And your large speeches may your deeds  
        approve,
     That good effects may spring from words of love.
 Enter Gloucester, with France and Burgundy; Attendants.


  Glou.
 I know no answer.
 Will you, with those infirmities she owes,
     Unfriended, new adopted to our hate,
     Dow'r'd with our curse, and stranger'd with our oath,
     Take her, or leave her?
  Bur.

  Lear.
 Sure her offence
     Must be of such unnatural degree
     That monsters it, or your fore-vouch'd affection
     Fall'n into taint; which to believe of her
     Must be a faith that reason without miracle
     Should never plant in me.
 Is it but this- a tardiness in nature
     Which often leaves the history unspoke
     That it intends to do? My Lord of Burgundy,
     What say you to the lady? Love's not love
     When it is mingled with regards that stands
     Aloof from th' entire point.

  Bur.
 Royal Lear,
     Give but that portion which yourself propos'd,
     And here I take Cordelia by the hand,
     Duchess of Burgundy.
 Nothing! I have sworn; I am firm.
 I am sorry then you have so lost a father
     That you must lose a husband.
 Peace be with Burgundy!
     Since that respects of fortune are his love,
     I shall not be his wife.
 Time shall unfold what plighted cunning hides.
 He always lov'd our  
     sister most, and with what poor judgment he hath now cast her
     off appears too grossly.

  Gon.

  Reg.
 Such unconstant starts are we like to have from him as this
     of Kent's banishment.

     Now, gods, stand up for bastards!

                          Enter Gloucester.
 No? What needed then that terrible dispatch of it into your
     pocket? The quality of nothing hath not such need to hide
     itself.

  Edm.
 Let's see, let's see!
  Edm.

  Glou.
 It is his hand, my lord; but I hope his heart is not in the
     contents.

  Glou.
 Never, my lord.
 But I have heard him oft maintain it to be fit
     that, sons at perfect age, and fathers declining, the father
     should be as ward to the son, and the son manage his revenue.
 If your honour judge it meet, I will place you where you shall
     hear us confer of this and by an auricular assurance have your
     satisfaction, and that without any further delay than this very
     evening.
 I would unstate
     myself to be in a due resolution.

  Glou.
 Love cools,
     friendship falls off, brothers divide.
 This villain of mine comes under the
     prediction; there's son against father: the King falls from bias
     of nature; there's father against child.
 An admirable evasion of whore-master man, to lay
     his goatish disposition to the charge of a star! My father
     compounded with my mother under the Dragon's Tail, and my
     nativity was under Ursa Major, so that it follows I am rough and  
     lecherous.
 The night gone by.
 Spake you with him?
  Edg.
 None at all.

  Edm.
 That's my fear.
 I pray you have a continent forbearance till
     the speed of his rage goes slower; and, as I say, retire with me
     to my lodging, from whence I will fitly bring you to hear my
     lord speak.
 Brother, I advise you to the best.
 I am no honest man
     if there be any good meaning toward you.





Scene III.


Enter Goneril and [her] Steward [Oswald].

     His knights grow riotous, and himself upbraids us
     On every trifle.
 Put on what weary negligence you please,
     You and your fellows.

     If he distaste it, let him to our sister,
     Whose mind and mine I know in that are one,
     Not to be overrul'd.
 And let his knights have colder looks among you.


Enter Kent, [disguised].
 Now, banish'd Kent,
     If thou canst serve where thou dost stand condemn'd,
     So may it come, thy master, whom thou lov'st,
     Shall find thee full of labours.


  Lear.
 What art thou?
  Kent.
 You.

  Lear.
 What services canst thou do?
  Kent.

  Lear.
 How old art thou?
  Kent.
 Not so young, sir, to love a woman for singing, nor so old to  
     dote on her for anything.
 Follow me; thou shalt serve me.
 He would not?
  Knight.
 I beseech you pardon me, my lord, if I be mistaken; for
     my duty cannot be silent when I think your Highness wrong'd.

  Lear.
 Thou but rememb'rest me of mine own conception.
 I will look further into't.
 Go you and tell my
     daughter I would speak with her.


     O, you, sir, you! Come you hither, sir.

  Kent.
 I thank thee, fellow.
 Come, sir, arise, away! I'll teach you differences.
]
  Lear.
 There's earnest of thy  
     service.
]

                             Enter Fool.
 Let me hire him too.
 Why, fool?
  Fool.
 Why, my boy?
  Fool.

     There's mine! beg another of thy daughters.

  Lear.
 Do.
 Then 'tis like the breath of an unfeed lawyer- you gave me
     nothing for't.
 [to Kent] Prithee tell him, so much the rent of his land  
     comes to.
 No, lad; teach me.
   That lord that counsell'd thee
            To give away thy land,
          Come place him here by me-
            Do thou for him stand.

          The sweet and bitter fool
            Will presently appear;
          The one in motley here,
            The other found out there.

  Fool.
 And ladies too, they
     will not let me have all the fool to myself; they'll be  
     snatching.
 I have us'd it, nuncle, ever since thou mad'st thy daughters
     thy mother; for when thou gav'st them the rod, and put'st down
     thine own breeches,
  
     [Sings]    Then they for sudden joy did weep,
                  And I for sorrow sung,
                That such a king should play bo-peep
                  And go the fools among.
 An you lie, sirrah, we'll have you whipp'd.
 I had rather be
     any kind o' thing than a fool! And yet I would not be thee,
     nuncle.


                            Enter Goneril.
 Your name, fair gentlewoman?
  Gon.

     Here do you keep a hundred knights and squires;
     Men so disorder'd, so debosh'd, and bold
     That this our court, infected with their manners,
     Shows like a riotous inn.
 Be then desir'd
     By her that else will take the thing she begs  
     A little to disquantity your train,
     And the remainder that shall still depend
     To be such men as may besort your age,
     Which know themselves, and you.

  Gon.
 [to Goneril] Detested kite, thou liest!  
     My train are men of choice and rarest parts,
     That all particulars of duty know
     And in the most exact regard support
     The worships of their name.
]
     And thy dear judgment out! Go, go, my people.
 Never afflict yourself to know the cause;
     But let his disposition have that scope
     That dotage gives it.
 I cannot be so partial, Goneril,
     To the great love I bear you -
  Gon.
- What, Oswald, ho!
     [To the Fool] You, sir, more knave than fool, after your master!
  Fool.
  

          A fox when one has caught her,
          And such a daughter,
          Should sure to the slaughter,
          If my cap would buy a halter.
 Well, you may fear too far.
 How far your eyes may pierce I cannot tell.

     Striving to better, oft we mar what's well.
 Well, well; th' event.


Enter Lear, Kent, and Fool.

  Fool.

  Lear.

  Fool.
 Nor I neither; but I can tell why a snail has a house.
 Why?
  Fool.

  Lear.
 If thou wert my fool, nuncle, I'ld have thee beaten for being
     old before thy time.
 Thou shouldst not have been old till thou hadst been wise.

  Fool.
 Scene I.


Enter [Edmund the] Bastard and Curan, meeting.

  Cur.
 And you, sir.
 You have heard of the news abroad- I mean the
     whisper'd ones, for they are yet but ear-kissing arguments?
  Edm.
 Have you heard of no likely wars toward 'twixt the two Dukes
     of Cornwall and Albany?
  Edm.

  Cur.
-
     Yield! Come before my father.
 Light, ho, here!
     Fly, brother.
 [Stabs his arm.
- Father, father!-
     Stop, stop! No help?

             Enter Gloucester, and Servants with torches.
 What I should deny
     (As this I would; ay, though thou didst produce
     My very character), I'ld turn it all
     To thy suggestion, plot, and damned practice;
     And thou must make a dullard of the world,
     If they not thought the profits of my death
     Were very pregnant and potential spurs
     To make thee seek it.
'
  Glou.


                Enter Cornwall, Regan, and Attendants.


  Corn.
 O madam, my old heart is crack'd, it's crack'd!
  Reg.
 What, did my father's godson seek your life?
     He whom my father nam'd? Your Edgar?
  Glou.
  
     I have this present evening from my sister
     Been well inform'd of them, and with such cautions
     That, if they come to sojourn at my house,
     I'll not be there.
 Ay, my good lord.

     Occasions, noble Gloucester, of some poise,
     Wherein we must have use of your advice.

     Your Graces are right welcome.
 Flourish.

  Osw.
 I' th' mire.
 Prithee, if thou lov'st me, tell me.

  Kent.
 If I had thee in Lipsbury Pinfold, I would make thee care for
     me.
 Fellow, I know thee.
 What a brazen-fac'd varlet art thou, to deny thou knowest me!
     Is it two days ago since I beat thee and tripp'd up thy heels
     before the King? [Draws his sword.
 Draw, you rascal! You come with letters against the King, and
     take Vanity the puppet's part against the royalty of her father.

  Kent.
 Keep peace, upon your lives!
     He dies that strikes again.
 What is your difference? Speak.
 You cowardly
     rascal, nature disclaims in thee; a tailor made thee.
 Ay, a tailor, sir.

  Corn.
 Speak yet, how grew your quarrel?  
  Osw.
 Why art thou angry?
  Kent.

     A plague upon your epileptic visage!  
     Smile you my speeches, as I were a fool?
     Goose, an I had you upon Sarum Plain,
     I'ld drive ye cackling home to Camelot.

  Corn.
 No more perchance does mine, or his, or hers.
 Sir, 'tis my occupation to be plain.
 He that beguil'd you in a plain
     accent was a plain knave, which, for my part, I will not be,
     though I should win your displeasure to entreat me to't.

  Kent.
 Sir, I am too old to learn.
 Fetch forth the stocks! As I have life and honour,
     There shall he sit till noon.
 Till noon? Till night, my lord, and all night too!
  Kent.

  Glou.

  Corn.

Exit.
 I know 'tis from Cordelia,
     Who hath most fortunately been inform'd
     Of my obscured course- and [reads] 'shall find time
     From this enormous state, seeking to give
     Losses their remedies'- All weary and o'erwatch'd,
     Take vantage, heavy eyes, not to behold  
     This shameful lodging.

The open country.


  Edg.
 Whiles I may scape,
     I will preserve myself; and am bethought
     To take the basest and most poorest shape
     That ever penury, in contempt of man,
     Brought near to beast.


Enter Lear, Fool, and Gentleman.

  Kent.
 No, I say.
 I say yea.

  Lear.
 By Jupiter, I swear no!
  Kent.

  Lear.

  Lear.

  Gent.
 We'll set thee to school to an ant, to teach thee there's no
     labouring i' th' winter.
 I
     would have none but knaves follow it, since a fool gives it.

          But I will tarry; the fool will stay,
            And let the wise man fly.

          The knave turns fool that runs away;
            The fool no knave, perdy.

  Glou.

     Infirmity doth still neglect all office
     Whereto our health is bound.
- Death on my state! Wherefore
     Should be sit here? This act persuades me
     That this remotion of the Duke and her
     Is practice only.
 Give me my servant forth.

     Go tell the Duke and 's wife I'ld speak with them-
     Now, presently.
 Bid them come forth and hear me,
     Or at their chamber door I'll beat the drum
     Till it cry sleep to death.
                 Exit.
 O me, my heart, my rising heart! But down!
  Fool.
 She knapp'd 'em o' th' coxcombs with
     a stick and cried 'Down, wantons, down!' 'Twas her brother that,
     in pure kindness to his horse, buttered his hay.

  Lear.
 I have hope
     You less know how to value her desert
     Than she to scant her duty.
 If, sir, perchance
     She have restrain'd the riots of your followers,  
     'Tis on such ground, and to such wholesome end,
     As clears her from all blame.

  Lear.
 My curses on her!
  Reg.
 Therefore I pray you
     That to our sister you do make return;
     Say you have wrong'd her, sir.

  Lear.
          [Kneels.
 On my knees I beg
     That you'll vouchsafe me raiment, bed, and food.
 Good sir, no more! These are unsightly tricks.

     Return you to my sister.
 Fie, sir, fie!
  Lear.
 No, Regan, thou shalt never have my curse.

  Reg.
 Good sir, to th' purpose.
 This approves her letter,
     That she would soon be here.
 Return to her, and fifty men dismiss'd?
     No, rather I abjure all roofs, and choose
     To wage against the enmity o' th' air,
     To be a comrade with the wolf and owl-
     Necessity's sharp pinch! Return with her?
     Why, the hot-blooded France, that dowerless took
     Our youngest born, I could as well be brought
     To knee his throne, and, squire-like, pension beg
     To keep base life afoot.
                 [Points at Oswald.

     I will not trouble thee, my child; farewell.

     We'll no more meet, no more see one another.

     I look'd not for you yet, nor am provided
     For your fit welcome.
 Give ear, sir, to my sister;
     For those that mingle reason with your passion
     Must be content to think you old, and so-
     But she knows what she does.
 To no more
     Will I give place or notice.

  Lear.

  Lear.
  
     What need you five-and-twenty, ten, or five,
     To follow in a house where twice so many
     Have a command to tend you?
  Reg.
 O, reason not the need! Our basest beggars
     Are in the poorest thing superfluous.

     Allow not nature more than nature needs,
     Man's life is cheap as beast's.

     If it be you that stirs these daughters' hearts
     Against their father, fool me not so much
     To bear it tamely; touch me with noble anger,
     And let not women's weapons, water drops,
     Stain my man's cheeks! No, you unnatural hags!
     I will have such revenges on you both  
     That all the world shall- I will do such things-
     What they are yet, I know not; but they shall be
     The terrors of the earth! You think I'll weep.

     No, I'll not weep.

  Reg.

  Reg.

  
                          Enter Gloucester.

  Glou.
 Whither is he going?
  Glou.

  Glou.
>>



ACT III.


Storm still.


  Kent.
 I know you.

  Kent.
 There is division
     (Although as yet the face of it be cover'd
     With mutual cunning) 'twixt Albany and Cornwall;
     Who have (as who have not, that their great stars
     Thron'd and set high?) servants, who seem no less,
     Which are to France the spies and speculations
     Intelligent of our state.

  Gent.

Another part of the heath.
 Then let fall  
     Your horrible pleasure.
 No, I will be the pattern of all patience;
     I will say nothing.

  Kent.
 Alas, sir, are you here? Things that love night
     Love not such nights as these.
 The wrathful skies
     Gallow the very wanderers of the dark
     And make them keep their caves.
 I am a man
     More sinn'd against than sinning.

     Poor fool and knave, I have one part in my heart
     That's sorry yet for thee.


  Lear.
 This is a brave night to cool a courtesan.

          Then comes the time, who lives to see't,
          That going shall be us'd with feet.


  Glou.
 These injuries the King now bears will be revenged
     home; there's part of a power already footed; we must incline to
     the King.
 Though I
     die for't, as no less is threat'ned me, the King my old master
     must be relieved.

The heath.
 Wilt break my heart?
  Kent.
 I had rather break mine own.
 So 'tis to thee;
     But where the greater malady is fix'd,
     The lesser is scarce felt.
 When the mind's free,
     The body's delicate.
 Good my lord, enter here.
 But I'll go in.

                                                    Exit [Fool].
 Who gives anything to poor Tom? whom the foul fiend hath led  
     through fire and through flame, through ford and whirlpool, o'er
     bog and quagmire; that hath laid knives under his pillow and
     halters in his pew, set ratsbane by his porridge, made him proud
     of heart, to ride on a bay trotting horse over four-inch'd
     bridges, to course his own shadow for a traitor.

     Is it the fashion that discarded fathers
     Should have thus little mercy on their flesh?  
     Judicious punishment! 'Twas this flesh begot
     Those pelican daughters.

  Edg.
 What hast thou been?
  Edg.
 Wine lov'd
     I deeply, dice dearly; and in woman out-paramour'd the Turk.
 Why, thou wert better in thy grave than to answer with thy
     uncover'd body this extremity of the skies.
 Prithee, nuncle, be contented! 'Tis a naughty night to swim
     in.
 Who's there? What is't you seek?
  Glou.


     Beware my follower.
 What, hath your Grace no better company?
  Edg.
 The prince of darkness is a gentleman!
     Modo he's call'd, and Mahu.
 Let me ask you one word in private.
 What a night 's this!
     I do beseech your Grace-
  Lear.
  
     Noble philosopher, your company.
 With him!
     I will keep still with my philosopher.

  Glou.

Gloucester's Castle.

  Edm.
 If the matter of this paper be certain, you have mighty
     business in hand.

  Corn.

  Edm.

                                                         Exeunt.
 I will
     piece out the comfort with what addition I can.

  Kent.
 All the power of his wits have given way to his impatience.
 Pray, innocent, and beware the foul fiend.

  Lear.
 No, he's a yeoman that has a gentleman to his son; for he's a
     mad yeoman that sees his son a gentleman before him.
 The foul fiend bites my back.
  
  Lear.
 Now, you she-foxes!
  Edg.
 Look, where he stands and glares! Want'st thou eyes at trial,
     madam?

             Come o'er the bourn, Bessy, to me.

  Kent.
 How do you, sir? Stand you not so amaz'd.
 [To Kent] You are o' th' commission,
     Sit you too.
 Arraign her first.
 I here take my oath before
     this honourable assembly, she kicked the poor King her father.
 Come hither, mistress.

  Fool.
 Sessa! Come, march to wakes and fairs and market
     towns.

  Lear.

     So, so, so.
 So, so, so.

  Fool.
 And I'll go to bed at noon.
 Good friend, I prithee take him in thy arms.

  Glou.
                                         [Exit.
 Pluck out his eyes.

  Corn.
 Our posts shall be swift and intelligent betwixt us.

                           Exeunt Goneril, [Edmund, and Oswald].

  Glou.

  Corn.

                                            [Servants bind him.
 By the kind gods, 'tis most ignobly done
     To pluck me by the beard.
 So white, and such a traitor!
  Glou.
 Be simple-answer'd, for we know the truth.

  Glou.
 I have a letter guessingly set down,
     Which came from one that's of a neutral heart,
     And not from one oppos'd.

  Corn.
 Wherefore to Dover? Wast thou not charg'd at peril-
  Corn.
 Wherefore to Dover? Let him first answer that.
 I am tied to th' stake, and I must stand the course.
'
     All cruels else subscrib'd.
 But I shall see
     The winged vengeance overtake such children.

     Upon these eyes of thine I'll set my foot.
 If you see vengeance-
  1.
  
  Reg.
 Give me thy sword.
 Go thrust him out at gates, and let him smell
     His way to Dover.
 I have receiv'd a hurt.
 Give me your arm.
 I'll never care what wickedness I do,
     If this man come to good.
 Let's follow the old Earl, and get the bedlam
     To lead him where he would.





<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.

The heath.
 Yet better thus, and known to be contemn'd,
     Than still contemn'd and flatter'd.
 I have no way, and therefore want no eyes;
     I stumbled when I saw.
 Ah dear son Edgar,
     The food of thy abused father's wrath!
     Might I but live to see thee in my touch,
     I'ld say I had eyes again!
  Old Man.
 Is it a beggarman?
  Old Man.
 He has some reason, else he could not beg.
 I have heard more since.
- Bless thee, master!
  Glou.
 Then prithee get thee gone.
                                  Exit.
 Sirrah naked fellow-
  Edg.
 [aside] And yet I must.

  Glou.
 So,
     bless thee, master!
  Glou.
 Heavens, deal so still!  
     Let the superfluous and lust-dieted man,
     That slaves your ordinance, that will not see
     Because he does not feel, feel your pow'r quickly;
     So distribution should undo excess,
     And each man have enough.
 Give me thy arm.


Enter Goneril and [Edmund the] Bastard.
 I marvel our mild husband
     Not met us on the way.


                     Enter [Oswald the] Steward.

     I told him of the army that was landed:
     He smil'd at it.
 Ere long you are like to hear
     (If you dare venture in your own behalf)
     A mistress's command.
          [Gives a favour.
 This kiss, if it durst speak,
     Would stretch thy spirits up into the air.

     Conceive, and fare thee well.

  Osw.

     Could my good brother suffer you to do it?
     A man, a prince, by him so benefited!  
     If that the heavens do not their visible spirits
     Send quickly down to tame these vile offences,
     It will come,
     Humanity must perforce prey on itself,
     Like monsters of the deep.
 Thou changed and self-cover'd thing, for shame!  
     Bemonster not thy feature! Were't my fitness
     To let these hands obey my blood,
     They are apt enough to dislocate and tear
     Thy flesh and bones.
 Howe'er thou art a fiend,
     A woman's shape doth shield thee.
 This shows you are above,
     You justicers, that these our nether crimes
     So speedily can venge! But O poor Gloucester!
     Lose he his other eye?
  Gent.
 Both, both, my lord.

  Gon.

Exit.
 Where was his son when they did take his eyes?
  Gent.

                                                         Exeunt.





Scene III.
 The Marshal of France, Monsieur La Far.

  Kent.
 In brief,
     Sorrow would be a rarity most belov'd,
     If all could so become it.
 Made she no verbal question?
  Gent.
 No.
 Alack, poor gentleman!
  Kent.

     When I am known aright, you shall not grieve
     Lending me this acquaintance.

The French camp.

     Our foster nurse of nature is repose,
     The which he lacks.

  Cor.
 'Tis known before.
 Our preparation stands
     In expectation of them.
 O dear father,
     It is thy business that I go about.

     No blown ambition doth our arms incite,
     But love, dear love, and our ag'd father's right.


  Reg.
 Ay, madam.

     Your sister is the better soldier.
 I know not, lady.

     It was great ignorance, Gloucester's eyes being out,
     To let him live.
 Edmund, I think, is gone,
     In pity of his misery, to dispatch
     His nighted life; moreover, to descry
     The strength o' th' enemy.
 I may not, madam.
 Why should she write to Edmund? Might not you
     Transport her purposes by word? Belike,
     Something- I know not what- I'll love thee much-
     Let me unseal the letter.
 You may gather more.
 Would I could meet him, madam! I should show
     What party I do follow.

The country near Dover.
 Look how we labour.
 Why, then, your other senses grow imperfect
     By your eyes' anguish.
 Methinks y'are better spoken.
 The murmuring surge
     That on th' unnumb'red idle pebble chafes
     Cannot be heard so high.
 Set me where you stand.
 You are now within a foot
     Of th' extreme verge.
 For all beneath the moon
     Would I not leap upright.

  Glou.
  
  Edg.

  Glou.

  Edg.
 Hadst thou been aught but gossamer, feathers, air,
     So many fadom down precipitating,
     Thou'dst shiver'd like an egg; but thou dost breathe;
     Hast heavy substance; bleed'st not; speak'st; art sound.

     It was some fiend.
 Therefore, thou happy father,
     Think that the clearest gods, who make them honours
     Of men's impossibility, have preserv'd thee.
 Henceforth I'll bear
     Affliction till it do cry out itself
     'Enough, enough,' and die.
 That thing you speak of,
     I took it for a man.
 Often 'twould say
     'The fiend, the fiend'- he led me to that place.
 O thou side-piercing sight!
  Lear.
 Nature 's above art in that respect.
 There's your press
     money.
 Draw me
     a clothier's yard.
 There's my gauntlet; I'll prove it
     on a giant.
 Bring up the brown bills.
 O, well flown, bird! i'
     th' clout, i' th' clout! Hewgh! Give the word.

  Lear.

  Glou.

  Lear.
 When the rain came to wet me
     once, and the wind to make me chatter; when the thunder would  
     not peace at my bidding; there I found 'em, there I smelt 'em
     out.
 Go to, they are not men o' their words! They told me I was
     everything.
 Ay, every inch a king!
     When I do stare, see how the subject quakes.
 Die for adultery? No.

     To't, luxury, pell-mell! for I lack soldiers.
  
     The fitchew nor the soiled horse goes to't
     With a more riotous appetite.

  Glou.
 O, let me kiss that hand!
  Lear.
 Dost thou know me?
  Lear.
 Dost thou squiny at me?
     No, do thy worst, blind Cupid! I'll not love.

  Glou.
  
  Lear.
 Read.

  Glou.

  Lear.
 Hark in thine ear.

     Through tatter'd clothes small vices do appear;
     Robes and furr'd gowns hide all.
 Now, now, now, now!
     Pull off my boots.
 Alack, alack the day!
  Lear.
 When we are born, we cry that we are come
     To this great stage of fools.
 This' a good block.
 No seconds? All myself?
     Why, this would make a man a man of salt,
     To use his eyes for garden waterpots,
     Ay, and laying autumn's dust.

  Gent.
 Then there's life in't.
 Nay, an you get it, you shall get it
     by running.
 I thank you sir.
 That's all.

  Gent.

  Glou.
 Well pray you, father.

  Glou.
 A most poor man, made tame to fortune's blows,
     Who, by the art of known and feeling sorrows,
     Am pregnant to good pity.
 The sword is out
     That must destroy thee.
 An chud
     ha' bin zwagger'd out of my life, 'twould not ha' bin zo long as
     'tis by a vortnight.
 Out, dunghill!
                                                     They fight.
 Come! No matter vor your foins.

  Edg.
 Sit you down, father; rest you.
 I am only sorry
     He had no other deathsman.
 Let us see.
 If your will want not, time and
     place will be fruitfully offer'd.
 There is nothing done, if he  
     return the conqueror.
 The King is mad.


  Cor.
 Madam, sleeps still.
 So please your Majesty
     That we may wake the King? He hath slept long.
 Be govern'd by your knowledge, and proceed
     I' th' sway of your own will.
 Is he array'd?

              Enter Lear in a chair carried by Servants.
 Be by, good madam, when we do awake him.
 Kind and dear princess!
  Cor.

  Cor.
 How does my royal lord? How fares your Majesty?
  Lear.
  
  Cor.
 Still, still, far wide!
  Doct.

     I am a very foolish fond old man,
     Fourscore and upward, not an hour more nor less;
     And, to deal plainly,
     I fear I am not in my perfect mind.
 And so I am! I am!
  Lear.

  Doct.
 Be comforted, good madam.
  
  Cor.
 They say Edgar, his banish'd son, is with the Earl of Kent
     in Germany.
 'Tis time to look about; the powers of
     the kingdom approach apace.
 My point and period will be throughly wrought,
     Or well or ill, as this day's battle's fought.

The British camp near Dover.


  Edm.
 Know of the Duke if his last purpose hold,
     Or whether since he is advis'd by aught
     To change the course.
 Our sister's man is certainly miscarried.

  Reg.

  Reg.
 Fear me not.
 [aside] I had rather lose the battle than that sister
     Should loosen him and me.
  
  Reg.
 I shall attend you presently at your tent.

  Reg.
 Sister, you'll go with us?
  Gon.
 If e'er your Grace had speech with man so poor,
     Hear me one word.

                              Exeunt [all but Albany and Edgar].
 Before you fight the battle, ope this letter.
 I was forbid it.

     When time shall serve, let but the herald cry,
     And I'll appear again.
 I will o'erlook thy paper.
 To both these sisters have I sworn my love;  
     Each jealous of the other, as the stung
     Are of the adder.
 Which of them shall I take?
     Both? one? or neither? Neither can be enjoy'd,
     If both remain alive.
 To take the widow
     Exasperates, makes mad her sister Goneril;
     And hardly shall I carry out my side,
     Her husband being alive.





Scene II.


Enter Edgar and Gloucester.
 Pray that the right may thrive.


               Alarum and retreat within.
 A man may rot even here.
 And that's true too.

  Cor.
 We are not the first
     Who with best meaning have incurr'd the worst.

     For thee, oppressed king, am I cast down;
     Myself could else outfrown false Fortune's frown.

  Edm.

     The goodyears shall devour 'em, flesh and fell,
     Ere they shall make us weep! We'll see 'em starv'd first.
 Come hither, Captain; hark.

     One step I have advanc'd thee.
 If thou dost
     As this instructs thee, thou dost make thy way
     To noble fortunes.
 I cannot draw a cart, nor eat dried oats;
     If it be man's work, I'll do't.


          Flourish.
 You have the captives
     Who were the opposites of this day's strife.

  Alb.
 Sir, by your patience,
     I hold you but a subject of this war,
     Not as a brother.
 That's as we list to grace him.
  
  Gon.

  Gon.
 Lady, I am not well; else I should answer
     From a full-flowing stomach.

     Witness the world that I create thee here
     My lord and master.
 Mean you to enjoy him?
  Alb.
 Half-blooded fellow, yes.
 [to Edmund] Let the drum strike, and prove my title thine.

  Gon.
 An interlude!
  Alb.
 Let the trumpet sound.

  Reg.
 [aside] If not, I'll ne'er trust medicine.

  Edm.
 He that dares approach,
     On him, on you, who not? I will maintain
     My truth and honour firmly.
 A herald, ho!
  Edm.
 My sickness grows upon me.
]

                           Enter a Herald.

  Her.
 Again!                                     Third trumpet.
 What's he that speaks for Edmund Earl of Gloucester?
  Edm.

     Behold, it is the privilege of mine honours,
     My oath, and my profession.
 In wisdom I should ask thy name;
     But since thy outside looks so fair and warlike,
     And that thy tongue some say of breeding breathes,
     What safe and nicely I might well delay
     By rule of knighthood, I disdain and spurn.
]
  Alb.

     [To Goneril] Thou worse than any name, read thine own evil.
 Say if I do- the laws are mine, not thine.

     Who can arraign me for't?
  Alb.
 Most monstrous!
     Know'st thou this paper?
  Gon.
 Ask me not what I know.

  Alb.

     I am no less in blood than thou art, Edmund;
     If more, the more th' hast wrong'd me.

     The wheel is come full circle; I am here.
 This speech of yours hath mov'd me,
     And shall perchance do good; but speak you on;
     You look as you had something more to say.

  Alb.


  Gent.

     It came even from the heart of- O! she's dead!
  Alb.
 Who dead? Speak, man.
 All three
     Now marry in an instant.
]
     This judgement of the heavens, that makes us tremble
     Touches us not with pity.
 I am come
     To bid my king and master aye good night.
 Great thing of us forgot!
     Speak, Edmund, where's the King? and where's Cordelia?
                 The bodies of Goneril and Regan are brought in.
 Run, run, O, run!
  Edg.

  Edm.
  
  Alb.
 The gods defend her! Bear him hence awhile.

                                          [Edmund is borne off.

     She's dead as earth.

     If that her breath will mist or stain the stone,
     Why, then she lives.

  Lear.
 Ha!
     What is't thou say'st, Her voice was ever soft,
     Gentle, and low- an excellent thing in woman.

  Capt.

  Lear.
 The same-
     Your servant Kent.
 Where is your servant Caius?
  Lear.
 He's a good fellow, I can tell you that.

  Lear.
 Nor no man else! All's cheerless, dark, and deadly.
 He knows not what he says; and vain is it
     That we present us to him.

  Edg.


                           Enter a Captain.
 For us, we will resign,
     During the life of this old Majesty,
     To him our absolute power; [to Edgar and Kent] you to your
        rights;
     With boot, and Such addition as your honours
     Have more than merited.
  
  Edg.
 Our present business
     Is general woe.

     My master calls me; I must not say no.

  Alb.
 My loving lord, Dumain is mortified.
 I can but say their protestation over;
    So much, dear liege, I have already sworn,
    That is, to live and study here three years.

    But there are other strict observances,
    As: not to see a woman in that term,  
    Which I hope well is not enrolled there;
    And one day in a week to touch no food,
    And but one meal on every day beside,
    The which I hope is not enrolled there;
    And then to sleep but three hours in the night
    And not be seen to wink of all the day-
    When I was wont to think no harm all night,
    And make a dark night too of half the day-
    Which I hope well is not enrolled there.
 Your oath is pass'd to pass away from these.
 You swore to that, Berowne, and to the rest.

    What is the end of study, let me know.

  KING.
 Things hid and barr'd, you mean, from common sense?  
  KING.

    If study's gain be thus, and this be so,
    Study knows that which yet it doth not know.

  BEROWNE.
 Why, all delights are vain; but that most vain
    Which, with pain purchas'd, doth inherit pain,
    As painfully to pore upon a book
    To seek the light of truth; while truth the while
    Doth falsely blind the eyesight of his look.

    Study me how to please the eye indeed,
    By fixing it upon a fairer eye;
    Who dazzling so, that eye shall be his heed,
    And give him light that it was blinded by.

  BEROWNE.
 In reason nothing.

  BEROWNE.

  KING.

  KING.
 [Reads] 'Item.
 That no woman shall come within a mile of
    my court'- Hath this been proclaimed?
  LONGAVILLE.
 Four days ago.
 Let's see the penalty.
 [Reads] '-on pain of losing her
    tongue.
' Who devis'd this penalty?
  LONGAVILLE.
 If any man be seen to talk with a woman within
    the term of three years, he shall endure such public shame as the
    rest of the court can possibly devise.
 So study evermore is over-shot.

  KING.

    So to the laws at large I write my name;        [Subscribes]
    And he that breaks them in the least degree
    Stands in attainder of eternal shame.
  
    Suggestions are to other as to me;
    But I believe, although I seem so loath,
    I am the last that will last keep his oath.
 Ay, that there is.
 Signior Arme- Arme- commends you.
 Sir, the contempts thereof are as touching me.
 Well, sir, be it as the style shall give us cause to climb
    in the merriness.

    The manner of it is, I was taken with the manner.

  BEROWNE.

  BEROWNE.
 Will you hear this letter with attention?
  BEROWNE.

  COSTARD.
  
  KING.
 Be to me, and every man that dares not fight!
  KING.

  KING.
 So much for the time When.
 Then
    for the place Where? where, I mean, I did encounter that obscene
    and most prepost'rous event that draweth from my snow-white pen
    the ebon-coloured ink which here thou viewest, beholdest,
    surveyest, or seest.
 There did I see that low-spirited swain,  
    that base minnow of thy mirth,'
  COSTARD.
 'that shallow vassal,'
  COSTARD.
 Me, an't shall please you; I am Antony Dull.
 Ay, the best for the worst.
 But, sirrah, what say you to
    this?
  COSTARD.

  KING.
 This maid will serve my turn, sir.
 Sir, I will pronounce your sentence: you shall fast a week
    with bran and water.
 Boy, what sign is it when a man of great spirit grows
    melancholy?
  MOTH.
 Why tough signior? Why tough signior?
  MOTH.
 Pretty and apt.
 How mean you, sir? I pretty, and my saying apt? or I apt, and
    my saying pretty?  
  ARMADO.
 Wherefore apt?
  ARMADO.

  MOTH.
 Speak you this in my praise, master?
  ARMADO.

  MOTH.
 That an eel is quick.

  ARMADO.
 I do say thou art quick in answers; thou heat'st my blood.

  ARMADO.

  ARMADO.
 I am ill at reck'ning; it fitteth the spirit of a tapster.

  MOTH.
 Which the base vulgar do call three.
 A most fine figure!
  MOTH.
 And as it is base for
    a soldier to love, so am I in love with a base wench.
 I
    think scorn to sigh; methinks I should out-swear Cupid.
 Comfort
    me, boy; what great men have been in love?
  MOTH.

  ARMADO.

  ARMADO.
 Tell me precisely of what complexion.
  
  MOTH.

  ARMADO.
 Define, define, well-educated infant.

             Then if she fear, or be to blame,
               By this you shall not know;
             For still her cheeks possess the same
               Which native she doth owe.

  ARMADO.

  ARMADO.

  JAQUENETTA.
 Lord, how wise you are!  
  ARMADO.

  ARMADO.
 And so, farewell.
 Villain, thou shalt fast for thy offences ere thou be
    pardoned.

  COSTARD.
 Thou shalt be heavily punished.

  COSTARD.
 Take away this villain; shut him up.
 Let me not be pent up, sir; I will fast, being loose.

    I shall be forsworn- which is a great argument of falsehood- if I
    love.
 There is no evil angel but
    Love.
 The first and second cause
    will not serve my turn; the passado he respects not, the duello
    he regards not; his disgrace is to be called boy, but his glory
    is to subdue men.
  
    Devise, wit; write, pen; for I am for whole volumes in folio.

  PRINCESS OF FRANCE.
 Know you the man?
  MARIA.

    A man of sovereign parts, peerless esteem'd,
    Well fitted in arts, glorious in arms;
    Nothing becomes him ill that he would well.
  
    Who are the rest?
  KATHARINE.

    Berowne they call him; but a merrier man,
    Within the limit of becoming mirth,
    I never spent an hour's talk withal.
 Marry, thus much I have learnt:
    He rather means to lodge you in the field,
    Like one that comes here to besiege his court,
    Than seek a dispensation for his oath,
    To let you enter his unpeopled house.

                                    [The LADIES-IN-WAITING mask]
  
             Enter KING, LONGAVILLE, DUMAIN, BEROWNE,
                         and ATTENDANTS

    Here comes Navarre.

  PRINCESS OF FRANCE.
 I will be welcome then; conduct me thither.
 Our Lady help my lord! He'll be forsworn.

  KING.
 Not for the world, fair madam, by my will.

  PRINCESS OF FRANCE.

    I hear your Grace hath sworn out house-keeping.
 YOU Will the sooner that I were away,
    For you'll prove perjur'd if you make me stay.
 I know you did.

  KATHARINE.

  BEROWNE.
 Not till it leave the rider in the mire.

  BEROWNE.
 Now fair befall your mask!
  KATHARINE.
 Madam, your father here doth intimate
    The payment of a hundred thousand crowns;
    Being but the one half of an entire sum
    Disbursed by my father in his wars.

    But say that he or we, as neither have,
    Receiv'd that sum, yet there remains unpaid
    A hundred thousand more, in surety of the which,
    One part of Aquitaine is bound to us,
    Although not valued to the money's worth.
 So please your Grace, the packet is not come,
    Where that and other specialties are bound;
    To-morrow you shall have a sight of them.

    Your own good thoughts excuse me, and farewell.
 Sweet health and fair desires consort your
    Grace!
  KING.
 Thy own wish wish I thee in every place.
 Pray you, do my commendations;  
    I would be glad to see it.
 Is the fool sick?
  BEROWNE.
 Alack, let it blood.
 Will YOU prick't with your eye?
  ROSALINE.
 And yours from long living!
  BEROWNE.
 Sir, I pray you, a word: what lady is that same?
  BOYET.
 A gallant lady! Monsieur, fare you well.

  LONGAVILLE.
 I desire her name.
 Pray you, sir, whose daughter?  
  BOYET.
 God's blessing on your beard!
  BOYET.
           Exit LONGAVILLE
  BEROWNE.
 What's her name in the cap?
  BOYET.
 Rosaline, by good hap.
 To her will, sir, or so.
 That last is Berowne, the merry mad-cap lord;
    Not a word with him but a jest.
  
  KATHARINE.
 And wherefore not ships?
    No sheep, sweet lamb, unless we feed on your lips.
 You sheep and I pasture- shall that finish the jest?
  BOYET.
 So you grant pasture for me.
     [Offering to kiss her]
  KATHARINE.
 Belonging to whom?
  KATHARINE.
 Your reason?
  BOYET.

    His heart, like an agate, with your print impressed,
    Proud with his form, in his eye pride expressed;
    His tongue, all impatient to speak and not see,
    Did stumble with haste in his eyesight to be;
    All senses to that sense did make their repair,
    To feel only looking on fairest of fair.

    I'll give you Aquitaine and all that is his,
    An you give him for my sake but one loving kiss.
 Come, to our pavilion.

  MARIA.
 He is Cupid's grandfather, and learns news of him.
 Ay, our way to be gone.

  BOYET.
 Warble, child; make passionate my sense of hearing.

  MOTH.
 Master, will you win your love with a French brawl?
  ARMADO.
 The hobby-horse is forgot.
 Call'st thou my love 'hobby-horse'?
  MOTH.
 A man, if I live; and this, by, in, and without, upon the
    instant.
 Fetch hither the swain; he must carry me a letter.

  MOTH.

  ARMADO.
 But I go.

  ARMADO.

  ARMADO.
 I say lead is slow.

  MOTH.

  ARMADO.

  COSTARD.

    There's the moral.

  MOTH.
 I will tell you sensibly.

  COSTARD.
 True, true; and now you will be my purgation, and let me
    loose.
 Like the sequel, I.
 Signior Costard, adieu.

  COSTARD.
 God be wi' you!
  BEROWNE.
 Stay, slave; I must employ thee.

  BEROWNE.
 It must be done this afternoon.

    Hark, slave, it is but this:
    The Princess comes to hunt here in the park,
    And in her train there is a gentle lady;
    When tongues speak sweetly, then they name her name,
    And Rosaline they call her.
