SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
 I most fehemently desire you you will also look that
    way.
 How
    melancholies I am! I will knog his urinals about his knave's
    costard when I have goot opportunities for the ork.
 He's welcome.
                                   [Sings]
    To shallow rivers, to whose falls-
    Heaven prosper the right! What weapons is he?
  SIMPLE.
 Pless you from his mercy sake, all of you!
  SHALLOW.
 And youthful still, in your doublet and hose, this raw
    rheumatic day!
  EVANS.
 We are come to you to do a good office, Master
    Parson.

  EVANS.

  SLENDER.
 Disarm them, and let them question; let them keep
    their limbs whole and hack our English.
 I pray you, let-a me speak a word with your ear.
  [Aside to CAIUS]  Pray you use your patience; in
    good time.

  HOST.
 Peace, I say.
 Hear mine host of the Garter.
 Trust me, a mad host.

  SLENDER.
  [Aside]  O sweet Anne Page!
                                  Exeunt all but CAIUS and EVANS
  CAIUS.
 Well, I will smite his noddles.
 Pray you follow.
 Is she at home?
  FORD.

  MRS.
 What do you call your knight's
    name, sirrah?
  ROBIN.
 Sir John Falstaff!
  MRS.
 I am sick till I see her.
 And Falstaff's
    boy with her! Good plots! They are laid; and our revolted  
    wives share damnation together.
 I will go.
 Trust me, a good knot; I have good cheer at home,
    and I pray you all go with me.
 I must excuse myself, Master Ford.

  SLENDER.
  
  SHALLOW.
 I beseech you, heartily, some of you go home with me  
    to dinner: besides your cheer, you shall have sport; I will
    show you a monster.
            Exit RUGBY
  HOST.


FORD'S house

Enter MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE

  MRS.
 PAGE.
 Come, come, come.

  MRS.
 FORD.
 You will do it?
  MRS.
 Be gone, and come when you are call'd.

  MRS.
 FORD.
 FORD.
 O this blessed hour!
  MRS.
 Now shall I sin in my wish; I would thy
    husband were dead; I'll speak it before the best lord, I
    would make thee my lady.
  
  FALSTAFF.
 Thou mightst as well say I love to walk by the
    Counter-gate, which is as hateful to me as the reek of a
    lime-kiln.

  FALSTAFF.

  FALSTAFF.
 What's the matter, good Mistress Page?
  MRS.
 FORD.

  MRS.

  MRS.
 If you know yourself clear, why,
    I am glad of it; but if you have a friend here, convey,
    convey him out.
 Be not amaz'd; call all your senses to you;
    defend your reputation, or bid farewell to your good life  
    for ever.
 What shall I do? There is a gentleman, my dear
    friend; and I fear not mine own shame as much as his peril.

    I had rather than a thousand pound he were out of the
    house.
 PAGE.
 O,
    how have you deceiv'd me! Look, here is a basket; if he be
    of any reasonable stature, he may creep in here; and throw
    foul linen upon him, as if it were going to bucking, or-it is
    whiting-time-send him by your two men to Datchet
    Mead.
 FORD.
  [Coming forward]  Let me see 't, let me see 't.
 What, Sir John Falstaff!      [Aside to FALSTAFF]
    Are these your letters, knight?
  FALSTAFF.
 Help to cover your master, boy.
 FORD.
 What, John! Robert! John!                Exit ROBIN

                 Re-enter SERVANTS

    Go, take up these clothes here, quickly; where's the
    cowl-staff? Look how you drumble.
 FORD.
  [Locking the door]  So, now
    uncape.
 This is fery fantastical humours and jealousies.
                        Exeunt EVANS, PAGE, and CAIUS
  MRS.
 PAGE.
 FORD.
 I think my husband hath some special suspicion
    of Falstaff's being here, for I never saw him so gross in his
    jealousy till now.
 Shall we send that foolish carrion, Mistress
    Quickly, to him, and excuse his throwing into the water,
    and give him another hope, to betray him to another
    punishment?
  MRS.
 We will do it; let him be sent for to-morrow
    eight o'clock, to have amends.
 I cannot find him; may be the knave bragg'd of that
    he could not compass.
 FORD.
 FORD.
 Amen.

  MRS.

  FORD.
 'Tis my fault, Master Page; I suffer for it.
 Shall it be so?
  FORD.
 I pray you now, remembrance to-morrow on the
    lousy knave, mine host.
 I see I cannot get thy father's love;
    Therefore no more turn me to him, sweet Nan.

  ANNE.
 Why, thou must be thyself.

    He doth object I am too great of birth;
    And that, my state being gall'd with my expense,
    I seek to heal it only by his wealth.
.

    If opportunity and humblest suit
    Cannot attain it, why then-hark you hither.

  SHALLOW.
 Hark ye, Master Slender would speak a word
    with you.

  SHALLOW.
 O boy, thou hadst a
    father!
  SLENDER.

  SHALLOW.
 Mistress Anne, my cousin loves you.
 He will make you a hundred and fifty pounds
    jointure.
  
  SHALLOW.
 Good Master Fenton, come not to my child.

  FENTON.
 No, good Master Fenton.
 Speak to Mistress Page.
 Good Mistress Page, for that I love your daughter
    In such a righteous fashion as I do,
    Perforce, against all checks, rebukes, and manners,
    I must advance the colours of my love,
    And not retire.
 Good mother, do not marry me to yond fool.
 Alas, I had rather be set quick i' th' earth.
 PAGE and ANNE
  QUICKLY.


The Garter Inn

Enter FALSTAFF and BARDOLPH

  FALSTAFF.
 Bardolph, I say!
  BARDOLPH.
 Here, sir.

                                                   Exit BARDOLPH
    Have I liv'd to be carried in a basket, like a barrow of
    butcher's offal, and to be thrown in the Thames? Well, if
    I be serv'd such another trick, I'll have my brains ta'en out
    and butter'd, and give them to a dog for a new-year's gift.
 Come, let me pour in some sack to the Thames
    water; for my belly's as cold as if I had swallow'd
    snowballs for pills to cool the reins.
 By your leave; I cry you mercy.
 Well, she laments, sir, for it, that it would yearn
    your heart to see it.
 Her husband goes this morning
    a-birding; she desires you once more to come to her between
    eight and nine; I must carry her word quickly.
 Tell her so; and bid her
    think what a man is.
 Eight and nine, sir.

  FALSTAFF.
 Well, be gone; I will not miss her.
 I like his money well.

  FALSTAFF.
 Master Brook, I will not lie to you; I was at her
    house the hour she appointed me.

  FORD.
 And did he search for you, and could not find you?
  FALSTAFF.

  FORD.

  FALSTAFF.
 If I have horns to make one mad, let the proverb
    go with me-I'll be horn mad.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
>>



ACT IV.

  MRS.
 No; Master Slender is let the boys leave to play.

  QUICKLY.
 Sir Hugh, my husband says my son profits
    nothing in the world at his book; I pray you ask him some
    questions in his accidence.
 Peace your tattlings.
 What is 'fair,' William?
  WILLIAM.
 Polecats! There are fairer things than polecats,
    sure.

    What is 'lapis,' William?
  WILLIAM.
 Articles are borrowed of the pronoun, and be
    thus declined: Singulariter, nominativo; hic, haec, hoc.
 Leave your prabbles, oman.
 O-vocativo, O.
 And that's a good root.
 Oman, forbear.
 PAGE.
 What is your genitive case plural, William?
  WILLIAM.
 Ay.
 Vengeance of Jenny's case; fie on her! Never  
    name her, child, if she be a whore.
 For shame, oman.

  QUICKLY.
 PAGE.

  EVANS.
 Show me now, William, some declensions of your
    pronouns.

  EVANS.
 Farewell, Mistress Page.
            Exeunt




SCENE 2.
 Step into th' chamber, Sir John.
      Exit FALSTAFF

                      Enter MISTRESS PAGE

  MRS.

  MRS.
 Why?
  MRS.
 He so takes on yonder with my husband; so rails
    against all married mankind; so curses an Eve's daughters,
    of what complexion soever; and so buffets himself on the
    forehead, crying 'Peer-out, peer-out!' that any madness I
    ever yet beheld seem'd but tameness, civility, and patience,
    to this his distemper he is in now.

  MRS.
 PAGE.
 FORD.
 No, I'll come no more i' th' basket.
 Alas, three of Master Ford's brothers watch the
    door with pistols, that none shall issue out; otherwise you
    might slip away ere he came.
 What shall I do? I'll creep up into the chimney.

  MRS.
 There they always use to discharge their
    birding-pieces.
 Creep into the kiln-hole.
 FORD.
 Neither press,  
    coffer, chest, trunk, well, vault, but he hath an abstract for
    the remembrance of such places, and goes to them by his
    note.

  FALSTAFF.
 FORD.
 Good hearts, devise something; any extremity
    rather than a mischief.

  MRS.
 PAGE.

  MRS.
 PAGE.
 Heaven guide him to thy husband's cudgel; and
    the devil guide his cudgel afterwards!
  MRS.
 FORD.
 We'll try that; for I'll appoint my men to carry
    the basket again, to meet him at the door with it as they
    did last time.
 PAGE.
 PAGE.
 Go, sirs, take the basket again on your shoulders;
    your master is hard at door; if he bid you set it down, obey
    him; quickly, dispatch.
                                 Exit
  FIRST SERVANT.
 Pray heaven it be not full of knight again.
 Youth in a basket! O you panderly
    rascals, there's a knot, a ging, a pack, a conspiracy
    against me.
 Now shall the devil be sham'd.

  EVANS.

  SHALLOW.
 Well said, brazen-face; hold it out.
 Come forth, sirrah.
 FORD.
 Will you take up your wife's
    clothes? Come away.

    Pluck me out all the linen.

  FORD.
 No, nor nowhere else but in your brain.

  MRS.
 What, hoa, Mistress Page! Come you and the old
    woman down; my husband will come into the chamber.

  FORD.
 A witch, a quean, an old cozening quean! Have I not
    forbid her my house? She comes of errands, does she? We
    are simple men; we do not know what's brought to pass
    under the profession of fortune-telling.
 We know nothing.

  MRS.


   Re-enter FALSTAFF in woman's clothes, and MISTRESS PAGE
  
  MRS.
 PAGE.
 I'll prat her.
 baggage, you polecat, you ronyon!
    Out, out! I'll conjure you, I'll fortune-tell you.
 FORD.
 FORD and MRS.
 PAGE
  MRS.
 PAGE.
 What think you? May we, with the warrant of
    womanhood and the witness of a good conscience, pursue
    him with any further revenge?
  MRS.
 Yes, by all means; if it be but to scrape the
    figures out of your husband's brains.
 If they can find in their
    hearts the poor unvirtuous fat knight shall be any further
    afflicted, we two will still be the ministers.


The Garter Inn

Enter HOST and BARDOLPH

  BARDOLPH.
 They shall have my horses, but I'll make them pay;
    I'll sauce them; they have had my house a week at
    command; I have turn'd away my other guests.

  PAGE.
 FORD.
 PAGE.

  PAGE.
 Well, let it not be doubted but he'll come,
    And in this shape.
 That likewise have we thought upon, and
    thus:
    Nan Page my daughter, and my little son,
    And three or four more of their growth, we'll dress
    Like urchins, ouphes, and fairies, green and white,
    With rounds of waxen tapers on their heads,
    And rattles in their hands; upon a sudden,
    As Falstaff, she, and I, are newly met,
    Let them from forth a sawpit rush at once
    With some diffused song; upon their sight  
    We two in great amazedness will fly.

  MRS.

  EVANS.

  MRS.
  
  PAGE.
 Nay, I'll to him again, in name of Brook;
    He'll tell me all his purpose.
 Fear not you that.
 It is admirable pleasures, and fery
    honest knaveries.
 Go, Mistress Ford.

    Send Quickly to Sir John to know his mind.


The Garter Inn

Enter HOST and SIMPLE

  HOST.
 There's an old woman, a fat woman, gone up into
    his chamber; I'll be so bold as stay, sir, till she come down;
    I come to speak with her, indeed.

  HOST.
 I'll call.

  FALSTAFF.

  FALSTAFF.
 Why, sir, they were nothing but about Mistress
    Anne Page: to know if it were my master's fortune to
    have her or no.

  HOST.
 Where is mine host?
  HOST.
 There is a friend
    of mine come to town tells me there is three  
    cozen-germans that has cozen'd all the hosts of Readins,
    of Maidenhead, of Colebrook, of horses and money.
 Vere is mine host de Jarteer?
  HOST.

  CAIUS.
                          Exit
  HOST.

    I never prosper'd since I forswore myself at primero.
 The devil take one party and his dam the other!
    And so they shall be both bestowed.
 But
    that my admirable dexterity of wit, my counterfeiting the
    action of an old woman, deliver'd me, the knave constable
    had set me i' th' stocks, i' th' common stocks, for a witch.
 Which means she to deceive, father or mother?
  FENTON.

    Bring you the maid, you shall not lack a priest.
>>



ACT V.
 This is
    the third time; I hope good luck lies in odd numbers.
 Away.

  QUICKLY.
 I'll provide you a chain, and I'll do what I can to
    get you a pair of horns.

  FORD.
 I am in haste; go along with
    me; I'll.
                 Exeunt




SCENE 2.

  SHALLOW.
 PAGE.
 They are all couch'd in a pit hard by Heme's
    oak, with obscur'd lights; which, at the very instant of
    Falstaff's and our meeting, they will at once display to the
    night.
 That cannot choose but amaze him.

  MRS.

  MRS.
 Trib, trib, fairies; come; and remember your parts.
 Come, come; trib,
    trib.


Another part of the Park

Enter FALSTAFF disguised as HERNE

  FALSTAFF.
 Send me a cool
    rut-time, Jove, or who can blame me to piss my tallow?
    Who comes here? my doe?

        Enter MISTRESS FORD and MISTRESS PAGE  

  MRS.
 Alas, what noise?
  MRS.
 What should this be?
  MRS.
 } Away, away.
 Fairies, black, grey, green, and white,
    You moonshine revellers, and shades of night,
    You orphan heirs of fixed destiny,
    Attend your office and your quality.

    Crier Hobgoblin, make the fairy oyes.
 Elves, list your names; silence, you airy toys.
 They are fairies; he that speaks to them shall die.
 About, about;
    Search Windsor castle, elves, within and out;
    Strew good luck, ouphes, on every sacred room,
    That it may stand till the perpetual doom
    In state as wholesome as in state 'tis fit,
    Worthy the owner and the owner it.

    Away, disperse; but till 'tis one o'clock,
    Our dance of custom round about the oak
    Of Herne the Hunter let us not forget.
 I smell a man of middle earth.
 Heavens defend me from that Welsh fairy, lest he
    transform me to a piece of cheese!
  PUCK.

    Pinch him, fairies, mutually;
    Pinch him for his villainy;
    Pinch him and burn him and turn him about,
    Till candles and star-light and moonshine be out.


        During this song they pinch FALSTAFF.

        FALSTAFF pulls off his buck's head, and rises

       Enter PAGE, FORD, MISTRESS PAGE, MISTRESS FORD, and
                        SIR HUGH EVANS

  PAGE.
 Ay, and an ox too; both the proofs are extant.

  FALSTAFF.

  EVANS.

  FORD.
 Why, Sir John, do you think, though we would
    have thrust virtue out of our hearts by the head and
    shoulders, and have given ourselves without scruple to hell,
    that ever the devil could have made you our delight?
  FORD.
 What, a hodge-pudding? a bag of flax?
  MRS.
 Old, cold, wither'd, and of intolerable entrails?
  FORD.
 Well, I am your theme; you have the start of me;
    I am dejected; I am not able to answer the Welsh flannel;
    ignorance itself is a plummet o'er me; use me as you will.
 I came yonder at Eton to marry Mistress Anne
    Page, and she's a great lubberly boy.

  PAGE.

  PAGE.
 Good George, be not angry.
 I knew of your
    purpose; turn'd my daughter into green; and, indeed, she
    is now with the Doctor at the dean'ry, and there married.

  PAGE.

    You would have married her most shamefully,  
    Where there was no proportion held in love.

    Th' offence is holy that she hath committed;
    And this deceit loses the name of craft,
    Of disobedience, or unduteous title,
    Since therein she doth evitate and shun
    A thousand irreligious cursed hours,
    Which forced marriage would have brought upon her.

    In love, the heavens themselves do guide the state;
    Money buys lands, and wives are sold by fate.

  FALSTAFF.
       Exeunt

THE END



<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.


          Enter EGEUS, and his daughter HERMIA, LYSANDER,
                           and DEMETRIUS

  EGEUS.

    Thou, thou, Lysander, thou hast given her rhymes,
    And interchang'd love-tokens with my child;
    Thou hast by moonlight at her window sung,
    With feigning voice, verses of feigning love,
    And stol'n the impression of her fantasy  
    With bracelets of thy hair, rings, gawds, conceits,
    Knacks, trifles, nosegays, sweetmeats- messengers
    Of strong prevailment in unhardened youth;
    With cunning hast thou filch'd my daughter's heart;
    Turn'd her obedience, which is due to me,
    To stubborn harshness.
  
  HERMIA.
 You have her father's love, Demetrius;
    Let me have Hermia's; do you marry him.

  EGEUS.
 I am, my lord, as well deriv'd as he,
    As well possess'd; my love is more than his;
    My fortunes every way as fairly rank'd,
    If not with vantage, as Demetrius';
    And, which is more than all these boasts can be,
    I am belov'd of beauteous Hermia.

  THESEUS.

  EGEUS.
 With duty and desire we follow you.
 Belike for want of rain, which I could well  
    Beteem them from the tempest of my eyes.
 O cross! too high to be enthrall'd to low.

  LYSANDER.
 O spite! too old to be engag'd to young.

  LYSANDER.

  LYSANDER.

    Were the world mine, Demetrius being bated,
    The rest I'd give to be to you translated.
 His folly, Helena, is no fault of mine.
 Helen, to you our minds we will unfold:
    To-morrow night, when Phoebe doth behold
    Her silver visage in the wat'ry glass,
    Decking with liquid pearl the bladed grass,
    A time that lovers' flights doth still conceal,
    Through Athens' gates have we devis'd to steal.

    But what of that? Demetrius thinks not so;
    He will not know what all but he do know.
 QUINCE'S house

Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING

  QUINCE.

  BOTTOM.
 Name what part I am for, and proceed.
 A lover, that kills himself most gallant for love.
 If I
    do it, let the audience look to their eyes; I will move storms; I
    will condole in some measure.
 I could play Ercles rarely, or a part to tear a cat
    in, to make all split.
 What is Thisby? A wand'ring knight?
  QUINCE.

  STARVELING.

    Tom Snout, the tinker.

  SNOUT.

  SNUG.
'
  QUINCE.
 I grant you, friends, if you should fright the ladies out
    of their wits, they would have no more discretion but to hang us;
    but I will aggravate my voice so, that I will roar you as gently
    as any sucking dove; I will roar you an 'twere any nightingale.
 Well, I will undertake it.

  QUINCE.
 We will meet; and there we may rehearse most obscenely and
    courageously.
 Take pains; be perfect; adieu.

  QUINCE.
 Enough; hold, or cut bow-strings.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.

A wood near Athens

Enter a FAIRY at One door, and PUCK at another

  PUCK.
      Over hill, over dale,
                Thorough bush, thorough brier,
              Over park, over pale,
                Thorough flood, thorough fire,
              I do wander every where,
              Swifter than the moon's sphere;
              And I serve the Fairy Queen,
              To dew her orbs upon the green.

  PUCK.

    And now they never meet in grove or green,
    By fountain clear, or spangled starlight sheen,
    But they do square, that all their elves for fear
    Creep into acorn cups and hide them there.
 Are not you he
    That frights the maidens of the villagery,
    Skim milk, and sometimes labour in the quern,  
    And bootless make the breathless housewife churn,
    And sometime make the drink to bear no barm,
    Mislead night-wanderers, laughing at their harm?
    Those that Hobgoblin call you, and sweet Puck,
    You do their work, and they shall have good luck.

    The wisest aunt, telling the saddest tale,
    Sometime for three-foot stool mistaketh me;
    Then slip I from her bum, down topples she,
    And 'tailor' cries, and falls into a cough;
    And then the whole quire hold their hips and laugh,  
    And waxen in their mirth, and neeze, and swear
    A merrier hour was never wasted there.
 Would that he were gone!

       Enter OBERON at one door, with his TRAIN, and TITANIA,
                        at another, with hers

  OBERON.
 Ill met by moonlight, proud Titania.
 Why art thou here,
    Come from the farthest steep of India,
    But that, forsooth, the bouncing Amazon,
    Your buskin'd mistress and your warrior love,  
    To Theseus must be wedded, and you come
    To give their bed joy and prosperity?
  OBERON.

    The human mortals want their winter here;
    No night is now with hymn or carol blest;
    Therefore the moon, the governess of floods,
    Pale in her anger, washes all the air,
    That rheumatic diseases do abound.

    But she, being mortal, of that boy did die;
    And for her sake do I rear up her boy;
    And for her sake I will not part with him.
 Perchance till after Theseus' wedding-day.
 Give me that boy and I will go with thee.
 Fairies, away.

    We shall chide downright if I longer stay.

  PUCK.

    And ere I take this charm from off her sight,
    As I can take it with another herb,
    I'll make her render up her page to me.
 I will not stay thy questions; let me go;
    Or, if thou follow me, do not believe
    But I shall do thee mischief in the wood.
 Fie, Demetrius!
    Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex.
 Ay, there it is.

    I know a bank where the wild thyme blows,
    Where oxlips and the nodding violet grows,
    Quite over-canopied with luscious woodbine,
    With sweet musk-roses, and with eglantine;
    There sleeps Titania sometime of the night,
    Lull'd in these flowers with dances and delight;
    And there the snake throws her enamell'd skin,
    Weed wide enough to wrap a fairy in;
    And with the juice of this I'll streak her eyes,
    And make her full of hateful fantasies.
 Fear not, my lord; your servant shall do so.
 Come now, a roundel and a fairy song;
    Then, for the third part of a minute, hence:
    Some to kill cankers in the musk-rose buds;
    Some war with rere-mice for their leathern wings,
    To make my small elves coats; and some keep back
    The clamorous owl that nightly hoots and wonders
    At our quaint spirits.
  
               Lulla, lulla, lullaby; lulla, lulla, lullaby.

  SECOND FAIRY.
  Weaving spiders, come not here;
                 Hence, you long-legg'd spinners, hence.

               One aloof stand sentinel.
          Exeunt FAIRIES

      Enter OBERON and squeezes the flower on TITANIA'S eyelids

  OBERON.
 What thou seest when thou dost wake,
    Do it for thy true-love take;
    Love and languish for his sake.
 Be it so, Lysander: find you out a bed,
    For I upon this bank will rest my head.
 One turf shall serve as pillow for us both;
    One heart, one bed, two bosoms, and one troth.

  HERMIA.

    I mean that my heart unto yours is knit,
    So that but one heart we can make of it;  
    Two bosoms interchained with an oath,
    So then two bosoms and a single troth.
 Amen, amen, to that fair prayer say I;
    And then end life when I end loyalty!
    Here is my bed; sleep give thee all his rest!
  HERMIA.
 O, I am out of breath in this fond chase!
    The more my prayer, the lesser is my grace.

    Happy is Hermia, wheresoe'er she lies,
    For she hath blessed and attractive eyes.

  LYSANDER.

    Things growing are not ripe until their season;
    So I, being young, till now ripe not to reason;
    And touching now the point of human skill,
    Reason becomes the marshal to my will,
    And leads me to your eyes, where I o'erlook  
    Love's stories, written in Love's richest book.
 Wherefore was I to this keen mockery born?
    When at your hands did I deserve this scorn?
    Is't not enough, is't not enough, young man,
    That I did never, no, nor never can,
    Deserve a sweet look from Demetrius' eye,
    But you must flout my insufficiency?
    Good troth, you do me wrong, good sooth, you do,
    In such disdainful manner me to woo.

    Ay me, for pity! What a dream was here!
    Lysander, look how I do quake with fear.
 TITANIA lying asleep

Enter QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING

  BOTTOM.

  BOTTOM.
 I believe we must leave the killing out, when all is
    done.

  BOTTOM.
 Write me a
    prologue; and let the prologue seem to say we will do no harm
    with our swords, and that Pyramus is not kill'd indeed; and for  
    the more better assurance, tell them that I Pyramus am not
    Pyramus but Bottom the weaver.

  BOTTOM.

  SNOUT.
 Therefore another prologue must tell he is not a lion.

  BOTTOM.
  
  QUINCE.
 But there is two hard things- that
    is, to bring the moonlight into a chamber; for, you know, Pyramus
    and Thisby meet by moonlight.
 Doth the moon shine that night we play our play?
  BOTTOM.

  QUINCE.

  SNOUT.
 You can never bring in a wall.
 Pyramus, you begin; when
    you have spoken your speech, enter into that brake; and so every
    one according to his cue.
 Speak, Pyramus.

  FLUTE.
 Most radiant Pyramus, most lily-white of hue,
    Of colour like the red rose on triumphant brier,
    Most brisky juvenal, and eke most lovely Jew,
    As true as truest horse, that would never tire,
    I'll meet thee, Pyramus, at Ninny's tomb.
 Pyramus enter: your cue is past; it is 'never tire.
 O- As true as truest horse, that y et would never tire.
 If I were fair, Thisby, I were only thine.


                          Re-enter SNOUT

  SNOUT.
 What do you see? You see an ass-head of your own, do you?
                                                      Exit SNOUT

                          Re-enter QUINCE

  QUINCE.

 Exit
  BOTTOM.
 I see their knavery: this is to make an ass of me; to
    fright me, if they could.
                     [Sings]

          The ousel cock, so black of hue,
            With orange-tawny bill,
          The throstle with his note so true,
            The wren with little quill.
 Thou art as wise as thou art beautiful.

  BOTTOM.

  COBWEB.

  MOTH.
 And I.
 And I.
 Where shall we go?
  TITANIA.

    Nod to him, elves, and do him courtesies.
 Hail!
  BOTTOM.
 Cobweb.

  BOTTOM.

Another part of the wood

Enter OBERON

  OBERON.
 How now, mad spirit!
    What night-rule now about this haunted grove?
  PUCK.
 Would he have stolen away
    From sleeping Hermia? I'll believe as soon  
    This whole earth may be bor'd, and that the moon
    May through the centre creep and so displease
    Her brother's noontide with th' Antipodes.
 So should the murdered look; and so should I,
    Pierc'd through the heart with your stern cruelty;
    Yet you, the murderer, look as bright, as clear,
    As yonder Venus in her glimmering sphere.
 A privilege never to see me more.

  PUCK.
 About the wood go swifter than the wind,
    And Helena of Athens look thou find;
    All fancy-sick she is and pale of cheer,
    With sighs of love that costs the fresh blood dear.

  PUCK.
 The noise they make
                Will cause Demetrius to awake.

    How can these things in me seem scorn to you,  
    Bearing the badge of faith, to prove them true?
  HELENA.
 I hod no judgment when to her I swore.
 Helen, it is not so.


                       Enter HERMIA

  HERMIA.
 Why should he stay whom love doth press to go?
  HERMIA.
 What love could press Lysander from my side?
  LYSANDER.

    Why seek'st thou me? Could not this make thee know
    The hate I bare thee made me leave thee so?
  HERMIA.

  HELENA.
 Have you not set Lysander, as in scorn,  
    To follow me and praise my eyes and face?
    And made your other love, Demetrius,
    Who even but now did spurn me with his foot,
    To call me goddess, nymph, divine, and rare,
    Precious, celestial? Wherefore speaks he this
    To her he hates? And wherefore doth Lysander
    Deny your love, so rich within his soul,
    And tender me, forsooth, affection,
    But by your setting on, by your consent?
    What though I be not so in grace as you,
    So hung upon with love, so fortunate,
    But miserable most, to love unlov'd?
    This you should pity rather than despise.
 O excellent!
  HERMIA.

  DEMETRIUS.

  LYSANDER.
 If thou say so, withdraw, and prove it too.
 Quick, come.
 Away, you Ethiope!
  DEMETRIUS.
 Why are you grown so rude? What change is this,
    Sweet love?
  LYSANDER.
 Yes, sooth; and so do you.

  HERMIA.

    Since night you lov'd me; yet since night you left me.

  HERMIA.

    How low am I? I am not yet so low
    But that my nails can reach unto thine eyes.

  HELENA.

  HERMIA.
 Why, get you gone! Who is't that hinders you?
  HELENA.

  LYSANDER.
 Be not afraid; she shall not harm thee, Helena.

  DEMETRIUS.
 No, sir, she shall not, though you take her part.

  HERMIA.

  DEMETRIUS.

  DEMETRIUS.

    Your hands than mine are quicker for a fray;
    My legs are longer though, to run away.
                 Exit
  HERMIA.
 Damned spirits all
    That in cross-ways and floods have burial,
    Already to their wormy beds are gone,
    For fear lest day should look their shames upon;
    They wilfully themselves exil'd from light,
    And must for aye consort with black-brow'd night.
 Where art thou?
  LYSANDER.
 He goes before me, and still dares me on;
    When I come where he calls, then he is gone.

    The villain is much lighter heel'd than I.
 [Lies down] Come, thou gentle day.
 Come hither; I am here.

  DEMETRIUS.
              [Sleeps]
  PUCK.
  
    Here will I rest me till the break of day.

    Heavens shield Lysander, if they mean a fray!
                                          [Lies down and sleeps]
  PUCK.
 LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA, lying asleep

Enter TITANIA and Bottom; PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED,
and other FAIRIES attending;
                      OBERON behind, unseen

  TITANIA.
 Come, sit thee down upon this flow'ry bed,
    While I thy amiable cheeks do coy,
    And stick musk-roses in thy sleek smooth head,
    And kiss thy fair large ears, my gentle joy.
 Where's Peaseblossom?
  PEASEBLOSSOM.
 Scratch my head, Peaseblossom.
 Mounsieur Cobweb; good mounsieur, get you your weapons in
    your hand and kill me a red-hipp'd humble-bee on the top of a
    thistle; and, good mounsieur, bring me the honey-bag.
 I must to the barber's, mounsieur; for methinks I am
    marvellous hairy about the face; and I am such a tender ass, if
    my hair do but tickle me I must scratch.
 What, wilt thou hear some music, my sweet love?
  BOTTOM.
 Methinks I have a great desire to a bottle of hay.

  TITANIA.
 [Advancing] Welcome, good Robin.

    And now I have the boy, I will undo
    This hateful imperfection of her eyes.

  TITANIA.

  OBERON.
 Robin, take off this head.
 Music, ho, music, such as charmeth sleep!
  PUCK.

  PUCK.
           Exeunt

        To the winding of horns, enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA,
                      EGEUS, and train

  THESEUS.

    Dispatch, I say, and find the forester.
 My lord, this is my daughter here asleep,
    And this Lysander, this Demetrius is,
    This Helena, old Nedar's Helena.
 No doubt they rose up early to observe
    The rite of May; and, hearing our intent,
    Came here in grace of our solemnity.

    But speak, Egeus; is not this the day
    That Hermia should give answer of her choice?
  EGEUS.
 It is, my lord.
 Go, bid the huntsmen wake them with their horns.
 Pardon, my lord.
 I pray you all, stand up.

    I know you two are rival enemies;
    How comes this gentle concord in the world  
    That hatred is so far from jealousy
    To sleep by hate, and fear no enmity?
  LYSANDER.
 Our intent
    Was to be gone from Athens, where we might,
    Without the peril of the Athenian law-
  EGEUS.
 Enough, enough, my Lord; you have enough;
    I beg the law, the law upon his head.
  
    But, my good lord, I wot not by what power-
    But by some power it is- my love to Hermia,
    Melted as the snow, seems to me now
    As the remembrance of an idle gaud
    Which in my childhood I did dote upon;
    And all the faith, the virtue of my heart,
    The object and the pleasure of mine eye,
    Is only Helena.
  
    Away with us to Athens, three and three;
    We'll hold a feast in great solemnity.

                     Exeunt THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train
  DEMETRIUS.

  HERMIA.

  DEMETRIUS.
 Do not you think
    The Duke was here, and bid us follow him?
  HERMIA.
 Yea, and my father.

  HELENA.
 And he did bid us follow to the temple.
 [Awaking] When my cue comes, call me, and I will answer.

    Peradventure, to make it the more gracious, I shall sing it at
    her death.
 QUINCE'S house

Enter QUINCE, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING

  QUINCE.
 He cannot be heard of.
 You have not a man in all Athens able
    to discharge Pyramus but he.
 O sweet bully Bottom! Thus hath he lost sixpence a day
    during his life; he could not have scaped sixpence a day.
 An the
    Duke had not given him sixpence a day for playing Pyramus, I'll
    be hanged.
 Not a word of me.
 SCENE I.

Athens.


          Enter LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HERMIA, and HELENA

  THESEUS.
 Come now; what masques, what dances shall we have,  
    To wear away this long age of three hours
    Between our after-supper and bed-time?
    Where is our usual manager of mirth?
    What revels are in hand? Is there no play
    To ease the anguish of a torturing hour?
    Call Philostrate.

  PHILOSTRATE.

                                                [Giving a paper]
  THESEUS.
'
    We'll none of that: that have I told my love,
    In glory of my kinsman Hercules.

    'The riot of the tipsy Bacchanals,
    Tearing the Thracian singer in their rage.
'
    That is some satire, keen and critical,
    Not sorting with a nuptial ceremony.
 Hard-handed men that work in Athens here,
    Which never labour'd in their minds till now;
    And now have toil'd their unbreathed memories
    With this same play against your nuptial.

  THESEUS.

  THESEUS.

    Go, bring them in; and take your places, ladies.
 Why, gentle sweet, you shall see no such thing.
 He says they can do nothing in this kind.

    Where I have come, great clerks have purposed
    To greet me with premeditated welcomes;
    Where I have seen them shiver and look pale,
    Make periods in the midst of sentences,
    Throttle their practis'd accent in their fears,
    And, in conclusion, dumbly have broke off,
    Not paying me a welcome.


                       Re-enter PHILOSTRATE  

  PHILOSTRATE.
              [Flourish of trumpets]

                 Enter QUINCE as the PROLOGUE

  PROLOGUE.
 That you should here repent you,
    The actors are at band; and, by their show,
    You shall know all, that you are like to know,
  THESEUS.
 His speech was like a tangled chain; nothing im paired,
    but all disordered.
 In this same interlude it doth befall
    That I, one Snout by name, present a wall;
    And such a wall as I would have you think  
    That had in it a crannied hole or chink,
    Through which the lovers, Pyramus and Thisby,
    Did whisper often very secretly.

  THESEUS.


                       Enter PYRAMUS

  THESEUS.
 No, in truth, sir, he should not.
 She is to enter now, and I am to spy her through the wall.

  THISBY.

  PYRAMUS.

  THISBY.
 Wilt thou at Ninny's tomb meet me straightway?
  THISBY.
 Thus have I, Wall, my part discharged so;
    And, being done, thus Wall away doth go.
 No remedy, my lord, when walls are so wilful to hear
    without warning.

  HIPPOLYTA.

  THESEUS.

  DEMETRIUS.
 True; and a goose for his discretion.

  MOONSHINE.
 I am aweary of this moon.

  MOON.

  THESEUS.
 Beshrew my heart, but I pity the man.

  LYSANDER.

  THESEUS.
 Methinks she should not use a long one for such a
    Pyramus; I hope she will be brief.
 A mote will turn the balance, which Pyramus, which
    Thisby, is the better- he for a man, God warrant us: She for a
    woman, God bless us!
  LYSANDER.
 [Starting up] No, I assure you; the wall is down that
    parted their fathers.
 But
    come, your Bergomask; let your epilogue alone.

    This palpable-gross play hath well beguil'd
    The heavy gait of night.

             Now the wasted brands do glow,
             Whilst the screech-owl, screeching loud,
             Puts the wretch that lies in woe
             In remembrance of a shroud.

             Now it is the time of night
             That the graves, all gaping wide,
             Every one lets forth his sprite,
             In the church-way paths to glide.
      First, rehearse your song by rote,
                To each word a warbling note;
                Hand in hand, with fairy grace,
                Will we sing, and bless this place.
    Now, until the break of day,
             Through this house each fairy stray.
    Exeunt all but PUCK
  PUCK.
      If we shadows have offended,
             Think but this, and all is mended,
             That you have but slumb'red here
             While these visions did appear.
>>





1599


MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING


by William Shakespeare



Dramatis Personae

  Don Pedro, Prince of Arragon.

  Don John, his bastard brother.

  Conrade, follower of Don John.


  Hero, daughter to Leonato.
  




<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
 Scene I.


  Leon.

  Mess.
 A kind overflow of kindness.
 I know none of that name, lady.
 O, he's return'd, and as pleasant as ever he was.
 I pray
    you, how many hath he kill'd and eaten in these wars? But how
    many hath he kill'd? For indeed I promised to eat all of his
    killing.

  Mess.

  Beat.
 A lord to a lord, a man to a man; stuff'd with all honourable
    virtues.

  Beat.
 You must not, sir, mistake my niece.

  Beat.
 O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease! He is sooner
    caught than the pestilence, and the taker runs presently mad.
 Do, good friend.
 Don Pedro is approach'd.

  Leon.

  Bene.

  Bene.

  Bene.
 A dear happiness to women! They would else have been troubled
    with a pernicious suitor.

  Bene.

  Bene.

  Leon.
 No.
 Why, i' faith, methinks she's too low for a high praise,
    too brown for a fair praise, and too little for a great praise.
 But I hope you have no intent to turn husband, have
    you?
  Claud.
 Is't come to this? In faith, hath not the world one man but
    he will wear his cap with suspicion? Shall I never see a
    bachelor of threescore again? Go to, i' faith! An thou wilt needs  
    thrust thy neck into a yoke, wear the print of it and sigh away
    Sundays.

  Pedro.
 With who? Now that is your Grace's
    part.
 By my troth, I speak my thought.

  Bene.

  Pedro.

  Claud.
 And never could maintain his part but in the force of his
    will.
 With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord; not with
    love.

  Pedro.
 From my house--if I had it--
  Pedro.
 Your loving friend, Benedick.

  Bene.
 The body of your discourse is
    sometime guarded with fragments, and the guards are but slightly
    basted on neither.
 My liege, your Highness now may do me good.
 My love is thine to teach.

  Claud.
 Wast not to this end
    That thou began'st to twist so fine a story?
  Claud.

    I will assume thy part in some disguise
    And tell fair Hero I am Claudio,
    And in her bosom I'll unclasp my heart
    And take her hearing prisoner with the force
    And strong encounter of my amorous tale.

  Leon.
 We will hold it as a dream till it appear itself; but  
    I will acquaint my daughter withal, that she may be the better
    prepared for an answer, if peradventure this be true.
 What the goodyear, my lord! Why are you thus out of measure
    sad?
  John.
 I wonder that thou (being, as thou say'st thou art, born
    under Saturn) goest about to apply a moral medicine to a
    mortifying mischief.
 I cannot hide what I am: I must be sad when
    I have cause, and smile at no man's jests; eat when I have
    stomach, and wait for no man's leisure; sleep when I am drowsy,
    and tend on no man's business; laugh when I am merry, and claw no
    man in his humour.
 You have of late stood out against
    your brother, and he hath ta'en you newly into his grace, where  
    it is impossible you should take true root but by the fair
    weather that you make yourself.
 I came yonder from a great supper.
 A very forward March-chick! How came you to this?
  Bora.
 I whipt me behind the arras and there heard it agreed
    upon that the Prince should woo Hero for himself, and having
    obtain'd her, give her to Count Claudio.
 This may prove food to my
    displeasure.
 Let us to the great supper.





<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.

  Beat.

  Hero.
 He were an excellent man that were made just in the midway
    between him and Benedick.
 Then half Signior Benedick's tongue in Count John's mouth,
    and half Count John's melancholy in Signior Benedick's face--
  Beat.

  Leon.
 In faith, she's too curst.

  Beat.
 I shall lessen God's sending
    that way, for it is said, 'God sends a curst cow short horns,'
    but to a cow too curst he sends none.
 You may light on a husband that hath no beard.
 Therefore I will even take sixpence in
    earnest of the berrord and lead his apes into hell.
 Well then, go you into hell?
  Beat.
' So  
    deliver I up my apes, and away to Saint Peter--for the heavens.
 [to Hero] Well, niece, I trust you will be rul'd by your
    father.

  Beat.
'
  Leon.

  Beat.

  Beat.
 With me in your company?  
  Hero.
 I may say so when I please.
 When I like your favour, for God defend the lute should be
    like the case!
  Pedro.

  Hero.
 Speak low if you speak love.
         [Takes her aside.
 So would not I for your own sake, for I have many ill
    qualities.
 I love you the better.
 God match me with a good dancer!
  Balth.
 Amen.
 I know you by the waggling of your head.

  Ant.
 Here's his dry hand up and down.

  Urs.
]
  Beat.

  Beat.
 Nor will you not tell me who you are?
  Bene.

  Beat.
 I pray you, what is he?
  Beat.

    I would he had boarded me.
]
    We must follow the leaders.
 Exeunt (all but Don John, Borachio, and Claudio].

  John.
 Sure my brother is amorous on Hero and hath withdrawn her
    father to break with him about it.
 The ladies follow her and but  
    one visor remains.
 And that is Claudio.
 I know him by his bearing.
 I am he.

  John.
 So did I too, and he swore he would marry her tonight.
 Thus answer I in name of Benedick
    But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.
 Yea, the same.
 Come, will you go with me?
  Claud.
 Even to the next willow, about your own business, County.
 Why, that's spoken like an honest drovier.
 But did you think the Prince would have served you
    thus?
  Claud.
 Yea, but so I am apt to do myself wrong.
 It is the base (though bitter) disposition of Beatrice
    that puts the world into her person and so gives me out.

  Pedro.
 I will but teach them to sing and restore them to the owner.


           Enter Claudio and Beatrice, Leonato, Hero.

  Bene.
]
  Pedro.

  Beat.

  Beat.
 I have brought Count Claudio, whom you sent
    me to seek.
 Neither, my lord.

  Pedro.
 Here, Claudio, I
    have wooed in thy name, and fair Hero is won.
 Name the day of marriage,
    and God give thee joy!
  Leon.
 Count, take of me my daughter, and with her my fortunes.
 Speak, cousin; or, if you cannot, stop his mouth with a kiss
    and let not him speak neither.
 Hath your
    Grace ne'er a brother like you? Your father got excellent
    husbands, if a maid could come by them.

  Pedro.

  Pedro.
 Come, you shake the head at so long a breathing;
    but I warrant thee, Claudio, the time shall not go dully by us.

    I will in the interim undertake one of Hercules' labours, which
    is, to bring Signior Benedick and the Lady Beatrice into a
    mountain of affection th' one with th' other.

  Leon.
 My lord, I am for you, though it cost me ten nights'
    watchings.
 And I, my lord.
 I will do any modest office, my lord, to help my cousin to a
    good husband.
 I will teach you how to humour
    your cousin, that she shall fall in love with Benedick; and I,
    [to Leonato and Claudio] with your two helps, will so practise on
    Benedick that, in despite of his quick wit and his queasy
    stomach, he shall fall in love with Beatrice.

                                                         Exeunt.





Scene II.


Enter [Don] John and Borachio.
 The Count Claudio shall marry the daughter of
    Leonato.

  John.
 Not honestly, my lord, but so covertly that no dishonesty
    shall appear in me.
 Show me briefly how.
 The poison of that lies in you to temper.
 Only to despite them I will endeavour anything.

  Bora.
 Go then; find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and the Count
    Claudio alone; tell them that you know that Hero loves me; intend
    a kind of zeal both to the Prince and Claudio, as--in love of
    your brother's honour, who hath made this match, and his friend's
    reputation, who is thus like to be cozen'd with the semblance of
    a maid--that you have discover'd thus.
 Offer them instances; which shall bear no
    less likelihood than to see me at her chamber window, hear me
    call Margaret Hero, hear Margaret term me Claudio; and bring them
    to see this the very night before the intended wedding (for in
    the meantime I will so fashion the matter that Hero shall be
    absent) and there shall appear such seeming truth of Hero's  
    disloyalty that jealousy shall be call'd assurance and all the
    preparation overthrown.
 Grow this to what adverse issue it can, I will put it in
    practice.





Scene III.
 In my chamber window lies a book.
 Bring it hither to me in
    the orchard.
 He was wont to speak plain
    and to the purpose, like an honest man and a soldier; and now is
    he turn'd orthography; his words are a very fantastical banquet--
    just so many strange dishes.
 One woman is fair, yet I am well; another is wise, yet I am
    well; another virtuous, yet I am well; but till all graces be in
    one woman, one woman shall not come in my grace.

  Pedro.

  Pedro.


        Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more!
          Men were deceivers ever,
        One foot in sea, and one on shore;
          To one thing constant never.


        Sing no more ditties, sing no moe,
          Of dumps so dull and heavy!
        The fraud of men was ever so,
          Since summer first was leavy.

            Then sigh not so, &c.
 No, nor I neither; but most wonderful that she should so dote
    on Signior Benedick, whom she hath in all outward behaviours
    seem'd ever to abhor.
 It is past the
    infinite of thought.

  Pedro.

  Claud.

  Leon.
  
  Claud.
 [aside] I should think this a gull but that the white-bearded
    fellow speaks it.
 [aside] He hath ta'en th' infection.
 That's her torment.
 This says she now when she is beginning to write to him; for
    she'll be up twenty times a night, and there will she sit in her
    smock till she have writ a sheet of paper.
 Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a pretty jest
    your daughter told us of.
 O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence, rail'd at
    herself that she should be so immodest to write to one that she
    knew would flout her.
'
  Claud.
 O, my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender a body,
    we have ten proofs to one that blood hath the victory.
 I would have
    daff'd all other respects and made her half myself.
 Were it good, think you?
  Claud.
 She doth well.

  Pedro.
  
  Claud.
 And I take him to be valiant.
 Let her wear it out with good
    counsel.
 I love Benedick well, and I could wish he would
    modestly examine himself to see how much he is unworthy so good a
    lady.
 If he dote on her upon this, I will never trust my
    expectation.

    That's the scene that I would see, which will be merely a dumb
    show.


                [Benedick advances from the arbour.
 This can be no trick.

    It seems her affections have their full bent.
 Happy are they that
    hear their detractions and can put them to mending.


                 Enter Beatrice.

  Bene.

  Beat.
 You take pleasure then in the message?  
  Beat.
 Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knives point, and
    choke a daw withal.
 Fare you well.
 I will go get her picture.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
