    in all shapes that man goes up and down in from fourscore to
    thirteen, this spirit walks in.

  VARRO'S SERVANT.
 Thou art not altogether a fool.

                                                 Exeunt SERVANTS
  TIMON.
 Go to;
    Perchance some single vantages you took
    When my indisposition put you back,
    And that unaptness made your minister
    Thus to excuse yourself.
 Let all my land be sold.
 To Lacedaemon did my land extend.
 You tell me true.
 So the gods bless me,
    When all our offices have been oppress'd
    With riotous feeders, when our vaults have wept
    With drunken spilth of wine, when every room
    Hath blaz'd with lights and bray'd with minstrelsy,
    I have retir'd me to a wasteful cock
    And set mine eyes at flow.
 Prithee no more.

  TIMON.
 Is't true? Can't be?
  FLAVIUS.

    Their blood is cak'd, 'tis cold, it seldom flows;
    'Tis lack of kindly warmth they are not kind;
    And nature, as it grows again toward earth,
    Is fashion'd for the journey dull and heavy.

  FLAVIUS.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.
 Why,
    this hits right; I dreamt of a silver basin and ewer to-night-
    Flaminius, honest Flaminius, you are very respectively welcome,
    sir.
 [Exit SERVANT] And how does that
    honourable, complete, freehearted gentleman of Athens, thy very
    bountiful good lord and master?
  FLAMINIUS.
 I am right glad that his health is well, sir.
 And what
    hast thou there under thy cloak, pretty Flaminius?
  FLAMINIUS.
 Every man has his fault, and honesty is his.
 I ha'
    told him on't, but I could ne'er get him from't.


                    Re-enter SERVANT, with wine

  SERVANT.
 Please your lordship, here is the wine.

A public place

Enter Lucius, with three STRANGERS

  LUCIUS.
 Who, the Lord Timon? He is my very good friend, and an
    honourable gentleman.
 How?
  SECOND STRANGER.


                             Enter SERVILIUS

  SERVILIUS.
- My honour'd lord!
  LUCIUS.
 But in the mean time he wants less, my lord.

  LUCIUS.

  LUCIUS.

                                                  Exit SERVILIUS  
    True, as you said, Timon is shrunk indeed;
    And he that's once denied will hardly speed.
 Do you observe this, Hostilius?
  SECOND STRANGER.
 Ay, too well.

  FIRST STRANGER.
 Why, this is the world's soul; and just of the same
      piece
    Is every flatterer's spirit.

    And does he think so backwardly of me now
    That I'll requite it last? No;
    So it may prove an argument of laughter
    To th' rest, and I 'mongst lords be thought a fool.
 Excellent! Your lordship's a goodly villain.
 The devil
    knew not what he did when he made man politic- he cross'd himself
    by't; and I cannot think but, in the end, the villainies of man
    will set him clear.

    Of such a nature is his politic love.
 Now his friends are dead,  
    Doors that were ne'er acquainted with their wards
    Many a bounteous year must be employ'd
    Now to guard sure their master.

  TITUS.


                          Enter PHILOTUS

  LUCIUS' SERVANT.
 Labouring for nine.
 I wonder on't; he was wont to shine at seven.

  PHILOTUS.

  TITUS.
  
  HORTENSIUS.


                           Enter FLAMINIUS

  TITUS.
 No, indeed, he is not.
 I need not tell him that; he knows you are to diligent.

  TITUS.
 How! What does his cashier'd worship mutter?
  SECOND VARRO'S SERVANT.
 O, here's Servilius; now we shall know some answer.
 If I might beseech you, gentlemen, to repair some other
    hour, I should derive much from't; for take't of my soul, my lord
    leans wondrously to discontent.
 His comfortable temper has
    forsook him; he's much out of health and keeps his chamber.

  LUCIUS' SERVANT.
 [Within] Servilius, help! My lord! my lord!

           Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following

  TIMON.

  LUCIUS' SERVANT.

  PHILOTUS.
 Knock me down with 'em; cleave me to the girdle.
 Mine, fifty talents.
 What yours? and yours?
  FIRST VARRO'S SERVANT.
 My lord-
  SECOND VARRO'S SERVANT.
 Tear me, take me, and the gods fall upon you!      Exit
  HORTENSIUS.
 Here, my lord.

    I'll once more feast the rascals.

  FLAVIUS.
 O my lord,
    You only speak from your distracted soul;
    There is not so much left to furnish out
    A moderate table.

The Senate House

Enter three SENATORS at one door, ALCIBIADES meeting them, with attendants

  FIRST SENATOR.
 Most true; the law shall bruise him.
 I am an humble suitor to your virtues;
    For pity is the virtue of the law,
    And none but tyrants use it cruelly.
 My lords, then, under favour, pardon me
    If I speak like a captain:
    Why do fond men expose themselves to battle,
    And not endure all threats? Sleep upon't,
    And let the foes quietly cut their throats,
    Without repugnancy? If there be
    Such valour in the bearing, what make we
    Abroad? Why, then, women are more valiant,
    That stay at home, if bearing carry it;
    And the ass more captain than the lion; the fellow
    Loaden with irons wiser than the judge,
    If wisdom be in suffering.

    Who cannot condemn rashness in cold blood?
    To kill, I grant, is sin's extremest gust;  
    But, in defence, by mercy, 'tis most just.

    To be in anger is impiety;
    But who is man that is not angry?
    Weigh but the crime with this.

  ALCIBIADES.
 In vain! His service done
    At Lacedaemon and Byzantium
    Were a sufficient briber for his life.

  FIRST SENATOR.

    If there were no foes, that were enough
    To overcome him.
 Hard fate! He might have died in war.
 Urge it no more
    On height of our displeasure.

    'Tis honour with most lands to be at odds;
    Soldiers should brook as little wrongs as gods.
 Enter divers LORDS,
friends of TIMON, at several doors

  FIRST LORD.
 I also wish it to you.

  FIRST LORD.

  SECOND LORD.
 I am sorry, when he
    sent to borrow of me, that my provision was out.
 What of you?
  SECOND LORD.


                   Enter TIMON and attendants

  TIMON.
 With all my heart, gentlemen both! And how fare you?
  FIRST LORD.

  TIMON.
 O sir, let it not trouble you.
  
  SECOND LORD.
 Ah, my good friend, what cheer?
  SECOND LORD.
 [The banquet
    brought in] Come, bring in all together.
 Royal cheer, I warrant you.

  THIRD LORD.
 Alcibiades banish'd!
  THIRD LORD.
 This is the old man still.
 Lend to each man enough,
    that one need not lend to another; for were your god-heads to
    borrow of men, men would forsake the gods.
 Make the meat be
    beloved more than the man that gives it.
 If there sit twelve women
    at the table, let a dozen of them be- as they are.


    Uncover, dogs, and lap.
        [The dishes are uncovered and
                                  seen to he full of warm water]
  SOME SPEAK.

  TIMON.
 This is Timon's last;
    Who, stuck and spangled with your flatteries,
    Washes it off, and sprinkles in your faces
                             [Throwing the water in their faces]
    Your reeking villainy.

    Stay, I will lend thee money, borrow none.
 Push! Did you see my cap?
  FOURTH LORD.
 I have lost my gown.

  FIRST LORD.
 Did you see my cap?
  SECOND LORD.
 Here 'tis.
 Let's make no stay.
 Lord Timon's mad.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
 Bound servants, steal:
    Large-handed robbers your grave masters are,
    And pill by law.
 Piety and fear,
    Religion to the gods, peace, justice, truth,
    Domestic awe, night-rest, and neighbourhood,  
    Instruction, manners, mysteries, and trades,
    Degrees, observances, customs and laws,
    Decline to your confounding contraries
    And let confusion live.
                                                   Exit




SCENE II.

Athens.
 More of our fellows.

  THIRD SERVANT.
' Let each take some.
 Not one word more!
    Thus part we rich in sorrow, parting poor.
 Alas, kind lord!
    He's flung in rage from this ingrateful seat
    Of monstrous friends; nor has he with him to
    Supply his life, or that which can command it.
          Exit




SCENE III.
 Before TIMON'S cave

Enter TIMON in the woods

  TIMON.
 Not nature,
    To whom all sores lay siege, can bear great fortune
    But by contempt of nature.
 The learned pate  
    Ducks to the golden fool.

                                                       [Digging]
    Who seeks for better of thee, sauce his palate
    With thy most operant poison.
 A beast, as thou art.

  ALCIBIADES.
 Follow thy drum;
    With man's blood paint the ground, gules, gules.

    Religious canons, civil laws, are cruel;
    Then what should war be? This fell whore of thine
    Hath in her more destruction than thy sword
    For all her cherubin look.
 I will not kiss thee; then the rot returns
    To thine own lips again.
 How came the noble Timon to this change?
  TIMON.

    But then renew I could not, like the moon;
    There were no suns to borrow of.
 None, but to
    Maintain my opinion.
 What is it, Timon?
  TIMON.
 If thou wilt not
    promise, the gods plague thee, for thou art man! If thou dost
    perform, confound thee, for thou art a man!
  ALCIBIADES.
 I have heard in some sort of thy miseries.

  TIMON.
 As thine is now, held with a brace of harlots.
 Yes.
 Season the slaves
    For tubs and baths; bring down rose-cheek'd youth  
    To the tub-fast and the diet.

  TIMON.
 How dost thou pity him whom thou dost trouble?
    I had rather be alone.

  TIMON.

  ALCIBIADES.
 War'st thou 'gainst Athens?
  ALCIBIADES.

  TIMON.
 Dost thou, or dost thou not, heaven's curse upon thee!
  PHRYNIA AND TIMANDRA.
 Enough to make a whore forswear her trade,
    And to make whores a bawd.
 Be whores still;
    And he whose pious breath seeks to convert you-  
    Be strong in whore, allure him, burn him up;
    Let your close fire predominate his smoke,
    And be no turncoats.
 Hoar the flamen,
    That scolds against the quality of flesh
    And not believes himself.
 Farewell, Timon;
    If I thrive well, I'll visit thee again.

  ALCIBIADES.
 Yes, thou spok'st well of me.
 Men daily find it.
 Get thee away, and take
    Thy beagles with thee.
 I was directed hither.
 Men report
    Thou dost affect my manners and dost use them.
 Thou wast told thus;
    Thou gav'st thine ears, like tapsters that bade welcome,
    To knaves and all approachers.

    O, thou shalt find-
  TIMON.
  
  APEMANTUS.

  TIMON.
 Why dost thou seek me out?
  APEMANTUS.
 What, a knave too?
  APEMANTUS.
 If thou didst put this sour-cold habit on
    To castigate thy pride, 'twere well; but thou
    Dost it enforcedly.
  
    Thy nature did commence in sufferance; time
    Hath made thee hard in't.

    If thou hadst not been born the worst of men,
    Thou hadst been a knave and flatterer.
 Art thou proud yet?
  TIMON.

  APEMANTUS.
 If thou wilt,
    Tell them there I have gold; look, so I have.
 Where my stomach.
 Would poison were obedient, and knew my mind!
  APEMANTUS.
 On what I hate I feed not.
 What man didst thou ever know unthrift
    that was beloved after his means?
  TIMON.
 Who, without those means thou talk'st of, didst thou ever
    know belov'd?
  APEMANTUS.
 Myself.
 Give it the beasts, to be rid of the men.
 All thy safety
    were remotion, and thy defence absence.
 All villains that do stand by thee are pure.
 Away, thou issue of a mangy dog!
    Choler does kill me that thou art alive;
    I swoon to see thee.
 Beast!
  TIMON.
 Would 'twere so!
    But not till I am dead.
 More
    things like men? Eat, Timon, and abhor them.

  THIRD BANDIT.

  FIRST BANDIT.
 Save thee, Timon!
  TIMON.

  TIMON.

    Why should you want? Behold, the earth hath roots;
    Within this mile break forth a hundred springs;
    The oaks bear mast, the briars scarlet hips;
    The bounteous housewife Nature on each bush
    Lays her full mess before you.

  TIMON.
 Go, suck the subtle blood o' th' grape
    Till the high fever seethe your blood to froth,
    And so scape hanging.
 Take wealth and lives together;
    Do villainy, do, since you protest to do't,
    Like workmen.
 Love not yourselves; away,
    Rob one another.

  FIRST BANDIT.
 O you gods!
    Is yond despis'd and ruinous man my lord?
    Full of decay and failing? O monument
    And wonder of good deeds evilly bestow'd!
    What an alteration of honour
    Has desp'rate want made!
    What viler thing upon the earth than friends,
    Who can bring noblest minds to basest ends!
    How rarely does it meet with this time's guise,
    When man was wish'd to love his enemies!
    Grant I may ever love, and rather woo
    Those that would mischief me than those that do!
    Has caught me in his eye; I will present
    My honest grief unto him, and as my lord
    Still serve him with my life.
 Have you forgot me, sir?
  TIMON.

  FLAVIUS.

  FLAVIUS.
 I beg of you to know me, good my lord,
    T' accept my grief, and whilst this poor wealth lasts
    To entertain me as your steward still.
 Had I a steward
    So true, so just, and now so comfortable?
    It almost turns my dangerous nature mild.

    Let me behold thy face.

    Forgive my general and exceptless rashness,  
    You perpetual-sober gods! I do proclaim
    One honest man- mistake me not, but one;
    No more, I pray- and he's a steward.
 But all, save thee,
    I fell with curses.
 The gods, out of my misery,
    Have sent thee treasure.
 If thou hat'st curses,
    Stay not; fly whilst thou art blest and free.

                                                Exeunt severally




<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.

  POET.
 Nothing at this time but my visitation; only I will
    promise him an excellent piece.
 I must serve him so too, tell him of an intent that's coming
    toward him.

  POET.

  TIMON.
 He and myself
    Have travail'd in the great show'r of your gifts,
    And sweetly felt it.
 Ay, you are honest men.
 Th'art indeed the best;
    Thou counterfeit'st most lively.

  POET.
 Look you, I love you well; I'll give you gold,
    Rid me these villains from your companies.
 You that way, and you this- but two in company;
    Each man apart, all single and alone,
    Yet an arch-villain keeps him company.
 At all times alike
    Men are not still the same; 'twas time and griefs
    That fram'd him thus.
 Time, with his fairer hand,
    Offering the fortunes of his former days,  
    The former man may make him.

    Peace and content be here! Lord Timon! Timon!
    Look out, and speak to friends.
 Th' Athenians
    By two of their most reverend Senate greet thee.


                   Enter TIMON out of his cave

  TIMON.

  FIRST SENATOR.

  TIMON.
 But if he sack fair Athens,
    And take our goodly aged men by th' beards,
    Giving our holy virgins to the stain
    Of contumelious, beastly, mad-brain'd war,  
    Then let him know- and tell him Timon speaks it
    In pity of our aged and our youth-
    I cannot choose but tell him that I care not,
    And let him take't at worst; for their knives care not,
    While you have throats to answer.
 So I leave you
    To the protection of the prosperous gods,
    As thieves to keepers.

  TIMON.
 But yet I love my country, and am not
    One that rejoices in the common wreck,  
    As common bruit doth put it.

  TIMON.
 Commend me to them,
    And tell them that, to ease them of their griefs,
    Their fears of hostile strokes, their aches, losses,
    Their pangs of love, with other incident throes
    That nature's fragile vessel doth sustain
    In life's uncertain voyage, I will some kindness do them-
    I'll teach them to prevent wild Alcibiades' wrath.

  TIMON.

    Lips, let sour words go by and language end:
    What is amiss, plague and infection mend!
    Graves only be men's works and death their gain!
    Sun, hide thy beams.
 Our hope in him is dead.
 Let us return
    And strain what other means is left unto us
    In our dear peril.
 I have spoke the least.

    Who's here? Speak, ho! No answer? What is this?
    Timon is dead, who hath outstretch'd his span.

    Some beast rear'd this; here does not live a man.

    Dead, sure; and this his grave.
 What's on this tomb
    I cannot read; the character I'll take with wax.

    Our captain hath in every figure skill,
    An ag'd interpreter, though young in days;
    Before proud Athens he's set down by this,
    Whose fall the mark of his ambition is.


       Sound a parley.
 Now the time is flush,
    When crouching marrow, in the bearer strong,
    Cries of itself 'No more!' Now breathless wrong
    Shall sit and pant in your great chairs of ease,
    And pursy insolence shall break his wind
    With fear and horrid flight.

  FIRST SENATOR.
 These walls of ours
    Were not erected by their hands from whom
    You have receiv'd your griefs; nor are they such
    That these great tow'rs, trophies, and schools, should fall
    For private faults in them.
 Then there's my glove;
    Descend, and open your uncharged ports.

  BOTH.

  ALCIBIADES.
 Descend, and keep your words.

    Pass by, and curse thy fill; but pass, and stay not here thy
      gait.

    Let our drums strike.

    I am his first born son that was the last
    That ware the imperial diadem of Rome;
    Then let my father's honours live in me,
    Nor wrong mine age with this indignity.

    Open the gates and let me in.


        Sound drums and trumpets, and then enter MARTIUS
        and MUTIUS, two of TITUS' sons; and then two men
        bearing a coffin covered with black; then LUCIUS
        and QUINTUS, two other sons; then TITUS ANDRONICUS;
        and then TAMORA the Queen of Goths, with her three
        sons, ALARBUS, DEMETRIUS, and CHIRON, with AARON the
        Moor, and others,  as many as can be.
 Hail, Rome, victorious in thy mourning weeds!
    Lo, as the bark that hath discharg'd her fraught
    Returns with precious lading to the bay  
    From whence at first she weigh'd her anchorage,
    Cometh Andronicus, bound with laurel boughs,
    To re-salute his country with his tears,
    Tears of true joy for his return to Rome.
 Give us the proudest prisoner of the Goths,
    That we may hew his limbs, and on a pile
    Ad manes fratrum sacrifice his flesh
    Before this earthy prison of their bones,
    That so the shadows be not unappeas'd,
    Nor we disturb'd with prodigies on earth.

    Andronicus, stain not thy tomb with blood.

    Thrice-noble Titus, spare my first-born son.
 Patient yourself, madam, and pardon me.

    To this your son is mark'd, and die he must
    T' appease their groaning shadows that are gone.

    Alarbus goes to rest, and we survive
    To tremble under Titus' threat'ning look.
 See, lord and father, how we have perform'd
    Our Roman rites: Alarbus' limbs are lopp'd,
    And entrails feed the sacrificing fire,
    Whose smoke like incense doth perfume the sky.

    In peace and honour rest you here, my sons!

                       Enter LAVINIA

  LAVINIA.
 In peace and honour live Lord Titus long;
    My noble lord and father, live in fame!
    Lo, at this tomb my tributary tears
    I render for my brethren's obsequies;
    And at thy feet I kneel, with tears of joy
    Shed on this earth for thy return to Rome.
 Kind Rome, that hast thus lovingly reserv'd
    The cordial of mine age to glad my heart!
    Lavinia, live; outlive thy father's days,
    And fame's eternal date, for virtue's praise!

          Enter, above, MARCUS ANDRONICUS and TRIBUNES;
          re-enter SATURNINUS, BASSIANUS, and attendants

  MARCUS.
 And welcome, nephews, from successful wars,
    You that survive and you that sleep in fame.

    Fair lords, your fortunes are alike in all
    That in your country's service drew your swords;
    But safer triumph is this funeral pomp
    That hath aspir'd to Solon's happiness
    And triumphs over chance in honour's bed.
  
    Titus Andronicus, the people of Rome,
    Whose friend in justice thou hast ever been,
    Send thee by me, their Tribune and their trust,
    This par]iament of white and spotless hue;
    And name thee in election for the empire
    With these our late-deceased Emperor's sons:
    Be candidatus then, and put it on,
    And help to set a head on headless Rome.
 A better head her glorious body fits
    Than his that shakes for age and feebleness.

  MARCUS.
 Titus, thou shalt obtain and ask the empery.

  SATURNINUS.
 Proud Saturnine, interrupter of the good
    That noble-minded Titus means to thee!
  TITUS.
 Andronicus, I do not flatter thee,
    But honour thee, and will do till I die.

    Then, if you will elect by my advice,
    Crown him, and say 'Long live our Emperor!'
  MARCUS.

  SATURNINUS.
 Thanks, noble Titus, father of my life.

    How proud I am of thee and of thy gifts
    Rome shall record; and when I do forget
    The least of these unspeakable deserts,  
    Romans, forget your fealty to me.

  TITUS.

    Lavinia, you are not displeas'd with this?
  LAVINIA.

    Ransomless here we set our prisoners free.

    Proclaim our honours, lords, with trump and drum.
 Lord Titus, by your leave, this maid is mine.
 Ay, noble Titus, and resolv'd withal
    To do myself this reason and this right.
 Traitors, avaunt! Where is the Emperor's guard?
    Treason, my lord- Lavinia is surpris'd!
  SATURNINUS.
 By him that justly may
    Bear his betroth'd from all the world away.

  MUTIUS.
 During the fray, exeunt SATURNINUS,
                            TAMORA, DEMETRIUS, CHIRON, and AARON

                      Re-enter Lucius

  LUCIUS.

  TITUS.
  
    I'll trust by leisure him that mocks me once;
    Thee never, nor thy traitorous haughty sons,
    Confederates all thus to dishonour me.
 These words are razors to my wounded heart.
 Ascend, fair Queen, Pantheon.

  TITUS, when wert thou wont to walk alone,  
    Dishonoured thus, and challenged of wrongs?

                      Re-enter MARCUS,
        and TITUS' SONS, LUCIUS, QUINTUS, and MARTIUS

  MARCUS.
 But let us give him burial, as becomes;
    Give Mutius burial with our bretheren.
 My lord, this is impiety in you.
 And shall, or him we will accompany.

  TITUS.
 Not I, till Mutius' bones be buried.
 Father, and in that name doth nature speak-
  TITUS.
 Renowned Titus, more than half my soul-
  LUCIUS.
 Dear father, soul and substance of us all-  
  MARCUS.

  TITUS.
 Re-enter the EMPEROR, TAMORA
        and her two SONS, with the MOOR, at one door;
    at the other door, BASSIANUS and LAVINIA, with others

  SATURNINUS.
 And you of yours, my lord! I say no more,
    Nor wish no less; and so I take my leave.

  SATURNINUS.

    [Aside to SATURNINUS]  My lord, be rul'd by me,
      be won at last;
    Dissemble all your griefs and discontents.
  
    For you, Prince Bassianus, I have pass'd
    My word and promise to the Emperor
    That you will be more mild and tractable.

    By my advice, all humbled on your knees,
    You shall ask pardon of his Majesty.
 Marcus, for thy sake, and thy brother's here,
    And at my lovely Tamora's entreats,
    I do remit these young men's heinous faults.

    This day shall be a love-day, Tamora.
 Be it so, Titus, and gramercy too.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.

    As when the golden sun salutes the morn,
    And, having gilt the ocean with his beams,
    Gallops the zodiac in his glistening coach
    And overlooks the highest-peering hills,
    So Tamora.
  
    Away with slavish weeds and servile thoughts!
    I will be bright and shine in pearl and gold,
    To wait upon this new-made emperess.
 Chiron, thy years wants wit, thy wits wants edge
    And manners, to intrude where I am grac'd,
    And may, for aught thou knowest, affected be.

  AARON.
 Why, boy, although our mother, unadvis'd,
    Gave you a dancing rapier by your side,
    Are you so desperate grown to threat your friends?
    Go to; have your lath glued within your sheath
    Till you know better how to handle it.

  AARON.

  AARON.
 For shame, be friends, and join for that you jar.
 My lovely Aaron, wherefore look'st thou sad
    When everything does make a gleeful boast?
    The birds chant melody on every bush;
    The snakes lie rolled in the cheerful sun;  
    The green leaves quiver with the cooling wind
    And make a chequer'd shadow on the ground;
    Under their sweet shade, Aaron, let us sit,
    And while the babbling echo mocks the hounds,
    Replying shrilly to the well-tun'd horns,
    As if a double hunt were heard at once,
    Let us sit down and mark their yellowing noise;
    And- after conflict such as was suppos'd
    The wand'ring prince and Dido once enjoyed,
    When with a happy storm they were surpris'd,
    And curtain'd with a counsel-keeping cave-
    We may, each wreathed in the other's arms,
    Our pastimes done, possess a golden slumber,
    Whiles hounds and horns and sweet melodious birds
    Be unto us as is a nurse's song
    Of lullaby to bring her babe asleep.
 Madam, though Venus govern your desires,
    Saturn is dominator over mine.

    Vengeance is in my heart, death in my hand,
    Blood and revenge are hammering in my head.

    Now question me no more; we are espied.


                Enter BASSIANUS and LAVINIA
  
  TAMORA.
 Saucy controller of my private steps!
    Had I the pow'r that some say Dian had,
    Thy temples should be planted presently
    With horns, as was Actaeon's; and the hounds
    Should drive upon thy new-transformed limbs,
    Unmannerly intruder as thou art!
  LAVINIA.

    Jove shield your husband from his hounds to-day!  
    'Tis pity they should take him for a stag.
 The King my brother shall have notice of this.

  LAVINIA.
 How now, dear sovereign, and our gracious mother!
    Why doth your Highness look so pale and wan?
  TAMORA.

                                               [Stabs BASSIANUS]
  CHIRON.
 Give me the poniard; you shall know, my boys,
    Your mother's hand shall right your mother's wrong.
 Stay, madam, here is more belongs to her;
    First thrash the corn, then after burn the straw.

  TAMORA.
 But when ye have the honey we desire,
    Let not this wasp outlive, us both to sting.
 I warrant you, madam, we will make that sure.

    Yet have I heard- O, could I find it now!-
    The lion, mov'd with pity, did endure
    To have his princely paws par'd all away.

  TAMORA.
 Away! for thou hast stay'd us here too long.

  MARTIUS.

    Speak, brother, hast thou hurt thee with the fall?
  MARTIUS.
 Why dost not comfort me, and help me out
    From this unhallow'd and blood-stained hole?
  QUINTUS.

  QUINTUS.

  MARTIUS.

  QUINTUS.

    Thou canst not come to me- I come to thee.
 Along with me! I'll see what hole is here,
    And what he is that now is leapt into it.

    Say, who art thou that lately didst descend
    Into this gaping hollow of the earth?
  MARTIUS.
  
  SATURNINUS.
 My brother dead! I know thou dost but jest:
    He and his lady both are at the lodge
    Upon the north side of this pleasant chase;
    'Tis not an hour since I left them there.

  MARTIUS.
 We know not where you left them all alive;
    But, out alas! here have we found him dead.
 Where is thy brother Bassianus?
  SATURNINUS.

    Look, sirs, if you can find the huntsman out
    That should have murdered Bassianus here.

  TAMORA.
 If it be prov'd! You see it is apparent.
 Andronicus himself did take it up.
 I did, my lord, yet let me be their bail;
    For, by my fathers' reverend tomb, I vow
    They shall be ready at your Highness' will
    To answer their suspicion with their lives.

  SATURNINUS.

    Some bring the murdered body, some the murderers;
    Let them not speak a word- the guilt is plain;
    For, by my soul, were there worse end than death,
    That end upon them should be executed.

  TAMORA.

    Fear not thy sons; they shall do well enough.
     Exeunt




SCENE IV.

Another part of the forest

Enter the Empress' sons, DEMETRIUS and CHIRON, with LAVINIA,
her hands cut off, and her tongue cut out, and ravish'd

  DEMETRIUS.

  DEMETRIUS.

  CHIRON.
 Enter MARCUS, from hunting

  MARCUS.
 Who is this?- my niece, that flies away so fast?  
    Cousin, a word: where is your husband?
    If I do dream, would all my wealth would wake me!
    If I do wake, some planet strike me down,
    That I may slumber an eternal sleep!
    Speak, gentle niece.
  
    Come, let us go, and make thy father blind,
    For such a sight will blind a father's eye;
    One hour's storm will drown the fragrant meads,
    What will whole months of tears thy father's eyes?
    Do not draw back, for we will mourn with thee;
    O, could our mourning case thy misery!                Exeunt




<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.

Rome.

  LUCIUS.
 O noble father, you lament in vain;
    The Tribunes hear you not, no man is by,
    And you recount your sorrows to a stone.
  
  TITUS.
 My gracious lord, no tribune hears you speak.

                                                         [Rises]
    But wherefore stand'st thou with thy weapon drawn?  
  LUCIUS.
 Titus, prepare thy aged eyes to weep,
    Or if not so, thy noble heart to break.

  TITUS.
 This was thy daughter.
 Ay me! this object kills me.

    Give me a sword, I'll chop off my hands too,
    For they have fought for Rome, and all in vain;
    And they have nurs'd this woe in feeding life;
    In bootless prayer have they been held up,
    And they have serv'd me to effectless use.

    Now all the service I require of them
    Is that the one will help to cut the other.

  LUCIUS.
 O, say thou for her, who hath done this deed?
  MARCUS.
 It was my dear, and he that wounded her
    Hath hurt me more than had he kill'd me dead;
    For now I stand as one upon a rock,
    Environ'd with a wilderness of sea,
    Who marks the waxing tide grow wave by wave,
    Expecting ever when some envious surge
    Will in his brinish bowels swallow him.

  TITUS.
 Mark, Marcus, mark! I understand her signs.

    O, what a sympathy of woe is this
    As far from help as Limbo is from bliss!

                   Enter AARON the Moor

  AARON.
 O gracious Emperor! O gentle Aaron!
    Did ever raven sing so like a lark
    That gives sweet tidings of the sun's uprise?
    With all my heart I'll send the Emperor my hand.

    Good Aaron, wilt thou help to chop it off?  
  LUCIUS.
 My hand will serve the turn,
    My youth can better spare my blood than you,
    And therefore mine shall save my brothers' lives.
 By heaven, it shall not go!
  TITUS.

  TITUS.
 Then I'll go fetch an axe.

    [Aside]  Their heads I mean.
 O brother, speak with possibility,
    And do not break into these deep extremes.

  TITUS.

    When heaven doth weep, doth not the earth o'erflow?
    If the winds rage, doth not the sea wax mad,
    Threat'ning the welkin with his big-swol'n face?
    And wilt thou have a reason for this coil?
    I am the sea; hark how her sighs do blow.

    She is the weeping welkin, I the earth;
    Then must my sea be moved with her sighs;
    Then must my earth with her continual tears
    Become a deluge, overflow'd and drown'd;
    For why my bowels cannot hide her woes,
    But like a drunkard must I vomit them.
             Exit
  MARCUS.
 Come, brother, take a head,
    And in this hand the other will I bear.

    And, Lavinia, thou shalt be employ'd in this;
    Bear thou my hand, sweet wench, between thy teeth.
  
    Farewell, Lavinia, my noble sister;
    O, would thou wert as thou tofore hast been!
    But now nor Lucius nor Lavinia lives
    But in oblivion and hateful griefs.
 So so, now sit; and look you eat no more
    Than will preserve just so much strength in us
    As will revenge these bitter woes of ours.
 Hark, Marcus, what she says-
    I can interpret all her martyr'd signs;  
    She says she drinks no other drink but tears,
    Brew'd with her sorrow, mesh'd upon her cheeks.

  BOY.
 Alas, the tender boy, in passion mov'd,
    Doth weep to see his grandsire's heaviness.

  TITUS.

    Give me thy knife, I will insult on him,
    Flattering myself as if it were the Moor
    Come hither purposely to poison me.
 Come, take away.

Rome.

  BOY.

  MARCUS.
-
    But thou art deeper read and better skill'd;
    Come and take choice of all my library,  
    And so beguile thy sorrow, till the heavens
    Reveal the damn'd contriver of this deed.
 I think she means that there were more than one
    Confederate in the fact; ay, more there was,
    Or else to heaven she heaves them for revenge.
 Soft! So busily she turns the leaves! Help her.
 O, why should nature build so foul a den,
    Unless the gods delight in tragedies?
  TITUS.

    Heaven guide thy pen to print thy sorrows plain,
    That we may know the traitors and the truth!
                               [She takes the staff in her mouth
                          and guides it with stumps, and writes]
    O, do ye read, my lord, what she hath writ?
  TITUS.

  TITUS.
 I say, my lord, that if I were a man
    Their mother's bedchamber should not be safe
    For these base bondmen to the yoke of Rome.
 Ay, that's my boy! Thy father hath full oft
    For his ungrateful country done the like.

    Come, come; thou'lt do my message, wilt thou not?
  BOY.
 Marcus, look to my house.
- May it please you,
    My grandsire, well advis'd, hath sent by me
    The goodliest weapons of his armoury
    To gratify your honourable youth,
    The hope of Rome; for so he bid me say;
    And so I do, and with his gifts present
    Your lordships, that, whenever you have need,  
    You may be armed and appointed well.

    And so I leave you both-  [Aside]  like bloody villains.

    But were our witty Empress well afoot,
    She would applaud Andronicus' conceit.
 A charitable wish and full of love.

  AARON.
 Come, let us go and pray to all the gods
    For our beloved mother in her pains.
 Why do the Emperor's trumpets flourish thus?
  CHIRON.
 Belike, for joy the Emperor hath a son.

  AARON.
 Well, God give her good rest! What hath he sent her?
  NURSE.
 Why, then she is the devil's dam;
    A joyful issue.
 Zounds, ye whore! Is black so base a hue?
    Sweet blowse, you are a beauteous blossom sure.

  CHIRON.

  AARON.

    Woe to her chance, and damn'd her loathed choice!
    Accurs'd the offspring of so foul a fiend!
  CHIRON.
 What, must it, nurse? Then let no man but I
    Do execution on my flesh and blood.

  AARON.

    What, what, ye sanguine, shallow-hearted boys!
    Ye white-lim'd walls! ye alehouse painted signs!
    Coal-black is better than another hue
    In that it scorns to bear another hue;
    For all the water in the ocean
    Can never turn the swan's black legs to white,
    Although she lave them hourly in the flood.

    Tell the Empress from me I am of age
    To keep mine own- excuse it how she can.
 Wilt thou betray thy noble mistress thus?  
  AARON.
 My mistress is my mistress: this my self,
    The vigour and the picture of my youth.

    This before all the world do I prefer;
    This maugre all the world will I keep safe,
    Or some of you shall smoke for it in Rome.

  DEMETRIUS.
 Aaron, what shall I say unto the Empress?
  DEMETRIUS.

    Save thou the child, so we may all be safe.

    But say, again, how many saw the child?
  NURSE.

  AARON.
 What mean'st thou, Aaron? Wherefore didst thou this?
  AARON.

    Shall she live to betray this guilt of ours-
    A long-tongu'd babbling gossip? No, lords, no.

    This done, see that you take no longer days,
    But send the midwife presently to me.
 Aaron, I see thou wilt not trust the air
    With secrets.
 For this care of Tamora,
    Herself and hers are highly bound to thee.


         Exeunt DEMETRIUS and CHIRON, bearing off the dead NURSE

  AARON.

    Go get you gone; and pray be careful all,
    And leave you not a man-of-war unsearch'd.
 O Publius, is not this a heavy case,
    To see thy noble uncle thus distract?
  PUBLIUS.

    Marry, for Justice, she is so employ'd,
    He thinks, with Jove in heaven, or somewhere else,
    So that perforce you must needs stay a time.

    I'll dive into the burning lake below
    And pull her out of Acheron by the heels.
 You are a good archer, Marcus.

                                      [He gives them the arrows]
    'Ad Jovem' that's for you; here 'Ad Apollinem.

    To it, boy.
 Kinsmen, shoot all your shafts into the court;
    We will afflict the Emperor in his pride.

  TITUS.
  [They shoot]  O, well said, Lucius!
    Good boy, in Virgo's lap! Give it Pallas.
 My lord, I aim a mile beyond the moon;
    Your letter is with Jupiter by this.
 Why, villain, art not thou the carrier?
  CLOWN.

  TITUS.
 From heaven! Alas, sir, I never came there.

  TITUS.
 Tell me, can you deliver an oration to the Emperor with a
    grace?
  CLOWN.

    Hold, hold! Meanwhile here's money for thy charges.

    Give me pen and ink.

  TITUS.

    Here, Marcus, fold it in the oration;
    For thou hast made it like a humble suppliant.
 God be with you, sir; I will.

  TITUS.
     Exeunt




SCENE IV.

Rome.
  [Aside]  Why, thus it shall become
    High-witted Tamora to gloze with all.

  TAMORA.
 'Tis he.
                                          [Exit guarded]
  SATURNINUS.
 Despiteful and intolerable wrongs!
    Shall I endure this monstrous villainy?
    I know from whence this same device proceeds.
 Is warlike Lucius general of the Goths?  
    These tidings nip me, and I hang the head
    As flowers with frost, or grass beat down with storms.
 King, be thy thoughts imperious like thy name!
    Is the sun dimm'd, that gnats do fly in it?
    The eagle suffers little birds to sing,
    And is not careful what they mean thereby,
    Knowing that with the shadow of his wings
    He can at pleasure stint their melody;
    Even so mayest thou the giddy men of Rome.
 But he will not entreat his son for us.
 Then go successantly, and plead to him.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
COMMERCIALLY.

  FIRST GOTH.

    But who comes here, led by a lusty Goth?

     Enter a GOTH, leading AARON with his CHILD in his arms

  SECOND GOTH.

  LUCIUS.
 Too like the sire for ever being good.

  AARON.
 Swear that he shall, and then I will begin.
 Who should I swear by? Thou believest no god;  
    That granted, how canst thou believe an oath?
  AARON.

  LUCIUS.
 O most insatiate and luxurious woman!
  AARON.

    'Twas her two sons that murdered Bassianus;  
    They cut thy sister's tongue, and ravish'd her,
    And cut her hands, and trimm'd her as thou sawest.
 O detestable villain! Call'st thou that trimming?
  AARON.
 O barbarous beastly villains like thyself!
  AARON.
'
    Tut, I have done a thousand dreadful things
    As willingly as one would kill a fly;
    And nothing grieves me heartily indeed
    But that I cannot do ten thousand more.
 Sirs, stop his mouth, and let him speak no more.
  

                       Enter AEMILIUS

  GOTH.
 Let him come near.


         They knock and TITUS opens his study door, above

  TITUS.
 Titus, I am come to talk with thee.
 No, not a word.

  TAMORA.
 If thou didst know me, thou wouldst talk with me.

  TITUS.

    Is not thy coming for my other hand?
  TAMORA.
 Art thou Revenge? and art thou sent to me
    To be a torment to mine enemies?
  TAMORA.
 I am; therefore come down and welcome me.

    Provide thee two proper palfreys, black as jet,
    To hale thy vengeful waggon swift away,
    And find out murderers in their guilty caves;
    And when thy car is loaden with their heads,  
    I will dismount, and by thy waggon wheel
    Trot, like a servile footman, all day long,
    Even from Hyperion's rising in the east
    Until his very downfall in the sea.

    See, here he comes, and I must ply my theme.
 Long have I been forlorn, and all for thee.

    Rapine and Murder, you are welcome too.
  
    But welcome as you are.
 Show me a villain that hath done a rape,
    And I am sent to be reveng'd on him.

  TITUS.

    Go thou with them; and in the Emperor's court
    There is a queen, attended by a Moor;
    Well shalt thou know her by thine own proportion,
    For up and down she doth resemble thee.

    What says Andronicus to this device?
  TITUS.

    This do thou for my love; and so let him,
    As he regards his aged father's life.
 This will I do, and soon return again.
            Exit
  TAMORA.

  TITUS.
  [Aside to her sons]  What say you, boys? Will you abide
      with him,
    Whiles I go tell my lord the Emperor
    How I have govern'd our determin'd jest?
    Yield to his humour, smooth and speak him fair,
    And tarry with him till I turn again.
  [Aside]  I knew them all, though they suppos'd me mad,
    And will o'er reach them in their own devices,
    A pair of cursed hell-hounds and their dam.

  TAMORA.

                                                     Exit TAMORA
  CHIRON.
 Tell us, old man, how shall we be employ'd?
  TITUS.


          Enter PUBLIUS, CAIUS, and VALENTINE

  PUBLIUS.

  TITUS.
 Villains, forbear! we are the Empress' sons.
 And therefore do we what we are commanded.

    Now bring them in, for I will play the cook,
    And see them ready against their mother comes.


            Sound trumpets.
 What, hath the firmament more suns than one?
  LUCIUS.
 Because I would be sure to have all well
    To entertain your Highness and your Empress.
 An if your Highness knew my heart, you were.

    My lord the Emperor, resolve me this:
    Was it well done of rash Virginius
    To slay his daughter with his own right hand,
    Because she was enforc'd, stain'd, and deflower'd?
  SATURNINUS.
 What, was she ravish'd? Tell who did the deed.
 Not I; 'twas Chiron and Demetrius.

  SATURNINUS.

  TITUS.
 Can the son's eye behold his father bleed?
    There's meed for meed, death for a deadly deed.
 You sad-fac'd men, people and sons of Rome,
    By uproars sever'd, as a flight of fowl
    Scatter'd by winds and high tempestuous gusts?
    O, let me teach you how to knit again
    This scattered corn into one mutual sheaf,
    These broken limbs again into one body;
    Lest Rome herself be bane unto herself,
    And she whom mighty kingdoms curtsy to,
    Like a forlorn and desperate castaway,
    Do shameful execution on herself.

    For their fell faults our brothers were beheaded,  
    Our father's tears despis'd, and basely cozen'd
    Of that true hand that fought Rome's quarrel out
    And sent her enemies unto the grave.

    I am the turned forth, be it known to you,
    That have preserv'd her welfare in my blood
    And from her bosom took the enemy's point,
    Sheathing the steel in my advent'rous body.

  ALL.
          Exeunt some
              attendants.

    Stand all aloof; but, uncle, draw you near
    To shed obsequious tears upon this trunk.

    O, were the sum of these that I should pay  
    Countless and infinite, yet would I pay them!
  LUCIUS.
 Come hither, boy; come, come, come, and learn of us
    To melt in showers.
 How many thousand times hath these poor lips,
    When they were living, warm'd themselves on thine!
    O, now, sweet boy, give them their latest kiss!
    Bid him farewell; commit him to the grave;
    Do them that kindness, and take leave of them.
 Ah, why should wrath be mute and fury dumb?
    I am no baby, I, that with base prayers
    I should repent the evils I have done;
    Ten thousand worse than ever yet I did
    Would I perform, if I might have my will.

    If one good deed in all my life I did,
    I do repent it from my very soul.

  LUCIUS.
, AND IS
PROVIDED BY PROJECT GUTENBERG ETEXT OF ILLINOIS BENEDICTINE COLLEGE
WITH PERMISSION.





<<THIS ELECTRONIC VERSION OF THE COMPLETE WORKS OF WILLIAM
SHAKESPEARE IS COPYRIGHT 1990-1993 BY WORLD LIBRARY, INC.
 SCENE 1.
 Before PRIAM'S palace

Enter TROILUS armed, and PANDARUS

  TROILUS.

    Why should I war without the walls of Troy
    That find such cruel battle here within?
    Each Troyan that is master of his heart,
    Let him to field; Troilus, alas, hath none!
  PANDARUS.

  PANDARUS.
 Ay, the grinding; but you must tarry the bolting.
 Still have I tarried.
 I  will not dispraise your sister Cassandra's wit; but-
  TROILUS.
 Thou answer'st 'She is fair'-
    Pourest in the open ulcer of my heart-
    Her eyes, her hair, her cheek, her gait, her voice,
    Handlest in thy discourse.

  PANDARUS.
 Faith, I'll not meddle in it.
 Let her be as she is: if
    she be fair, 'tis the better for her; an she be not, she has the
    mends in her own hands.
 But what care I? I care not an she were a
    blackamoor; 'tis all one to me.
 Let her to the Greeks; and so I'll tell her
    the next time I see her.

  TROILUS.

    But Pandarus-O gods, how do you plague me!
    I cannot come to Cressid but by Pandar;
    And he's as tetchy to be woo'd to woo
    As she is stubborn-chaste against all suit.


                Alarum.

  TROILUS.

    He chid Andromache, and struck his armourer;
    And, like as there were husbandry in war,
    Before the sun rose he was harness'd light,
    And to the field goes he; where every flower
    Did as a prophet weep what it foresaw
    In Hector's wrath.
 What was his cause of anger?
  ALEXANDER.
 The noise goes, this: there is among the Greeks
    A lord of Troyan blood, nephew to Hector;
    They call him Ajax.

  CRESSIDA.
 So do all men, unless they are drunk, sick, or have no
    legs.
 They say he yesterday cop'd Hector in the battle and
    struck him down, the disdain and shame whereof hath ever since
    kept Hector fasting and waking.
  

                          Enter PANDARUS

  CRESSIDA.
 This morning, uncle.

  PANDARUS.
 True, he was so; I know the cause too; he'll lay about  
    him today, I can tell them that.
 What, is he angry too?
  PANDARUS.
 What, not between Troilus and Hector? Do you know a man
    if you see him?
  CRESSIDA.
 Ay, if I ever saw him before and knew him.

  CRESSIDA.
 He is not Hector.

  PANDARUS.

  CRESSIDA.
 Nor his qualities.
 Helen herself swore th'
    other day that Troilus, for a brown favour, for so 'tis, I must
    confess- not brown neither-
  CRESSIDA.
 Faith, to say truth, brown and not brown.

  CRESSIDA.
 She prais'd his complexion above Paris.

  PANDARUS.
 I swear to you I think Helen loves him better than Paris.
 Juno have mercy! How came it cloven?
  PANDARUS.
 Troilus will stand to the proof, if you'll prove it so.

  PANDARUS.
 But there was a more temperate fire under the pot of her
    eyes.
 Marry, at the white hair that Helen spied on Troilus'
    chin.

  CRESSIDA.
 That white hair is my father,
    and all the rest are his sons.
 Well, cousin, I told you a thing yesterday; think on't.

  PANDARUS.
 And I'll spring up in his tears, an 'twere a nettle
    against May.
                                    [Sound a retreat]
  PANDARUS.

  CRESSIDA.

  PANDARUS.
 Here, here, here's an excellent place; here we may see
    most bravely.
 Speak not so loud.
 If he do, the rich shall have more.
 There's a countenance! Is't not a  
    brave man?
  CRESSIDA.
 There be hacks.
 Swords! anything, he cares not; an the devil come to him,
    it's all one.

  CRESSIDA.
 Where? yonder? That's Deiphobus.
 Mark him; note him.
 Here comes more.


                 Common soldiers pass

  PANDARUS.

    Ne'er look, ne'er look; the eagles are gone.
 Crows and daws,
    crows and daws! I had rather be such a man as Troilus than
    Agamemnon and all Greece.

  CRESSIDA.

  PANDARUS.
 Well, well.

  PANDARUS.

  PANDARUS.
 Nay, I'll watch you for that; and that's one of the
    chiefest of them too.

  CRESSIDA.

    Then though my heart's content firm love doth bear,  
    Nothing of that shall from mine eyes appear.

  ULYSSES.
 Agamemnon,
    Thou great commander, nerve and bone of Greece,  
    Heart of our numbers, soul and only spirit
    In whom the tempers and the minds of all
    Should be shut up-hear what Ulysses speaks.
 Troy, yet upon his basis, had been down,  
    And the great Hector's sword had lack'd a master,
    But for these instances:
    The specialty of rule hath been neglected;
    And look how many Grecian tents do stand
    Hollow upon this plain, so many hollow factions.

    When that the general is not like the hive,
    To whom the foragers shall all repair,
    What honey is expected? Degree being vizarded,
    Th' unworthiest shows as fairly in the mask.

    The heavens themselves, the planets, and this centre,
    Observe degree, priority, and place,
    Insisture, course, proportion, season, form,
    Office, and custom, in all line of order;
    And therefore is the glorious planet Sol
    In noble eminence enthron'd and spher'd
    Amidst the other, whose med'cinable eye
    Corrects the ill aspects of planets evil,
    And posts, like the commandment of a king,
    Sans check, to good and bad.
 But when the planets
    In evil mixture to disorder wander,  
    What plagues and what portents, what mutiny,
    What raging of the sea, shaking of earth,
    Commotion in the winds! Frights, changes, horrors,
    Divert and crack, rend and deracinate,
    The unity and married calm of states
    Quite from their fixture! O, when degree is shak'd,
    Which is the ladder of all high designs,
    The enterprise is sick! How could communities,
    Degrees in schools, and brotherhoods in cities,
    Peaceful commerce from dividable shores,
    The primogenity and due of birth,
    Prerogative of age, crowns, sceptres, laurels,
    But by degree, stand in authentic place?
    Take but degree away, untune that string,
    And hark what discord follows! Each thing melts
    In mere oppugnancy: the bounded waters
    Should lift their bosoms higher than the shores,
    And make a sop of all this solid globe;
    Strength should be lord of imbecility,
    And the rude son should strike his father dead;  
    Force should be right; or, rather, right and wrong-
    Between whose endless jar justice resides-
    Should lose their names, and so should justice too.
'
    And then, forsooth, the faint defects of age
    Must be the scene of mirth: to cough and spit
    And, with a palsy-fumbling on his gorget,
    Shake in and out the rivet.
 Let this be granted, and Achilles' horse
    Makes many Thetis' sons.
                                 [Tucket]
  AGAMEMNON.

  MENELAUS.
 Ay;
    I ask, that I might waken reverence,
    And bid the cheek be ready with a blush
    Modest as Morning when she coldly eyes
    The youthful Phoebus.
 Courtiers as free, as debonair, unarm'd,
    As bending angels; that's their fame in peace.
 Sir, you of Troy, call you yourself Aeneas?
  AENEAS.

    Hector, in view of Troyans and of Greeks,
    Shall make it good or do his best to do it:
    He hath a lady wiser, fairer, truer,
    Than ever Greek did couple in his arms;
    And will to-morrow with his trumpet call
    Mid-way between your tents and walls of Troy
    To rouse a Grecian that is true in love.

    If any come, Hector shall honour him;
    If none, he'll say in Troy, when he retires,
    The Grecian dames are sunburnt and not worth
    The splinter of a lance.
 But we are soldiers;
    And may that soldier a mere recreant prove
    That means not, hath not, or is not in love.
 He is old now;
    But if there be not in our Grecian mould
    One noble man that hath one spark of fire
    To answer for his love, tell him from me
    I'll hide my silver beard in a gold beaver,
    And in my vantbrace put this wither'd brawn,
    And, meeting him, will tell him that my lady
    Was fairer than his grandame, and as chaste
    As may be in the world.
 Now heavens forfend such scarcity of youth!
  ULYSSES.
 Nestor!
  NESTOR.
 What says Ulysses?
  ULYSSES.
 I have a young conception in my brain;
    Be you my time to bring it to some shape.
 This 'tis:
    Blunt wedges rive hard knots.
 Well, and how?
  ULYSSES.
 Who may you else oppose
    That can from Hector bring those honours off,
    If not Achilles? Though 't be a sportful combat,
    Yet in this trial much opinion dwells;
    For here the Troyans taste our dear'st repute
    With their fin'st palate; and trust to me, Ulysses,
    Our imputation shall be oddly pois'd
    In this vile action; for the success,
    Although particular, shall give a scantling
    Of good or bad unto the general;
    And in such indexes, although small pricks
    To their subsequent volumes, there is seen
    The baby figure of the giant mas
    Of things to come at large.

    Therefore 'tis meet Achilles meet not Hector.
 I see them not with my old eyes.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.

The Grecian camp

Enter Ajax and THERSITES

  AJAX.
 Thou bitch-wolf's son, canst thou not hear? Feel, then.

  AJAX.

  THERSITES.
 I would thou didst itch from head to foot and I had the
    scratching of thee; I would make thee the loathsomest scab in
    Greece.

  AJAX.
 He would pun thee into shivers with his fist, as a
    sailor breaks a biscuit.
 Ay, do, do; thou sodden-witted lord! Thou hast no more
    brain than I have in mine elbows; an assinico may tutor thee.
 You scurvy lord!
  AJAX.
 What's the matter?
  THERSITES.
 I know that, fool.
 Therefore I beat thee.
 Lo, lo, lo, lo, what modicums of wit he utters! His
    evasions have ears thus long.
 What?
  THERSITES.
 Nay, I must hold you.

  THERSITES.
 I would have peace and quietness, but the fool will not-
    he there; that he; look you there.
 Good words, Thersites.

  ACHILLES.

  THERSITES.
 Yes, good sooth.
 'Tis no matter; I shall speak as much as thou
    afterwards.
 No more words, Thersites; peace!
  THERSITES.
 Farewell.

  AJAX.
  
    Since the first sword was drawn about this question,
    Every tithe soul 'mongst many thousand dismes
    Hath been as dear as Helen-I mean, of ours.

    Who marvels, then, when Helenus beholds
    A Grecian and his sword, if he do set
    The very wings of reason to his heels
    And fly like chidden Mercury from Jove,
    Or like a star disorb'd? Nay, if we talk of reason,
    Let's shut our gates and sleep.
 Manhood and honour
    Should have hare hearts, would they but fat their thoughts
    With this cramm'd reason.

  HECTOR.
 Brother, she is not worth what she doth, cost
    The keeping.
 'Tis our mad sister; I do know her voice.

  HECTOR.
 Cry, Troyans, cry.

  HECTOR.

    Cry, Troyans, cry, A Helen and a woe!  
    Cry, cry.
 Now, youthful Troilus, do not these high strains
    Of divination in our sister work
    Some touches of remorse, or is your blood
    So madly hot that no discourse of reason,
    Nor fear of bad success in a bad cause,
    Can qualify the same?
  TROILUS.
 Her brain-sick raptures
    Cannot distaste the goodness of a quarrel
    Which hath our several honours all engag'd
    To make it gracious.

  PARIS.

  HECTOR.

    The reasons you allege do more conduce
    To the hot passion of distemp'red blood  
    Than to make up a free determination
    'Twixt right and wrong; for pleasure and revenge
    Have ears more deaf than adders to the voice
    Of any true decision.
 Thus to persist
    In doing wrong extenuates not wrong,
    But makes it much more heavy.

  HECTOR.
 Who's there? Thersites! Good Thersites, come in and
    rail.
 Where's Achilles?
  PATROCLUS.
 Ay, the heavens hear me!
  PATROCLUS.


                      Enter ACHILLES
  
  ACHILLES.

  PATROCLUS.
 He is a privileg'd man.

  PATROCLUS.
 Why am I a fool?
  THERSITES.
 Now the dry serpigo on
    the subject, and war and lechery confound all!               Exit

         Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, DIOMEDES,
                   AJAX, and CALCHAS

  AGAMEMNON.
  
  AGAMEMNON.
 Let it be known to him that we are here.

  PATROCLUS.
 I shall say so to him.
                              Exit
  ULYSSES.

  NESTOR.
 Then will Ajax lack matter, if he have lost his argument
  ULYSSES.
 The amity that wisdom knits not, folly may easily untie.


                    Re-enter PATROCLUS

    Here comes Patroclus.
 No Achilles with him.
 The elephant hath joints, but none for courtesy; his legs
    are legs for necessity, not for flexure.

  AGAMEMNON.
  
    Much attribute he hath, and much the reason
    Why we ascribe it to him.

    A stirring dwarf we do allowance give
    Before a sleeping giant.

  AJAX.
 Is he so much? Do you not think he thinks himself a better
    man than I am?
  AGAMEMNON.

  AJAX.
 Pride is his own glass,
    his own trumpet, his own chronicle; and whatever praises itself  
    but in the deed devours the deed in the praise.
 I do hate a proud man as I do hate the engend'ring of toads.
 O Agamemnon, let it not be so!
    We'll consecrate the steps that Ajax makes
    When they go from Achilles.

    This lord go to him! Jupiter forbid,
    And say in thunder 'Achilles go to him.
 O, no, you shall not go.

    Let me go to him.

  ULYSSES.
 A paltry, insolent fellow!
  NESTOR.
 [Aside] How he describes himself!
  AJAX.

  AJAX.
 [Aside] Wit would be out of fashion.

  ULYSSES.

  ULYSSES.

  ULYSSES.

  NESTOR.
 Know the whole world, he is as valiant.

  AJAX.
 Thank the heavens, lord, thou art of sweet composure
    Praise him that gat thee, she that gave thee suck;
    Fam'd be thy tutor, and thy parts of nature
    Thrice-fam'd beyond, beyond all erudition;
    But he that disciplin'd thine arms to fight-
    Let Mars divide eternity in twain
    And give him half; and, for thy vigour,
    Bull-bearing Milo his addition yield
    To sinewy Ajax.
 I will not praise thy wisdom,
    Which, like a bourn, a pale, a shore, confines
    Thy spacious and dilated parts.
 To-morrow
    We must with all our main of power stand fast;
    And here's a lord-come knights from east to west
    And cull their flower, Ajax shall cope the best.

    Light boats sail swift, though greater hulks draw deep.
>>



ACT III.

  SERVANT.
 The lord be praised!
  PANDARUS.
 You know me, do you not?
  SERVANT.

  SERVANT.
 I do desire it.

  SERVANT.
 I do but partly know, sir; it is music in parts.
  
  PANDARUS.
 Know you the musicians?
  SERVANT.
 Command, I mean, friend.

  SERVANT.
 Who shall I command, sir?
  PANDARUS.
 At whose request do these men play?
  SERVANT.
 That's to't, indeed, sir.
 Who, my cousin, Cressida?
  SERVANT.
 Could not you find out that by her
    attributes?
  PANDARUS.
 It should seem, fellow, that thou hast not seen the Lady
    Cressida.

  HELEN.

  PARIS.
 He is full of harmony.
 Nay, this shall not hedge us out.
 -And, my
    lord, he desires you that, if the King call for him at supper,
    you will make his excuse.

  HELEN.
 What says my sweet queen, my very very sweet queen?
  PARIS.
 No, no, no such matter; you are wide.

  PARIS.
 She shall have it, my lord, if it be not my Lord Paris.
 Falling in, after falling out, may make them three.
 Come, come.
 Ay, you may, you may.

  PARIS.
 In good troth, it begins so.
                      [Sings]

    Love, love, nothing but love, still love, still more!
           For, oh, love's bow
           Shoots buck and doe;
           The shaft confounds
           Not that it wounds,
    But tickles still the sore.
 Is love a generation of
    vipers? Sweet lord, who's a-field today?
  PARIS.
 I would fain have arm'd to-day, but my Nell would not
    have it so.

  PANDARUS.
 Sweet Helen, I must woo you
    To help unarm our Hector.

  HELEN.
 'Twill make us proud to be his servant, Paris;
    Yea, what he shall receive of us in duty
    Gives us more palm in beauty than we have,
    Yea, overshines ourself.
 PANDARUS' orchard

Enter PANDARUS and TROILUS' BOY, meeting

  PANDARUS.


                      Enter TROILUS

  PANDARUS.
 O, be thou my Charon,
    And give me swift transportance to these fields
    Where I may wallow in the lily beds
    Propos'd for the deserver! O gentle Pandar,
    From Cupid's shoulder pluck his painted wings,
    And fly with me to Cressid!
  PANDARUS.
  
      Exit
  TROILUS.
 She's making her ready, she'll come straight; you must be
    witty now.
 It is the
    prettiest villain; she fetches her breath as short as a new-ta'en  
    sparrow.
                                                     Exit
  TROILUS.
 Even such a passion doth embrace my bosom.


              Re-enter PANDARUS With CRESSIDA

  PANDARUS.
 Nay, you shall fight your hearts out ere I part you.
 Go to, go  
    to.

  PANDARUS.
 Fears make devils of cherubims; they never see truly.
 To fear the worst oft
    cures the worse.
 O, let my lady apprehend no fear! In all Cupid's pageant
    there is presented no monster.
 They that have the voice of lions and the act
    of hares, are they not monsters?
  TROILUS.
 Praise us as we are
    tasted, allow us as we prove; our head shall go bare till merit
    crown it.
  
  CRESSIDA.

  PANDARUS.

  TROILUS.
 See, see, your silence,
    Cunning in dumbness, from my weakness draws
    My very soul of counsel.
 Stop my mouth.
 Pretty, i' faith.
 Leave! An you take leave till to-morrow morning-
  CRESSIDA.
 You cannot shun yourself.
 Let me go and try.

    I have a kind of self resides with you;
    But an unkind self, that itself will leave
    To be another's fool.
 I would be gone.
 O that I thought it could be in a woman-
    As, if it can, I will presume in you-  
    To feed for aye her lamp and flames of love;
    To keep her constancy in plight and youth,
    Outliving beauty's outward, with a mind
    That doth renew swifter than blood decays!
    Or that persuasion could but thus convince me
    That my integrity and truth to you
    Might be affronted with the match and weight
    Of such a winnowed purity in love.

    How were I then uplifted! but, alas,
    I am as true as truth's simplicity,
    And simpler than the infancy of truth.
'
  PANDARUS.
 Go to, a bargain made; seal it, seal it; I'll be the  
    witness.
 Here I hold your hand; here my cousin's.

  CRESSIDA.
 Amen.
 Away!
    And Cupid grant all tongue-tied maidens here,
    Bed, chamber, pander, to provide this gear!                Exeunt




ACT III.

The Greek camp

Flourish.
 Let him be sent, great Princes,
    And he shall buy my daughter; and her presence
    Shall quite strike off all service I have done
    In most accepted pain.
  
  DIOMEDES.

                                          Exeunt DIOMEDES and CALCHAS

           ACHILLES and PATROCLUS stand in their tent

  ULYSSES.
 Achilles stands i' th' entrance of his tent.

    It may do good.
 I'll fight no more 'gainst Troy.

  AGAMEMNON.
 What says Achilles? Would he aught with us?
  NESTOR.
 Would you, my lord, aught with the general?
  ACHILLES.
 Ha?
  ACHILLES.

  AJAX.
 What mean these fellows? Know they not Achilles?  
  PATROCLUS.
 But 'tis not so with me:
    Fortune and I are friends; I do enjoy
    At ample point all that I did possess  
    Save these men's looks; who do, methinks, find out
    Something not worth in me such rich beholding
    As they have often given.
 Now, great Thetis' son!
  ACHILLES.
 Heavens, what a man is there!
    A very horse that has he knows not what!  
    Nature, what things there are
    Most abject in regard and dear in use!
    What things again most dear in the esteem
    And poor in worth! Now shall we see to-morrow-
    An act that very chance doth throw upon him-
    Ajax renown'd.
 Then what they do in present,
    Though less than yours in past, must o'ertop yours;
    For Time is like a fashionable host,
    That slightly shakes his parting guest by th' hand;  
    And with his arms out-stretch'd, as he would fly,
    Grasps in the corner.

    One touch of nature makes the whole world kin-
    That all with one consent praise new-born gawds,
    Though they are made and moulded of things past,
    And give to dust that is a little gilt
    More laud than gilt o'er-dusted.

    The present eye praises the present object.

    But it must grieve young Pyrrhus now at home,
    When fame shall in our island sound her trump,
    And all the Greekish girls shall tripping sing
    'Great Hector's sister did Achilles win;
    But our great Ajax bravely beat down him.
 I as your lover speak.
 To this effect, Achilles, have I mov'd you.
 Ay, and perhaps receive much honour by him.
 Go call Thersites hither, sweet Patroclus.
 A wonder!
  ACHILLES.
 The man's
    undone for ever; for if Hector break not his neck i' th' combat,
    he'll break't himself in vainglory.
 I said 'Good  
    morrow, Ajax'; and he replies 'Thanks, Agamemnon.
' What think you
    of this man that takes me for the general? He's grown a very land
    fish, languageless, a monster.
 Who most humbly desires you to invite Hector to his  
    tent-
  THERSITES.

  THERSITES.
 God buy you, with all my heart.
 Fare ye well, with all my heart.

  ACHILLES.
 No, but he's out a tune thus.
 I had rather be a tick in a sheep than
    such a valiant ignorance.
  PROHIBITED COMMERCIAL DISTRIBUTION INCLUDES BY ANY
SERVICE THAT CHARGES FOR DOWNLOAD TIME OR FOR MEMBERSHIP.

  AENEAS.
 Good morrow, Lord Aeneas.

  AENEAS.
 And thou shalt hunt a lion, that will fly
    With his face backward.
 We sympathise.
 We know each other well.

  DIOMEDES.
                         Exit with servant
  PARIS.
 Both alike:
    He merits well to have her that doth seek her,
    Not making any scruple of her soilure,
    With such a hell of pain and world of charge;
    And you as well to keep her that defend her,
    Not palating the taste of her dishonour,
    With such a costly loss of wealth and friends.
 Then, sweet my lord, I'll call mine uncle down;
    He shall unbolt the gates.

  CRESSIDA.
 Hark! there's one up.
 It is your uncle.

    You bring me to do, and then you flout me too.
 To do what? to do what? Let her say what.

    What have I brought you to do?
  CRESSIDA.
 Come, come, beshrew your heart! You'll ne'er be good,  
    Nor suffer others.
 Ha! ha!
  CRESSIDA.
 Who's there? What's the matter? Will you beat down the
    door? How now? What's the matter?

                          Enter AENEAS  
  AENEAS.
 Who's there? My lord Aeneas? By my troth,
    I knew you not.
 For my own part, I came in late.


                       Re-enter TROILUS

  TROILUS.
 My lord, I scarce have leisure to salute you,
    My matter is so rash.
 By Priam, and the general state of Troy.

    They are at hand and ready to effect it.
 A plague upon Antenor! I
    would they had broke's neck.
 Why sigh you so profoundly? Where's my lord? Gone? Tell
    me, sweet uncle, what's the matter?
  PANDARUS.
 Would I were as deep under the earth as I am above!
  CRESSIDA.
 O you gods divine,  
    Make Cressid's name the very crown of falsehood,
    If ever she leave Troilus! Time, force, and death,
    Do to this body what extremes you can,
    But the strong base and building of my love
    Is as the very centre of the earth,
    Drawing all things to it.
 I'll go in and weep-
  PANDARUS.
 Tear my bright hair, and scratch my praised cheeks,
    Crack my clear voice with sobs and break my heart,
    With sounding 'Troilus.

Troy.
 It is great morning; and the hour prefix'd
    For her delivery to this valiant Greek
    Comes fast upon.
                Exit
  PARIS.
                              Exeunt




ACT IV.
 Cressid, I love thee in so strain'd a purity
    That the bless'd gods, as angry with my fancy,
    More bright in zeal than the devotion which
    Cold lips blow to their deities, take thee from me.
 Have the gods envy?
  PANDARUS.

    We two, that with so many thousand sighs
    Did buy each other, must poorly sell ourselves
    With the rude brevity and discharge of one.
 [Within] My lord, is the lady ready?
  TROILUS.
 I true! how now! What wicked deem is this?
  TROILUS.

    The Grecian youths are full of quality;
    They're loving, well compos'd with gifts of nature,
    And flowing o'er with arts and exercise.

  CRESSIDA.
 I cannot sing,
    Nor heel the high lavolt, nor sweeten talk,
    Nor play at subtle games-fair virtues all,
    To which the Grecians are most prompt and pregnant;
    But I can tell that in each grace of these
    There lurks a still and dumb-discoursive devil  
    That tempts most cunningly.

  CRESSIDA.
 Come, kiss; and let us part.

  PARIS.

  TROILUS.
 I tell thee, lord of Greece,
    She is as far high-soaring o'er thy praises  
    As thou unworthy to be call'd her servant.

  DIOMEDES.
 And know you, lord,
    I'll nothing do on charge: to her own worth
    She shall be priz'd.
 But that you say 'Be't so,'
    I speak it in my spirit and honour, 'No.
 Come, to the port.

                               Exeunt TROILUS, CRESSIDA, and DIOMEDES
                                                      [Sound trumpet]
  PARIS.

  DEIPHOBUS.
 Let us make ready straight.

  AJAX.

  ACHILLES.
 'Tis but early days.


                Enter DIOMEDES, with CRESSIDA  

  AGAMEMNON.
 But that's no argument for kissing now;
    For thus popp'd Paris in his hardiment,
    And parted thus you and your argument.

  MENELAUS.
 Lady, by your leave.

  CRESSIDA.
 You are an odd man; give even or give none.
 You fillip me o' th' head.

  ULYSSES.
 I do desire it.
 Why, beg then.

  CRESSIDA.
 I am your debtor; claim it when 'tis due.
 Never's my day, and then a kiss of you.
 A woman of quick sense.
 Fie, fie upon her!
    There's language in her eye, her cheek, her lip,
    Nay, her foot speaks; her wanton spirits look out
    At every joint and motive of her body.
 Yonder comes the troop.
 Which way would Hector have it?
  AENEAS.

  AENEAS.
 Therefore Achilles.
 Weigh him well,
    And that which looks like pride is courtesy.

    This Ajax is half made of Hector's blood;
    In love whereof half Hector stays at home;
    Half heart, half hand, half Hector comes to seek
    This blended knight, half Troyan and half Greek.

  ACHILLES.
 The youngest son of Priam, a true knight;
    Not yet mature, yet matchless; firm of word;
    Speaking in deeds and deedless in his tongue;
    Not soon provok'd, nor being provok'd soon calm'd;
    His heart and hand both open and both free;
    For what he has he gives, what thinks he shows,
    Yet gives he not till judgment guide his bounty,
    Nor dignifies an impair thought with breath;
    Manly as Hector, but more dangerous;
    For Hector in his blaze of wrath subscribes
    To tender objects, but he in heat of action
    Is more vindicative than jealous love.

  AJAX.
 I am not warm yet; let us fight again.

  AENEAS.
 Ajax, farewell.

  HECTOR.
 The worthiest of them tell me name by name;  
    But for Achilles, my own searching eyes
    Shall find him by his large and portly size.

  AGAMEMNON.

    You brace of warlike brothers, welcome hither.
 O you, my lord? By Mars his gauntlet, thanks!
    Mock not that I affect the untraded oath;
    Your quondam wife swears still by Venus' glove.
  
    She's well, but bade me not commend her to you.

  HECTOR.
 He was a soldier good,
    But, by great Mars, the captain of us all,
    Never like thee.

  HECTOR.

    Most reverend Nestor, I am glad to clasp thee.

  NESTOR.

    Ah, sir, there's many a Greek and Troyan dead,
    Since first I saw yourself and Diomed
    In Ilion on your Greekish embassy.

    After the General, I beseech you next
    To feast with me and see me at my tent.

  HECTOR.
 Is this Achilles?
  ACHILLES.

  ACHILLES.
 Behold thy fill.
 Answer me, heavens.
 Wert thou an oracle to tell me so,
    I'd not believe thee.

    His insolence draws folly from my lips;
    But I'll endeavour deeds to match these words,
    Or may I never-
  AJAX.

    You may have every day enough of Hector,
    If you have stomach.
 Thy hand upon that match.
 At Menelaus' tent, most princely Troilus.
  ELECTRONIC AND MACHINE READABLE COPIES MAY BE
DISTRIBUTED SO LONG AS SUCH COPIES (1) ARE FOR YOUR OR OTHERS
PERSONAL USE ONLY, AND (2) ARE NOT DISTRIBUTED OR USED
COMMERCIALLY.
 Male varlet, you rogue! What's that?
  THERSITES.
 Do I curse thee?
  PATROCLUS.
 My sweet Patroclus, I am thwarted quite
    From my great purpose in to-morrow's battle.

    Come, come, Thersites, help to trim my tent;
    This night in banqueting must all be spent.
 We go wrong, we go wrong.
 I trouble you.

  DIOMEDES.
 They say he keeps a
    Troyan drab, and uses the traitor Calchas' tent.
 How now, my charge!
  CRESSIDA.
 Now, my sweet guardian! Hark, a word with you.

  DIOMEDES.
 What shall she remember?
  ULYSSES.
 List!
  CRESSIDA.
 Sweet honey Greek, tempt me no more to folly.
 Nay, then-
  CRESSIDA.

  DIOMEDES.
 I prithee, do not hold me to mine oath;
    Bid me do anything but that, sweet Greek.
  
  TROILUS.
 No, no, good night; I'll be your fool no more.

  ULYSSES.

  TROILUS.
 I prithee stay.

  ULYSSES.
 I pray you, stay; by hell and all hell's torments,
    I will not speak a word.
 How now, my lord?
  TROILUS.

  CRESSIDA.
 Come, come.
 Fear me not, my lord;
    I will not be myself, nor have cognition
    Of what I feel.
 Well said, whetstone.
 What, this?  
  DIOMEDES.

  DIOMEDES.
 I had your heart before; this follows it.
 You shall not have it, Diomed; faith, you shall not;
    I'll give you something else.
 I will have this.
 Whose was it?
  CRESSIDA.

  DIOMEDES.

  CRESSIDA.

  CRESSIDA.
 You shall not go.
 I do not like this fooling.
 I shall be plagu'd.
                 Exit DIOMEDES
    Troilus, farewell! One eye yet looks on thee;
    But with my heart the other eye doth see.

    Ah, poor our sex! this fault in us I find,
    The error of our eye directs our mind.
 All's done, my lord.

  TROILUS.

  ULYSSES.

    But if I tell how these two did coact,
    Shall I not lie in publishing a truth?
    Sith yet there is a credence in my heart,
    An esperance so obstinately strong,
    That doth invert th' attest of eyes and ears;
    As if those organs had deceptious functions
    Created only to calumniate.
 I cannot conjure, Troyan.

  ULYSSES.
 Most sure she was.
  
  TROILUS.
 Why, my negation hath no taste of madness.
 Nor mine, my lord.
 Rather think this not Cressid.
 What hath she done, Prince, that can soil our mothers?
  TROILUS.
 Nothing at all, unless that this were she.
 Will 'a swagger himself out on's own eyes?
  TROILUS.
  
    Within my soul there doth conduce a fight
    Of this strange nature, that a thing inseparate
    Divides more wider than the sky and earth;
    And yet the spacious breadth of this division
    Admits no orifex for a point as subtle
    As Ariachne's broken woof to enter.

    Instance, O instance! strong as heaven itself:
    The bonds of heaven are slipp'd, dissolv'd, and loos'd;
    And with another knot, five-finger-tied,
    The fractions of her faith, orts of her love,
    The fragments, scraps, the bits, and greasy relics
    Of her o'er-eaten faith, are bound to Diomed.
 May worthy Troilus be half-attach'd
    With that which here his passion doth express?
  TROILUS.
 I have been seeking you this hour, my lord.
 I'll bring you to the gates.
 Accept distracted thanks.

Troy.
 When was my lord so much ungently temper'd
    To stop his ears against admonishment?
    Unarm, unarm, and do not fight to-day.
 You train me to offend you; get you in.

    By all the everlasting gods, I'll go.

  HECTOR.

    Consort with me in loud and dear petition,
    Pursue we him on knees; for I have dreamt
    Of bloody turbulence, and this whole night
    Hath nothing been but shapes and forms of slaughter.
 Ho! bid my trumpet sound.
 No notes of sally, for the heavens, sweet brother!
  HECTOR.
 Be gone, I say.

    Let grow thy sinews till their knots be strong,
    And tempt not yet the brushes of the war.

  TROILUS.

  TROILUS.

  HECTOR.
 O, 'tis fair play!
  TROILUS.

  HECTOR.

    Therefore, come back.
 Aeneas is a-field;
    And I do stand engag'd to many Greeks,
    Even in the faith of valour, to appear
    This morning to them.

    You know me dutiful; therefore, dear sir,
    Let me not shame respect; but give me leave
    To take that course by your consent and voice
    Which you do here forbid me, royal Priam.
 O Priam, yield not to him!
  ANDROMACHE.
 O, farewell, dear Hector!
    Look how thou diest.

    Look how thy wounds do bleed at many vents.
 Away, away!
  CASSANDRA.

  PRIAM.
 Alarums
  TROILUS.

  TROILUS.
 Words, words, mere words, no matter from the heart;
    Th' effect doth operate another way.

The plain between Troy and the Grecian camp

Enter THERSITES.
 That dissembling abominable varlet, Diomed, has got that same
    scurvy doting foolish young knave's sleeve of Troy there in his
    helm.

  DIOMEDES.
 Hold thy whore, Grecian; now for thy whore,
    Troyan-now the sleeve, now the sleeve!
                                 Exeunt TROILUS and DIOMEDES fighting

                        Enter HECTOR

  HECTOR.
 SCENE 5.
 The dreadful Sagittary
    Appals our numbers.
 Haste we, Diomed,
    To reinforcement, or we perish all.

    There is a thousand Hectors in the field;
    Now here he fights on Galathe his horse,
    And there lacks work; anon he's there afoot,
    And there they fly or die, like scaled sculls
    Before the belching whale; then is he yonder,
    And there the strawy Greeks, ripe for his edge,
    Fall down before him like the mower's swath.

    Patroclus' wounds have rous'd his drowsy blood,
    Together with his mangled Myrmidons,
    That noseless, handless, hack'd and chipp'd, come to
    him, Crying on Hector.
 Troilus! thou coward Troilus!                            Exit
  DIOMEDES.
                              Exit
                      Enter ACHILLES

  ACHILLES.
 Troilus, thou coward Troilus, show thy head.


                     Enter DIOMEDES

  DIOMEDES.
 I would correct him.
 Ha! art thou there?
  AJAX.
                              Exit
  HECTOR.
 Ajax hath ta'en Aeneas.
 Fate, hear me what I say:
    I reck not though thou end my life to-day.

Another part of the plain

Enter ACHILLES, with Myrmidons

  ACHILLES.
 Come here about me, you my Myrmidons;
    Mark what I say.

    Follow me, sirs, and my proceedings eye.
 Now, bull!
    now, dog! 'Loo, Paris, 'loo! now my double-horn'd Spartan! 'loo,
    Paris, 'loo! The bull has the game.

  THERSITES.
 A bastard son of Priam's.

                                                       [HECTOR falls]
    So, Ilion, fall thou next! Come, Troy, sink down;
    Here lies thy heart, thy sinews, and thy bone.

  ACHILLES.
 Shout.
 Hark! hark! what shout is this?
  NESTOR.
 [Within] Achilles! Achilles! Hector's slain.
 Achilles!
  DIOMEDES.
 If it be so, yet bragless let it be;
    Great Hector was as good a man as he.
 March patiently along.


                         Enter TROILUS

  TROILUS.
 Hector! The gods forbid!
  TROILUS.

    I say at once let your brief plagues be mercy,
    And linger not our sure destructions on.
 My lord, you do discomfort all the host.
 You understand me not that tell me so.
'
    There is a word will Priam turn to stone;
    Make wells and Niobes of the maids and wives,
    Cold statues of the youth; and, in a word,
    Scare Troy out of itself.
 Hence, broker-lackey.

    Till then I'll sweat and seek about for eases,
